PREFACE
This City Code of the City of Duncan, as supplemented, contains ordinances and
resolutions up to and including Ordinance 1790, passed June 25, 2019, and
Resolution 1520, passed August 11, 2009. Ordinances and resolutions of the City
adopted after said ordinance and resolution supersede the provisions of this
City Code to the extent that they are in conflict or inconsistent therewith.
Consult the City office in order to ascertain whether any particular provision
of the Code has been amended, superseded or repealed.
Sterling Codifiers
Coeur d'Alene, Idaho
PENDING ORDINANCES
 
PART 1
GENERAL PROVISIONS
CHAPTER 1
USE AND CONSTRUCTION OF THE CODE
SECTION:
1-101: How Code Designated And Cited
1-102: Rules Of Construction
1-103: Catchlines Of Sections; Citations
1-104: Effect Of Repeal Of Ordinances
1-105: Severability Of Parts Of Code

1-101: HOW CODE DESIGNATED AND CITED 1 :
The provisions embraced in the following chapters and sections shall constitute
and be designated the CODE OF ORDINANCES, CITY OF DUNCAN, OKLAHOMA, and may be
so cited. (1985 Code)
 
Notes
1 1. 11 OS §§ 14-108, 14-109.
1-102: RULES OF CONSTRUCTION:
In the construction of this code and of all ordinances, the following rules are
observed unless the construction would be inconsistent with the manifest intent
of the council:
CITY OR THIS CITY: Shall be construed as if the words "of Duncan, Oklahoma",
followed them.
COMPUTATION OF TIME: Whenever a notice is required to be given or an act to be
done a certain length of time before any proceeding shall be had, the day on
which the notice is given or the act is done shall be counted in computing the
time but the day on which the proceeding is to be had shall not be counted.
COUNCIL OR CITY COUNCIL: The city council of Duncan.
COUNTY OR THIS COUNTY: The county of Stephens, Oklahoma.
GENDER: A word importing one gender only shall extend and be applied to other
genders and to firms, partnerships, and corporations as well.
JOINT AUTHORITY: All words giving "joint authority" to three (3) or more
persons or officers shall be construed as giving such authority to a majority
of such persons or officers.
LAW: Includes applicable federal law, provisions of the constitution and
statutes of the state of Oklahoma, the ordinances of the city, and, when
appropriate, any and all rules and regulations promulgated thereunder.
MANAGER OR CITY MANAGER: The city manager of the city.
MAYOR: The mayor of the city.
MONTH: A calendar month.
NONTECHNICAL AND TECHNICAL WORDS: Words and phrases which are not specifically
defined shall be construed according to the common and accepted usage of the
language; but technical words and phrases and such others as may have acquired
a peculiar and appropriate meaning in law shall be construed and understood
according to such meaning.
NUMBER: A word importing the singular number only may extend and be applied to
several persons and things as well as to one person and thing. Words used in
the plural number may also include the singular unless a contrary intention
plainly appears.
OATH: Shall be construed to include an affirmation in all cases in which, by
law, an affirmation may be substituted for an oath, and in such cases, the
words "swear" and "sworn" shall be equivalent to the words "affirm" and
"affirmed".
OR, AND: "Or" may be read "and", and "and" may be read "or", if the sense
requires it.
OTHER OFFICIALS OR OFFICERS, ETC.: Whenever reference is made to officers,
agencies or departments by title only, i.e., "clerk", "city clerk", "city
attorney", "fire chief", "chief of police", etc., they shall mean the officers,
agencies or departments of the city.
PERSON: Shall extend and be applied to an actual person, any persons and to
associations, clubs, societies, firms, partnerships, and bodies politic and
corporate, or the manager, lessee, agent, servant, officer or employee of any
of them, unless a contrary intention plainly appears.
PRECEDING, FOLLOWING: Next before and next after, respectively.
PROPERTY: Shall include real and personal property.
SIGNATURE OR SUBSCRIPTION: Includes a mark when a person cannot write.
STATE OR THIS STATE: Shall be construed to mean the state of Oklahoma.
STATUTORY REFERENCES: References to statutes of the state of Oklahoma as they
now are or as they may be amended to be.
STREET: Shall be construed to embrace streets, avenues, boulevards, roads,
alleys, lanes, viaducts, highways, courts, places, squares, curbs and all other
public ways in the city which are dedicated and open to public use.
TENSE: Words used in the past or present tense include the future as well as
the past and present.
WEEK: Seven (7) days.
YEAR: A calendar year. (Prior code §§ 10-1, 10-2, 10-3, 10-4)
1-103: CATCHLINES OF SECTIONS; CITATIONS:
The catchlines of sections in this code are printed in capital letters and
citations included at the ends of sections are intended to indicate the
contents of the section and original historical source respectively, and shall
not be deemed or taken to be titles and official sources of such sections; nor
as any part of the section, nor, unless expressly so provided, shall they be so
deemed when any of the sections, including the catchlines, or citations, are
amended or reenacted. (1985 Code)
1-104: EFFECT OF REPEAL OF ORDINANCES:
   A.   The repeal of an ordinance shall not revive any ordinances in force
before or at the time the ordinance repealed took effect.
   B.   The repeal of an ordinance shall not affect any punishment or penalty
incurred before the repeal took effect, nor any suit, prosecution or proceeding
pending at the time of the repeal, for an offense committed under the ordinance
repealed. (1985 Code)
1-105: SEVERABILITY OF PARTS OF CODE:
It is hereby declared to be the intention of the council that the sections,
paragraphs, sentences, clauses and phrases of this code are severable, and if
any phrase, clause, sentence, paragraph, or section of this code or of any
ordinance in this code shall be declared unconstitutional, illegal or otherwise
invalid by the valid judgment or decree of a court of competent jurisdiction,
such unconstitutionality or invalidity shall not affect any of the remaining
phrases, clauses, sentences, paragraphs and sections of this code. (Prior code
§ 10-6)
1-106: AMENDMENT TO CODE; EFFECT OF NEW ORDINANCES; AMENDATORY LANGUAGE 1 :
   A.   All ordinances passed subsequent to this code or ordinances which
amend, repeal or in any way affect this code may be numbered in accordance with
the numbering system of this code and printed for inclusion therein. When
subsequent ordinances repeal any chapter, section or subsection or any portion
thereof, the repealed portions may be excluded from this code by omission from
reprinted pages.
   B.   Amendments to any of the provisions of this code may be made by
amending the provisions by specific reference to the section of this code in
substantially the following language:
Be it ordained by the City Council of the City of Duncan, Oklahoma, that
Section                of the code of ordinances of the City of Duncan,
Oklahoma, is hereby amended to read as follows: (Set out new provisions in
full.)
   C.   When the council desires to enact an ordinance of a general and
permanent nature on a subject not heretofore existing in this code, which the
council desires to incorporate into this code, a section in substantially the
following language may be made part of the ordinance:
Section                Be it ordained by the City Council of the City of
Duncan, Oklahoma, that the provisions of this ordinance shall become and be
made a part of the code of ordinances of the City of Duncan, Oklahoma, and the
sections of this ordinance may be re-numbered to accomplish this intention.
   D.   All sections, articles, chapters or provisions of this code desired to
be repealed may be specifically repealed by section or chapter number, as the
case may be. (1985 Code)
 
Notes
1 1. 11 OS § 14-103 et seq.
1-107: ALTERING CODE:
It is unlawful for any person to change or amend by additions or deletions any
part or portion of this code, or to insert or delete pages or portions thereof,
or to alter or tamper with this code in any manner whatsoever which will cause
the law of the city to be misrepresented thereby. Any person violating this
section shall be punished as provided in section
1-108 of this chapter. (1985 Code)
1-108: GENERAL AND SPECIFIC PENALTIES 1 :
   A.   Except as otherwise provided by state law or this code, whenever in
this code or in any ordinance of the city an act is prohibited or is made or
declared to be unlawful or an offense or a misdemeanor, or whenever in this
code or ordinance the doing of any act is required or the failure to do any act
is declared to be unlawful, where no specific penalty is provided therefor, the
violation of any provision of this code or of any ordinance, upon conviction,
shall be punished by a fine of not to exceed seven hundred fifty dollars
($750.00). The maximum fine or deferred fee for traffic related offenses
relating to speeding or parking shall not exceed two hundred dollars ($200.00).
Each day or any portion of a day during which any violation of this code or of
any ordinance shall continue shall constitute a separate offense.
   B.   Any person who violates any of the following offenses or provisions of
this code shall, upon conviction, be punished by a fine, not to exceed seven
hundred fifty dollars ($750.00), plus costs, or by imprisonment not to exceed
sixty (60) days, or by both fine and imprisonment except that possession of
marijuana, DUI, APC, DWI, possession of drug paraphernalia and DUI drugs shall
carry upon conviction, a fine not to exceed eight hundred dollars ($800.00)
and/or imprisonment for a period of up to sixty (60) days: (Ord. 1724, 4-22-
2014)
      1.   Prostitution, section
10-404 of this code.
      2.   Keeping or residing in a house of prostitution, section
10-404 of this code.
      3.   Marijuana, section
10-402 of this code.
      4.   Drug paraphernalia, section
10-403 of this code.
      5.   Reckless driving, section
15-522 of this code.
      6.   Driver's license, section
15-211 of this code.
      7.   Operation of vehicle on invalid or suspended license, section
15-212 of this code.
      8.   Driving under the influence of alcohol, section
15-525 of this code.
      9.   Driving while under the influence of drugs, section
15-524 of this code.
      10.   Public intoxication, section
10-401 of this code.
      11.   Transporting open container of beer, section
3-212 of this code.
      12.   Transporting open container of liquor, section
3-115 of this code.
      13.   No or expired insurance, section
15-226 of this code.
      14.   Petit larceny, section
10-201 of this code.
      15.   Failure to obey citation, appear in court, section
15-220 of this code.
      16.   Failure to obey an order of this court, section
6-118 of this code.
      17.   Assault and battery, section
10-501 of this code.
      18.   Assault or battery upon police or other law officer, section
10-603 of this code.
      19.   Eluding police officer, section
10-613 of this code.
      20.   Rules and regulations adopted by lake commission and approved by
city council, section
11-208 of this code.
      21.   Tampering with utilities, section
10-206 of this code.
      22.   Conviction on a second violation of the same offense within a
twelve (12) month period, excluding parking violations and speeding violations,
part 15 of this code. (Ord. 1500, 3-28-2000)
      23.   Violation of temporary or periodic restrictions on water usage,
sections
17-218,
17-219,
17-220,
17-221 and
17-222 of this code. (Ord. 1716, 3-12-2013)
   C.   The amount of court costs shall not exceed costs allowed pursuant to 11
Oklahoma Statutes section
27-126.
   D.   Any person who shall aid, abet or assist in the violation of any
provision of this code or any other ordinance shall be deemed guilty of a
misdemeanor and upon conviction shall be punished as provided in this section.
(Ord. 1500, 3-28-2000)
   E.   A person who does any of the following acts or omissions shall be
guilty of an offense and upon conviction shall be subject to a fine of up to
one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) per day and the costs for each day during
which the act or omission continues to occur or thirty (30) days in jail for
each said conviction or both a fine and incarceration. Unpaid charges, fines,
and penalties shall, after thirty (30) calendar days, be assessed an additional
penalty of twenty five percent (25%) of the unpaid balance, and interest shall
accrue thereafter at the statutory rate recognized by district court. A lien
against the user's property will be sought for unpaid charges, fines, and
penalties. (Ord. 1642, 12-12-2006; amd. Ord. 1654, 8-14-2007)
      1.   Violates an effluent standard of limitation imposed by the
pretreatment program;
      2.   Violates the terms or conditions of a permit issued pursuant to the
pretreatment program;
      3.   Fails to complete a filing requirement of the pretreatment program;
      4.   Fails to allow or perform an entry, inspection, monitoring or
reporting requirement of the pretreatment program; or
      5.   Fails to pay user or cost recovery charges imposed by the
pretreatment program or violates a final determination or order of the board or
superintendent as described in sections 17-335 et seq., and 17-338 of this
code. (Ord. 1500, 3-28-2000)
      6.   Violates any provision of part 17, chapter 3, article F (sections
17-360 to 17-363) of this code, regarding stormwater sewer system discharge.
(Ord. 1745, 11-10-2015)
   F.   Those individuals found guilty of violating section
15-309 of this code requiring the wearing of seat belts by both passengers and
drivers shall be assessed a fine and costs not to exceed twenty dollars
($20.00). Said twenty dollars ($20.00) shall not include a ten dollar ($10.00)
CLEET (council on law enforcement education and training) assessment which the
state requires the municipal court to collect and disburse to the appropriate
state agency. (Ord. 1519, 1-9-2001)

1 1. 11 OS §§ 14-111, 27-119.
1-109: FINES RECOVERABLE BY CIVIL ACTION:
All fines shall be recoverable by civil action before any court of competent
jurisdiction in addition to any other method provided by law. (1985 Code)
1-110: ORDINANCES IN EFFECT IN OUTLYING TERRITORY OF CITY:
All ordinances of the city now in effect within the city are hereby extended to
all real property belonging to, or under the control of the city outside the
corporate limits of the city, and shall be in full effect therein, insofar as
they are applicable. All ordinances of the city which shall go into effect in
the future, shall also apply to, and be in full effect within the boundaries of
all outlying real property, insofar as they may be applicable. Any words in any
ordinance indicating that the effect of an ordinance provision is limited to
the corporate limits of the city shall be deemed to mean and include also the
outlying real property belonging to, or under the control of, the city, unless
the context clearly indicates otherwise. (Prior code § 10-6)
CHAPTER 2
CORPORATE AND WARD LIMITS
SECTION:
1-201: Map Of City Designated As Official Map
1-202: Ward Number And Boundaries
1-201: MAP OF CITY DESIGNATED AS OFFICIAL MAP:
The map of the city showing its territorial limits is hereby designated as the
official map of the city, and the corporate limits as shown thereon are
declared to be the true and correct corporate limits of the city, including all
annexations made to the city through and including the date of January 1, 1985.
(1985 Code)
1-202: WARD NUMBER AND BOUNDARIES:
   A.   The city shall be divided into four (4) wards as follows:
      1.   Ward one shall be composed of all that portion of the city north of
Oak Avenue and Highway 7A, east of "D" Street and east of the O.K.T. Railroad
right of way (formerly the CRI&P Railroad).
      2.   Ward two shall be composed of all that portion of the city between
the O.K.T. Railroad right of way and U.S. Highway 81 north of Oak Avenue.
      3.   Ward three shall be composed of all that portion of the city west of
U.S. Highway 81, north of Oak Avenue to 17th Street, north of Birch Avenue to
22nd Street (between 17th Street and 22nd Street), north of Oak Avenue to 23rd
Street (between 22nd Street and 23rd Street) and north of Beech Avenue west of
23rd Street.
      4.   Ward four shall be composed of that portion of the city west of U.S.
Highway 81, south of Oak Avenue east of 17th Street, south of Birch Avenue east
of 22nd Street (between 17th Street and 22nd Street), south of Oak Avenue east
of 23rd Street (between 22nd Street and 23rd Street), south of Beech Avenue
west of 23rd Street and all of that portion of the city lying south of Oak
Avenue west of "D" Street and Highway 7A east of Highway 81. (Ord. 1553, 8-27-
2002)
PART 2
ADMINISTRATION AND GOVERNMENT
CHAPTER 1
GOVERNMENT ORGANIZATION
SECTION:
2-101: Council Manager Form Of Government
2-101: COUNCIL MANAGER FORM OF GOVERNMENT:
The city is governed by the statutory council manager form of government. The
powers of the city are vested in the city council. (1985 Code)
CHAPTER 2
CITY COUNCIL
SECTION:
2-201: Council, Membership
2-202: Elections Held; Three Year Overlapping Terms; Candidate Filing
2-203: Time Of Regular Meetings Of The Council
2-204: Meetings Of The Council; Duty To Attend
2-205: Council Duties
2-206: Mayor And Vice Mayor; Duties
2-207: Compensation
2-208: Absentee Ballots
2-201: COUNCIL, MEMBERSHIP:
The council shall be composed of five (5) members, consisting of one councilman
from each of the four (4) wards of the city and the mayor as ex officio
councilman at large. (1985 Code)
2-202: ELECTIONS HELD; THREE YEAR OVERLAPPING TERMS; CANDIDATE FILING:
   A.   The terms of the elected officers shall be staggered so that at any one
municipal election, the following officers are to be elected for three (3) year
terms:
      1.   The mayor.
   B.   At the next municipal election, the following officers are to be
elected for three (3) year terms:
      1.   Councilmen from wards one and two.
   C.   At the next municipal election, the following officers are to be
elected for three (3) year terms:
      1.   Councilmen from wards three and four. (1985 Code)
   D.   A candidate may have his or her name printed upon the municipal
election ballot as candidate for any office to be filled at the election. To
become a candidate, a declaration of candidacy must be filed with the county
election board no earlier than eight o'clock (8:00) A.M. on the first Monday in
February and no later than five o'clock (5:00) P.M. on the next succeeding
Wednesday. A candidate must also be a registered voter at an address within the
city, or of the ward where the office is from a ward, for at least six (6)
months prior to filing a declaration of candidacy 1 . (Ord. 1730, 11-25-2014)
 
Notes
1 1. 11 OS § 16-110.
2-203: TIME OF REGULAR MEETINGS OF THE COUNCIL:
The council of the city shall hold a regular meeting on the second and fourth
Tuesday of every month at five fifteen o'clock (5:15) P.M. If such a Tuesday
falls on a holiday, the regular meeting shall be held on the next day which is
not a holiday. (Ord. 1648, 4-23-2007)
2-204: MEETINGS OF THE COUNCIL; DUTY TO ATTEND:
Every meeting of the council shall be held in the council chamber unless, in
case of an emergency, the mayor or the councilmen calling a special meeting
designate another place in the city for the holding of the special meeting.
(Prior code § 1-2)
2-205: COUNCIL DUTIES:
The duties of the council shall be those prescribed by law and the charter of
the city. (1985 Code)
2-206: MAYOR AND VICE MAYOR; DUTIES:
   A.   The mayor shall preside at meetings of the council, and shall certify
to the correct enrollment of all ordinances and resolutions passed by it. As
councilman at large he shall have the rights and privileges of a councilman. He
shall be recognized as head of the city government for all ceremonial purposes
and by the governor for purposes of military law. He shall have no regular
administrative duties except that he shall sign all conveyances and other
written obligations of the city as the council may require. The vice mayor
shall act as mayor during the absence, disability or suspension of the mayor.
   B.   Every year, at the first meeting after the time for the beginning of
the term of a newly elected mayor or councilmen or as soon thereafter as
practicable, the council shall elect one of its members vice mayor, who shall
serve as such until the next such first meeting. (1985 Code)
2-207: COMPENSATION:
The mayor or any councilman may not receive any compensation as such for any
services rendered the city other than actual expenses. (1985 Code)
   A.   The mayor and city councilmen shall provide bonds for the faithful
performance of their respective duties, payable to the city in the amount of
ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00) each and the city shall pay the premiums on
such bonds. (Ord. 1674, 2-10-2009)
2-208: ABSENTEE BALLOTS:
Pursuant to the provisions of state law, and as provided and controlled
thereby, absentee ballots shall be permitted in all primary, runoff, general
and special elections held within, for and on behalf of the city. It is
specifically recognized and declared that the charter contains no provision
restricting the use of absentee ballots in municipal elections. (Ord. 1216, 2-
14-1984)
CHAPTER 3
CITY MANAGER
SECTION:
2-301: City Manager Appointment
2-301: CITY MANAGER APPOINTMENT:
The council shall appoint a city manager for an indefinite term by a vote of a
majority of all its members. It shall choose him solely on the basis of his
executive and administrative qualifications. (Prior code § 1-3)
CHAPTER 4
CITY CLERK AND TREASURER
SECTION:
2-401: City Clerk
2-402: Duties Of City Clerk
2-403: City Treasurer
2-404: Duties Of City Treasurer
2-401: CITY CLERK:
The city treasurer shall be ex officio city clerk. (1985 Code)
2-402: DUTIES OF CITY CLERK:
The clerk shall keep the journal of the proceedings of the council. He shall
enroll in a book kept for the purpose, all ordinances and resolutions passed by
the council. He shall keep the seal of the city and attest the signature of the
mayor or vice mayor. He shall perform such other duties as may be required by
law or ordinance for the city clerk. (1985 Code)
2-403: CITY TREASURER:
There shall be a treasurer for the city, appointed by the city manager for an
indefinite term. (Prior code § 1-5)
2-404: DUTIES OF CITY TREASURER:
The treasurer shall collect and receive revenue and other money for the city
and deposit daily all funds coming into his hands in such depositories as the
council may designate. He shall maintain a general accounting system for the
city government. He shall disburse such funds in the manner provided by
applicable law or ordinance. He shall have such other powers, duties, and
functions as may be prescribed by applicable law or by ordinance. (Prior code §
1-6)
CHAPTER 5
OTHER DEPARTMENTS AND PERSONNEL
SECTION:
2-501: City Attorney
2-502: City-County Health Department Director
2-503: Officers And Employees; Number And Classes; Compensation
2-504: Certain Personnel To Be Bonded
2-501: CITY ATTORNEY:
The city attorney is appointed by the city manager for an indefinite term, and
is removable by the city manager. The city attorney is an officer of the city.
The city attorney is the chief legal adviser of the council and all other
officers, departments, and agencies of the city government in matters relating
to their official powers and duties. He represents the city in proceedings in
the courts, and performs all services incident to his position which may be
required by law or ordinance. (Prior code §§ 1-19, 1-20)
2-502: CITY-COUNTY HEALTH DEPARTMENT DIRECTOR:
The city-county health department of the county and its director shall have the
powers of a city health department and city health officer respectively for the
city. References to health department and health officer or director of the
health department in this code and in other ordinances of the city mean the
city-county health department and its director, unless the context clearly
indicates another meaning. (Prior code §§ 1-42, 1-43)
2-503: OFFICERS AND EMPLOYEES; NUMBER AND CLASSES; COMPENSATION:
The council, by motion, resolution, or ordinance, may regulate the number of
classes of officers and positions of employment in the various departments,
offices, and agencies of the city government, and may determine or regulate the
compensation to be paid to officers and employees. (Prior code § 1-44)
2-504: CERTAIN PERSONNEL TO BE BONDED 1 :
   A.   Before entering upon their official duties, the following personnel of
the city government shall provide bonds for the faithful performance of their
official duties, payable to the city, with a surety company authorized to
operate within the state, in such amounts as set or approved by the council:
      1.   City manager;
      2.   City treasurer; and
      3.   Mayor and each councilman.
   B.   The council, by motion or resolution, may require other officers and
employees in such positions as it may designate to be bonded.
   C.   The city shall pay the premiums on the bonds. (Prior code § 1-45)
 
Notes
1 1. 11 OS § 8-105.
CHAPTER 6
SOCIAL SECURITY
SECTION:
2-601: Declaration Of Policy To Come Under Coverage
2-602: Execution Of Agreement With State Agency
2-603: Withholdings
2-604: Contributions
2-605: Records And Reports
2-606: Exclusions
2-601: DECLARATION OF POLICY TO COME UNDER COVERAGE 1 :
It is hereby declared to be the policy and purpose of the city to extend, at
the earliest date, to the eligible employees and officials of the city the
benefits of the system of federal old age and survivors insurance as authorized
by the federal social security act and all amendments thereto, and 51 Oklahoma
Statutes section 121 et seq. In pursuance of this policy, the officers and
employees of the city shall take such action as may be required by applicable
state or federal laws or regulations. (Prior code § 1-52)
 
Notes
1 1. 51 OS § 125.
2-602: EXECUTION OF AGREEMENT WITH STATE AGENCY:
The mayor is authorized and directed to execute all necessary agreements and
amendments with the Oklahoma department of human services to accomplish the
provisions of section
2-601 of this chapter. (Prior code § 1-53)
2-603: WITHHOLDINGS:
Withholdings from salaries or wages of employees and officials for the purposes
provided in section
2-601 of this chapter are hereby authorized to be made in the amounts and at
such times as may be required by applicable state and federal laws or
regulations, and shall be paid over to the state or federal agency designated
by the laws and regulations. (Prior code § 1-54)
2-604: CONTRIBUTIONS:
Employer contributions shall be paid from amounts appropriated for these
purposes from available funds to the designated state or federal agency in
accordance with applicable state or federal laws or regulations. (Prior code §
1-55)
2-605: RECORDS AND REPORTS:
The city shall keep such records and submit such reports as may be required by
applicable state or federal laws or regulations. (Prior code § 1-56)
2-606: EXCLUSIONS:
   A.   Excluded from this chapter authorizing the extension of social security
benefits to city officers and employees are the following:
      1.   Any authority to make any agreement with respect to any position,
employee or official covered or authorized to be covered as of the initial
effective date of this chapter by any other ordinance creating any retirement
system for any employee or official of the city; or
      2.   Any authority to make any agreement with respect to any position,
employee or official for which compensation is on a fee basis, or any position,
employee or official engaged in rendering services of an emergency nature, or
any position, employee or official engaged in rendering services in part time
positions, or any position, employee or official not authorized to be covered
by applicable state or federal laws or regulations. (Prior code § 1-57)
CHAPTER 7
RETIREMENT AND PENSIONS
SECTION:
   Article A. Police Pension System
2-701: Police Pension System
   Article B. Firefighters' Pension Fund
2-710: Firefighters' Pension And Retirement System
   Article C. Employee Retirement System
2-720: System Established
2-721: Administration, Trustees
ARTICLE A.  POLICE PENSION SYSTEM
2-701: POLICE PENSION SYSTEM 1 :
It is hereby declared to be the purpose and intention of the city to adopt the
police pension and retirement system as provided by the laws of the state.
(Prior code § 1-49)
 
Notes
1 1. 11 OS §§ 50-101 et seq., 50-106.3, 50-109, 50-110.
ARTICLE B.  FIREFIGHTERS' PENSION FUND
2-710: FIREFIGHTERS' PENSION AND RETIREMENT SYSTEM 1 :
   A.   There is hereby created a local firefighters' pension and retirement
board composed of the mayor, the clerk, the treasurer and three (3) members
from the fire department. The board shall have the membership, organization,
powers, duties and functions as prescribed by 11 Oklahoma Statutes section
49-103 et seq.
   B.   It is hereby declared to be the purpose and intention of the city, by
this article, to adopt the firefighters' pension system as provided by the laws
of the state. (Prior code §§ 1-46, 1-47, 1-48)
 
Notes
1 2. 11 OS § 49-101 et seq.
ARTICLE C.  EMPLOYEE RETIREMENT SYSTEM
2-720: SYSTEM ESTABLISHED:
Pursuant to the authority conferred by the laws of the state of Oklahoma, and
for the purpose of encouraging continuity and meritorious service on the part
of city employees and thereby promote public efficiency, there is hereby
authorized, created, established, approved, and adopted, effective January 1,
1963, the pension plan designated "employee retirement system" of the city
(hereinafter called "system"), and all amendments thereto. The provisions of
the employee retirement system, as adopted by ordinance, and all amendments
thereto, are hereby adopted and incorporated herein by reference. (Prior code §
1-58)
2-721: ADMINISTRATION, TRUSTEES:
   A.   For the purpose of managing and administering the employee retirement
system, there is hereby created a board of trustees which shall be known as the
board of trustees of the employee retirement system.
   B.   The board of trustees shall be composed of five (5) members, of which
two (2) department heads or employees shall be appointed by the city council
from the various departments and the members may be removed at any time by the
city council. The city clerk and treasurer shall be a member of the board, and
act as treasurer of the retirement system. The two (2) other board of trustee
members shall be two (2) other employees of the city who shall be elected in
the manner hereinafter provided. (Prior code §§ 1-60, 1-61)
CHAPTER 8
RULES OF PROCEDURE FOR PUBLIC MEETINGS
SECTION:
2-801: Rules Or Order Of Procedure
2-802: Regular Meetings
2-803: Special Meetings
2-804: Quorum
2-805: Presiding Officer
2-806: Meetings Open To Public
2-807: Agenda Schedule
2-808: Order Of Business
2-809: Order Of Discussion Of Each Agenda Item
2-810: Rules Of Discussion
2-811: Motions
2-812: Voting
2-813: Robert's Rules Of Order To Govern
2-814: Attendance
2-815: Minutes
2-816: Special Committee
2-817: When Public Hearing Required
2-818: Items Previously Voted On By Council
2-801: RULES OR ORDER OF PROCEDURE:
   A.   The rules or order of procedure herein contained shall govern
deliberations and meetings of the council of the city and additionally shall
govern deliberations and meetings of the public utilities authority.
   B.   In all sections contained hereunder where it appears that where
procedures with regard to the city council all rules and regulations shall in
addition apply to the public utilities authority. (Ord. 1267, 2-10-1987)
2-802: REGULAR MEETINGS:
Regular meetings of the council/trustee shall be held at five fifteen o'clock
(5:15) P.M. at the city council chambers, 18 South 7th Street on the second and
fourth Tuesdays of the month; except in December when the fourth Tuesday is on
the twenty third through twenty sixth, the council/trustee may, by resolution,
reschedule that upon majority vote of those members of the council/trustee
present. Any meeting of the council/trustee may extend until twelve o'clock
(12:00) midnight of the day of the meeting. (Ord. 1267, 2-10-1987)
2-803: SPECIAL MEETINGS:
Special meetings may be held at the call of the mayor or any three (3)
councilmen/trustees on notice given at least forty eight (48) hours prior to
the special meeting. In the case of an emergency, an emergency meeting may be
held on such notice as may be reasonable and possible under the circumstances.
(Ord. 1267, 2-10-1987)
2-804: QUORUM:
A quorum authorized to conduct business shall consist of a majority of all
members elected to and constituting the council. Less than a quorum may adjourn
from day to day. (Ord. 1267, 2-10-1987)
2-805: PRESIDING OFFICER:
The presiding officer for each meeting shall be the mayor, or in his absence,
the vice mayor. If both the mayor and vice mayor be absent, the council/trustee
member most senior in service on the council shall initially preside for the
purpose of calling the meeting to order the electing a presiding officer who
shall then preside over the remainder of the meeting. (Ord. 1267, 2-10-1987)
2-806: MEETINGS OPEN TO PUBLIC:
All meetings, regular and special, shall be open to the public, and no person
shall be barred unless he is disorderly or refuses to obey the order of the
mayor, who may order the chief of police or any attending police officer to
eject any such person. The police department shall have at least one officer
present at each council meeting. The council may meet in executive sessions
only as authorized by the city charter and Oklahoma Statutes. (Ord. 1267, 2-10-
1987)
2-807: AGENDA SCHEDULE:
An agenda schedule for each meeting of the council shall be prepared by the
city manager to ensure that city business is conducted in an efficient manner.
This policy is designed to respect the time of those persons who come before
the council through the normal procedure of placing items on the agenda. The
Oklahoma open meeting law shall be strictly adhered to in conduct of the
meetings and the agenda schedule. No item shall be voted on by the council
without having been placed on the council agenda, unless it is of an emergency
nature and could not have been foreseen. To provide for timely preparation and
distribution of the agenda, all items must be submitted to the city manager's
office no later than one o'clock (1:00) P.M. on the Thursday immediately
preceding the next Tuesday's council meeting. (Ord. 1267, 2-10-1987)
2-808: ORDER OF BUSINESS:
   A.   The order of business shall be as follows:
      1.   Call to order;
      2.   Invocation;
      3.   Roll call;
      4.   From the office of the mayor. Items in this section shall include,
but not be limited to, the following:
         a.   Recognition of city employees for awards or honors;
         b.   Recognition of distinguished visitors or groups such as Boy
Scouts, Allied Officers, DeMolays, etc.; or
         c.   Expression of condolence to families on demise of prominent
citizens, civic leaders, etc.;
      5.   Consent agenda:
         a.   Council/trustee shall act on all items in this section by a
single motion and roll call vote, subject to questions, discussion, or the
right of any member to delete any item for individual action;
         b.   Items on the consent agenda shall include, but not be limited to,
consideration of the following:
            (1)   Preliminary plans and authorization for preparation of final
plans and specifications;
            (2)   Change orders;
            (3)   Final plans and authorization for advertisement of bids;
            (4)   Acceptance of final plats and improvements;
            (5)   Easements, acceptance or dedication;
            (6)   Set dates for public hearings;
            (7)   Internal fund transfers requiring excise board approval or
supplemental appropriations;
            (8)   Acceptance of annual audit reports (various);
            (9)   Annual lease agreements;
            (10)   Acknowledge receipt of state health department permits
(various);
            (11)   Award bids and authorize contract execution;
            (12)   Reject bids and authorize readvertisement;
            (13)   Mayor's appointments;
            (14)   Basic claims, payroll claims, longevity claims; or
            (15)   Council/trustee minutes;
      6.   Council's and citizens' scheduled presentations. When a citizen
contacts the mayor or council and requests to be on the agenda for a specific
presentation, the request must be relayed to the mayor's or city manager's
office prior to agenda deadline with citizen's name, address, subject of
presentation, and available background information. Council shall have the
option of voting on the item or referring it to staff for additional
information. Each presentation shall be listed on the agenda in this section by
name, address and subject. Time limits set out for audience participation will
apply;
      7.   New business:
         a.   In setting the order of items requiring individual action, the
mayor shall give priority to:
            (1)   Public hearings;
            (2)   Matters that may attract a large number of interested
citizens to the meeting; or
            (3)   Other matters that may attract interested parties such as
claims recommended for denial;
      8.   Audience participation:
         a.   In compliance with the Oklahoma open meeting law, council/trustee
shall not vote on items presented during this section of the meeting;
         b.   Each person shall have a maximum of three (3) minutes to state
his or her business;
         c.   Each subject shall have a maximum of twelve (12) minutes; and
         d.   After such time as the individual or the discussion of a
particular subject is completed, council/trustee shall recommend to the
individual or group as to what action they should take, i.e., refer situation
to a particular department or person at the city offices, or suggest they place
the item on a council agenda;
      9.   Executive session;
      10.   Reports: mayor, city manager, council/trustee:
         a.   Reports by council/trustee should be limited to those matters of
general interest to the whole council; or
         b.   Routine reports that concern the interest of only the ward or an
isolated situation that does not affect other councilmen/trustees or areas of
the city should be processed through normal channels; and
      11.   Adjournment. (Ord. 1267, 2-10-1987)
2-809: ORDER OF DISCUSSION OF EACH AGENDA ITEM:
   A.   Discussion of each agenda item shall be in the following order:
      1.   City Manager Or City Staff: After the mayor calls the particular
agenda item for consideration, the city manager or staff shall present any
matters in addition to the printed agenda commentary which may be pertinent to
the item;
      2.   Public Participation: During public hearings, citizens and
interested parties may address the council/trustee as a matter of "right"
subject to reasonable time limitations to expedite council business. On all
other matters, public participation shall be at the discretion of the council;
      3.   Council Members: After the staff and public have presented their
views, the city manager, mayor and council/trustee shall proceed to discuss the
merits of the issue; this portion of the discussion shall be limited to the
city manager, mayor and council/trustee unless the mayor or council/trustee
determines additional information is needed from the staff or public at that
time. (Ord. 1267, 2-10-1987)
2-810: RULES OF DISCUSSION:
   A.   Rules of discussion shall be as follows:
      1.   No council/trustee member shall speak without recognition from the
mayor, and no member shall speak more than twice on a specific item without
permission of the mayor;
      2.   A person who is not a member of the council shall not be allowed to
address the same without permission of the mayor;
      3.   Each person addressing the council/trustee shall address his remarks
to the council/trustee generally rather than to a specific member;
      4.   Discussions shall be limited to the matter presently before the
council/trustee. Speakers shall confine their remarks to the merits of the
particular measure and avoid comments which would tend to embarrass other
persons or attack their motives. (Ord. 1267, 2-10-1987)
2-811: MOTIONS:
   A.   After preliminary discussion of an agenda item, the mayor shall call
the matter for determination by the council/trustee:
      1.   Main Motion: Any member of the council desiring to offer a motion on
a particular agenda item shall so indicate by raising his hand to obtain the
mayor's recognition;
      2.   Seconding The Motions: Members desiring to second motions shall so
indicate to the mayor by raising their hands;
      3.   Recognition For Motions And Seconds: To the extent reasonably
possible, the mayor shall recognize council/trustee members for the offering
and seconding of motions on an alternating basis so that all council/trustee
members have an opportunity to offer and second main motions during a meeting;
      4.   Special Courtesy: Where a matter is of special concern to a
particular council/trustee member, he may prior to the beginning of the meeting
advise the mayor of his desire to offer or second the motion on that particular
agenda item. Absent conflicting requests the mayor shall so recognize the
requesting member for the purpose of submitting the motion or seconding. In the
event of conflicting requests, the mayor may recognize any one of the
requesting council members if they are unable to resolve the conflict among
themselves;
      5.   Typical Motions:
         a.   Main motion:
            (1)   "I move....";
         b.   Amendments:
            (1)   "I move to amend the motion by inserting between ... and
...";
            (2)   "I move to amend the motion by adding after...";
            (3)   "I move to amend the motion by striking out...";
            (4)   "I move to amend the motion by striking out... and
inserting...";
            (5)   "I move to amend by striking out the motion and substituting
the following...";
         c.   Committee:
            (1)   "I move that this motion be referred to a committee of the
council/trustee for further consideration and report back to the council/
trustee no later than.....";
         d.   Call for questions:
            (1)   "I move the previous question two-thirds (2/3) vote required
- stops debate and order an immediate vote";
         e.   Table:
            (1)   "I move that this item be tabled indefinitely" (or to a date
certain);
         f.   Award of contracts:
            (1)   "I move that the bid of ... be approved for award, pending
the signing of the contract and furnishing of required bonds, and that the
mayor be authorized and directed to sign the contract for and on behalf of the
city";
         g.   Adoption of ordinance:
            (1)   "I move the adoption of ordinance no.      entitled ... and
that the reading of the ordinance be waived";
         h.   Adoption of resolution:
            (1)   "I move the adoption of a resolution entitled...";
         i.   Claims:
            (1)   "I move that the council/trustee approve/reject the claim of
... (in the amount of ... )";
         j.   Consent agenda:
            (1)   "I move the approval of the consent agenda items";
      6.   Lack Of Motion Or Second: If no member offers a motion on an agenda
item, the mayor shall again call for motions; if no motion is presented after
the second calling, the mayor shall declare the item fails for lack of motion.
Similarly, if no one seconds another member's motion, the mayor shall declare
that the motion fails for lack of a second;
      7.   Debate Of Motions: Upon a motion having been offered and seconded,
the mayor shall state the motion and submit it for further debate by the
council/trustee if desired. Debate shall be limited to the merits of the agenda
item, and addressed to the mayor;
      8.   Amendments To Motions:
         a.   Any time prior to the mayor's calling for vote of the council/
trustee, a member may move to amend the motion, which shall require a second.
An amendment must be germane to the main motion;
         b.   Two (2) amendments can be made to any main motion, a primary
amendment and a secondary amendment. In order to avoid confusion, a third
amendment shall not be permitted. A council/trustee member may in the course of
debate on the secondary amendment announce that if the secondary amendment
fails, he intends to introduce another secondary amendment and may briefly
state the nature and content thereof. (Ord. 1267, 2-10-1987)
2-812: VOTING:
After allowing a reasonable but not unduly lengthy time for debate of the
motion, the mayor shall put the question to a vote. The clerk shall call the
roll of council members present, and record each vote. Council members may vote
"yes", "no", or "abstain". Where a council/trustee member has withdrawn from
consideration of an issue because of conflict of interest, he shall "abstain".
The mayor will announce the vote or he shall request the clerk to announce the
vote. A council/trustee member may change his vote only before the results of
the vote are announced by the mayor. Amendments shall be voted on prior to the
main motion, with secondary amendments voted on prior to primary amendments.
(Ord. 1267, 2-10-1987)
2-813: ROBERT'S RULES OF ORDER TO GOVERN:
The latest revision of "Robert's Rule Of Order" is incorporated into these
rules, and shall govern all matters not specifically addressed in these rules.
(Ord. 1267, 2-10-1987)
2-814: ATTENDANCE:
The city manager, clerk, attorney and finance director (or their assistants)
shall attend all regular and special meetings of the council/trustee.
Attendance of other city personnel shall be required only when there are agenda
items which affect their particular responsibility. (Ord. 1267, 2-10-1987)
2-815: MINUTES:
Minutes of each meeting of the council/trustee shall be prepared by the clerk
and submitted to a subsequent council meeting for approval. The minutes shall
summarize the council's deliberations and record the action of the council on
each item. The clerk shall maintain a record of the approved minutes. (Ord.
1267, 2-10-1987)
2-816: SPECIAL COMMITTEE:
   A.   On his own determination, or on vote of the council/trustee, the mayor
may from time to time appoint a special committee, two (2) members (if more
than 2, must comply with open meeting act) of the council to investigate and
study a particular matter in depth and report to the council/trustee its
findings and recommendations. Each committee shall consist of two (2) members.
If requested by the special committee of the council/trustee, the city manager
shall appoint a member of the city's staff to serve in a nonvoting capacity in
order to assist the committee.
   B.   The committee's report shall be submitted for such actions as may be
appropriate. (Ord. 1267, 2-10-1987)
2-817: WHEN PUBLIC HEARING REQUIRED:
   A.   When an item appears on the city council/trustee agenda which requires
three (3) (4 for bond issues) or more affirmative votes for passage, and one or
more members of the city council/trustee are absent from the meeting where the
item is originally considered, if not approved, such item shall be continued or
rescheduled for a vote thereon at the next regular meeting of the city council.
   B.   When the agenda item requires a public hearing, the mayor shall recess
the public hearing and take a vote of the city council/trustee. Should the vote
decide the issue, the mayor shall close the public hearing and announce the
vote. Should the vote not decide the issue and the results be such that the
issue is to be continued, the mayor shall continue the public hearing to the
next regular meeting of the city council/trustee.
   C.   An exception to the procedures established in this section shall be
allowed when an absent council/trustee member requests that the agenda item be
returned to the council/trustee agenda, with concurrence of the mayor, when the
vote of the absent council/trustee member could alter the outcome of the issue.
   D.   When the mayor is absent and the question requires three (3)
affirmative votes for passage and the vote is two (2) to two (2), the item will
be continued or rescheduled for the next regular meeting of the city council/
trustee. (Ord. 1267, 2-10-1987)
2-818: ITEMS PREVIOUSLY VOTED ON BY COUNCIL:
   A.   An item previously decided by the city council may be placed on the
agenda as a new item of business under the following circumstances:
      1.   The item is placed on the agenda by two (2) or more council members
who voted with the prevailing side by providing a signed letter to the city
manager, if proposed for the next regularly scheduled meeting as provided in
subsection A1b of this section:
         a.   In order to be reconsidered at the city council meeting, a motion
and second to the motion must be made by members who voted with the prevailing
side. "Prevailing side" is defined as one who voted "aye" if the motion
involved was adopted, and "no" if the motion was defeated;
         b.   A reconsideration can only be made at the same meeting of the
original adoption or defeat of the item, or the next following regularly
scheduled meeting. Special meetings are not included;
      2.   Annually, when council members have been sworn into office and the
item was voted on by the previous administration. (Ord. 1267, 2-10-1987; amd.
Ord. 1383, 6-27-1995)
   B.   This section shall not be applicable to the initiation, prosecution,
defense or settlement of litigation brought by or against the city, its
employees or agencies. (Ord. 1662, 10-23-2007)
CHAPTER 9
AUDIT COMMITTEE
SECTION:
2-901: Establishment
2-902: Approval Of Nominees
2-903: Term And Replacement Of Members
2-904: Renomination
2-905: Functions
2-906: Meetings
2-907: Interference With Fiscal Responsibilities
2-901: ESTABLISHMENT:
The mayor of the city of Duncan, Oklahoma, shall nominate two (2) individuals
to serve on the city of Duncan audit committee. The audit committee, as
appointed by the mayor of the city of Duncan, shall consist of two (2) seated
council persons. The audit committee shall elect an individual who will act as
chairman of the committee and perform such administrative duties as provided by
ordinance. (Ord. 1484, 4-26-1999)
2-902: APPROVAL OF NOMINEES:
Said nominees, as appointed by the mayor, in accordance with section
2-901 of this chapter, shall be approved by a majority vote of the city
council. (Ord. 1484, 4-26-1999)
2-903: TERM AND REPLACEMENT OF MEMBERS:
The members of the audit committee shall serve a term of two (2) years from the
date of appointment or until such sooner time when said council member leaves
office. Upon the occurrence of a council member leaving office, the mayor shall
immediately appoint a seated council person to serve the remainder of the term.
(Ord. 1484, 4-26-1999)
2-904: RENOMINATION:
The mayor, at his discretion, at the expiration of the term of any audit
committee member, may renominate a serving committee member for an additional
two (2) year term. (Ord. 1484, 4-26-1999)
2-905: FUNCTIONS:
The audit committee shall be established in order to provide the following
functions: a) to review applications submitted to the city of Duncan by those
individuals desiring to conduct the annual audit for the city; b) to make
recommendations to the council in selection of qualified certified public
accountant or accountants who shall conduct an independent audit of the
accounts and evidence of financial transactions of the department of finance
and all other departments, offices and agencies, keeping separate or
subordinate accounts or making financial transactions as of the end of every
fiscal year; c) to act as a liaison between the selected auditor and the city
of Duncan; d) to review all audit results with the auditor, the city manager
and the city treasurer; e) to make recommendations to the auditor which may
provide for a more expedient and efficient audit procedure. (Ord. 1484, 4-26-
1999)
2-906: MEETINGS:
The audit committee will meet when deemed necessary or at the request of the
chairman of the committee. (Ord. 1484, 4-26-1999)
2-907: INTERFERENCE WITH FISCAL RESPONSIBILITIES:
The audit committee may not direct any action which shall interfere with the
fiscal responsibilities of the city manager or city treasurer as dictated by
charter, statute or city ordinance. (Ord. 1484, 4-26-1999)
CHAPTER 10
TELECOMMUNICATIONS COMMISSION
SECTION:
2-1001: Commission Established
2-1002: Appointment And Terms
2-1003: Duties
2-1001: COMMISSION ESTABLISHED:
There is hereby established a telecommunications commission consisting of five
(5) members to be recommended by the mayor. The city council of the city shall
confirm the mayor's recommendations. The commissioners shall be appointed for
overlapping three (3) year terms and shall serve until their respective
successors have been appointed and qualified. (Ord. 1330, 1992)
2-1002: APPOINTMENT AND TERMS:
   A.   The commissioners shall assume their duties upon appointment. However,
at the time of initial appointment, the mayor shall identify those commission
seats which will first become vacant. The successor term of two (2)
commissioners first appointed shall begin at seven thirty o'clock (7:30) P.M.
on the first Monday in May 1993, the successor terms of two (2) commissioners
first appointed shall begin at seven thirty o'clock (7:30) P.M. on the first
Monday in May 1994, and the successor term of one commissioner first appointed
shall begin at seven thirty o'clock (7:30) P.M. on the first Monday in May
1995:
      1.   Each commissioner shall then serve a term of three (3) years;
      2.   Every year, at a time prescribed for the beginning of the term of a
new member or members or as soon thereafter as practicable, the commission
shall elect a chairman and vice chairman. The commission shall determine the
time and place of its regular meeting. The mayor, the chairman or any three (3)
members may call a special meeting;
      3.   The manner of conducting business shall be determined by the
members. However, the commission shall at all times comply with the guidelines
of the open meeting act even if not required by state law;
      4.   The mayor may remove members for the good of the city and fill
vacancies for unexpired terms; and
      5.   The city clerk or his designated representative will take the
minutes of all meetings. (Ord. 1330, 1992)
2-1003: DUTIES:
The telecommunications commission shall identify, review and assess the
telecommunication needs for the city. The commission shall become familiar with
federal and state rules, regulations and laws which govern telecommunications.
In addition, the commission shall monitor those individuals, companies,
partnerships or corporations which are grantees named in a nonexclusive cable
franchise or permit to ensure compliance with the franchise or permit. The
commission shall make recommendations to the city council on all matters
dealing with telecommunications such as, but not limited to, control,
maintenance, improvements, operations, compliance with permits, rates as
permitted by law and renewal of existing permits. (Ord. 1330, 1992)
CHAPTER 11
GRANT ADMINISTRATION
SECTION:
2-1101: CDBG-EDIF Job Tracking
2-1101: CDBG-EDIF JOB TRACKING:
If the city of Duncan is at any time a recipient of funds, either as a grant,
loan, or combination of grant and loan, from the program available through the
state of Oklahoma department of commerce, and identified as the community
development block grant - economic development infrastructure financing (CDBG-
EDIF) program, the city shall require that any entity or beneficiary using the
CDBG-EDIF funded infrastructure improvements must agree to provide job tracking
data as a condition of using the improvements. The job tracking data must be
provided for a period of time starting with the date the state awards the CDBG-
EDIF funds to the city of Duncan, and will end one year after the physical
completion of the public improvements. (Ord. 1482, 3-23-1999)
PART 3
ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGES
CHAPTER 1
ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGES

3-101: PURPOSES OF CHAPTER:
This chapter is enacted as an exercise of the police power of the City to
preserve the public peace, safety, health and good order thereof, and to aid
the enforcement of the policy of the State as established by the Oklahoma
Alcoholic Beverage Control Act, 37 Oklahoma Statutes section 501 et seq., and
to establish annual license fees upon all licenses issued to persons engaged in
the manufacture, sale or distribution of alcoholic beverages. (1985 Code; amd.
2015 Code)
3-102: TERMS AND PHRASES:
For the purpose of this chapter, all of the terms and phrases used in this
chapter shall be given the same use and meaning as defined by the Oklahoma
Alcoholic Beverage Control Act. "Minor" shall mean a person who, in accordance
with State law, has not yet attained the age at which consumption of alcoholic
beverages is permitted. "State licensee" means any person who holds a license
issued under authority of the Oklahoma Alcoholic Beverage Control Act. (Prior
Code § 2-1)

   D.   The holder of a valid certificate for a bottle club may convert such

§ 2-2; amd. Ord. 1259, 9-23-1986; 2015 Code)
