5-202: ADDITIONS AND CHANGES TO BUILDING CODE:
   A.   The following sections of the building code are hereby revised:
      1.   Section 101.1, insert city of Duncan;
      2.   Section 114, insert "amount as set by the city council by motion or
resolution";
      3.   Section 114.4, insert "offense, punishable as provided in section
1-108 of the city code of ordinances";
      4.   Section 118.2, insert "amount as provided in section
1-108 of the city's code of ordinances" in both locations;
      5.   Section 123.2, insert "amount as set by the city council by motion
or resolution";
      6.   Section 501.2, insert the "boundaries of the fire limits are
provided in section
5-130 of the city code of ordinances";
      7.   Section 1807.2.1, insert "depth as set by building official";
      8.   Section 1807.2.2, insert "depth as set by building official"; and
      9.   Section 1906.1, insert $10,000;
      10.   The board of adjustment as created in chapter 1, article B of the
city's building code shall be the appeal board for all building code matters,
with notice to be given in the same form as prescribed in section
12-127 of the city code except that notice to be given regarding appeals of the
building code shall not require notice to be given to property owners within a
three hundred (300) foot radius of the subject property unless the appeal shall
deal with variations contemplated by section
12-123 of the city code or exceptions contemplated by section
12-124 of article B, part 12 of the city code;
      11.   Sections 121.2 through 121.7 of the building code shall be deleted.
(Ord. 1413, 11-26-1996; amd. 2015 Code)
5-203: FEE FOR INSPECTION:
There shall be an inspection fee charged for inspection. All inspection fees
shall be in such amounts as may be set by the council by motion or resolution.
(1985 Code)
CHAPTER 3
PLUMBING REGULATIONS
SECTION:
5-301: Plumbing Inspector
5-302: Duties Of Plumbing Inspector
5-303: Registration Required, Exemptions
5-304: Permits
5-305: Adoption Of Plumbing Code
5-306: Additions, Insertions And Changes To Plumbing Code
5-307: Inspection
5-308: Failure To Comply With Plumbing Rules
5-309: Recourse To Plumbers Surety And Penalty
5-301: PLUMBING INSPECTOR 1 :
The office of plumbing inspector is hereby rated. The plumbing inspector may be
the building official or other person appointed by the city manager in
compliance with the provisions of state law. (Prior code § 4-37; amd. Ord.
1405, 7-31-1996)
 
Notes
1 1. 59 OS §§ 1016, 1001 et seq.
5-302: DUTIES OF PLUMBING INSPECTOR:
It is the duty of the plumbing inspector to inspect all plumbing and sewer
lines in the city. The plumbing inspector may, as far as necessary in the
performance of his duties, enter in the daytime, any building or premises
inside the corporate limits of the city. It is the duty of the plumbing
inspector to keep a daily record of all his work, including all notices and
applications received, permits and certificates granted, and all violations of
this chapter and other matters which may pertain thereto. (Prior code § 4-37;
amd. Ord. 1405, 7-31-1996)
5-303: REGISTRATION REQUIRED, EXEMPTIONS 1 :
   A.   Every person, firm or corporation, before engaging in the business of
plumbing in the city shall pay to the city treasurer a registration fee for the
purpose of regulating the business, the sums as set by council by motion or
resolution for plumbing contractors, journeymen and apprentices, payable in
advance to be deposited in the general fund of the city. The registration fee
herein assessed shall be construed to be exacted from each establishment or
place of business in the city, and not from the individual employees of
plumbing contractors, firms or establishments. The city shall issue
certificates and receipts for all sums of money collected under this provision
to the person, firm or corporation paying the same. No certificate or receipt
may be issued until the applicant shows proof of possession of the appropriate
state license. No certificate shall extend beyond the birth date of the
licensee of any year. Any request for renewal of a certificate must be received
by the city within thirty (30) days after the expiration date of the
certificate, along with the required fees and proof of state license. No
prorating of the license is allowed. (Ord. 1596, 1-25-2005)
   B.   Exempt from the provisions of this registration requirement are
homeowners performing work at their residence, minor repairs and other
exemptions as specifically in the state plumbing license law, 59 Oklahoma
Statutes section 1017. (Prior code § 4-40; amd. Ord. 1405, 7-31-1996)
 
Notes
1 2. 59 OS § 1001 et seq. See also chapter 17 of this part.
5-304: PERMITS:
It is unlawful for any person, firm or corporation to proceed with any plumbing
work, or work connected or to be connected with any pipe or pipes of the
waterworks or sewer system of the city, or any private plumbing connected or to
be connected therewith, until a permit for such work has been obtained from the
plumbing inspector. Included in the permit requirement shall be all work as
defined in the plumbing code adopted by the city. The fee for the issuance of
such permit shall be set by the city council by motion or resolution, which fee
shall be paid to the city treasurer of the city, and shall be deposited in the
general fund of the city. (Prior code § 4-38; amd. Ord. 1405, 7-31-1996)
5-305: ADOPTION OF PLUMBING CODE:
A certain document, at least one copy of which is on file in the office of the
city clerk, being marked and designated as the international plumbing code, the
latest edition thereof, and any appendices, revisions or amendments thereto, as
published by the Building Officials And Code Administrators International and
the International Conference Of Building Officials, is hereby adopted as the
plumbing code of the city regulating the design, construction, quality of
materials, erection, installation, alteration, repair, location, relocation,
replacement, addition to, use or maintenance of the plumbing systems. Each and
all of the regulations, provisions, penalties, conditions and terms of the
plumbing code are hereby referred to, adopted and made a part hereof, as if
fully set out in this code, with additions, insertions and changes, if any,
prescribed in this chapter. (Prior code § 4-36; amd. Ord. 1405, 7-31-1996)
5-306: ADDITIONS, INSERTIONS AND CHANGES TO PLUMBING CODE:
   A.   The following sections are hereby revised as follows:
      1.   Section 100.1 (page 1) insert "the city of Duncan";
      2.   Section 106.5.2 (page 4) insert "as set by the city";
      3.   Section 106.5.3 (page 4) insert "as determined by the plumbing
inspector";
      4.   Section 108.4 (page 6) insert "offense and punished as provided in
section
1-108 of the city's code of ordinances";
      5.   Section 108.5 (page 6) insert "as provided in section
1-108 of the city's code of ordinances"; and
      6.   Section 306.6.1 (page 14) insert "one foot" or as otherwise set by
the city.
   B.   The provisions of the plumbing code permitting the use of asbestos
cement pipe for building sewer or building to septic tank or building storm
drain or disposal fields or stack vents shall not be applicable nor allowed in
the city.
   C.   All pipes leaving the curb cock and used for connecting buildings with
the city water system shall be laid underground and at least twelve inches
(12") below the established grade. Such pipes shall be of galvanized, type K
copper pipe or PVC schedule 40 not less than three-fourths inch (3/4") in
diameter for underground and type L, copper pipe for general aboveground work.
   D.   For sewers, three inch (3") minimum size PVC schedule 40 or cast iron
shall be used in service lines from the sewer to any building. (Ord. 1405, 7-
31-1996)
   E.   There shall be a backwater valve installed on all new or replacement
sanitary sewer service lines near the junction of the building drain and the
building sewer. (Ord. 1595, 1-25-2005)
5-307: INSPECTION:
All plumbing and drainage of buildings, and all sewer work inside of private
property lines in the city must be done or installed in accordance with the
provisions of the adopted plumbing code and must be inspected by the plumbing
inspector and a certificate of inspection issued therefor, before the same may
be used or connected with any public sewer or water pipeline, and all sewer
connections or other connections to city water or sewer lines must be inspected
by the plumbing inspector before use. The fees shall be as set by the council
by motion or resolution. (Ord. 1405, 7-31-1996)
5-308: FAILURE TO COMPLY WITH PLUMBING RULES:
Should the plumbing inspector refuse to issue a certificate of approval on any
work due to failure to comply with the plumbing rules and regulations the
inspector shall notify the person(s) doing the work to make such changes and
revisions as are required to comply with the plumbing rules and regulations.
Such notice shall provide that the required changes and revisions be
accomplished within not more than three (3) days of the date of notice of
failure to comply. (Prior code § 4-43; amd. Ord. 1405, 7-31-1996)
5-309: RECOURSE TO PLUMBERS SURETY AND PENALTY:
   A.   In the instance of failure or refusal on the part of a plumber to
rectify or change such plumbing so as to cause same to comply with the plumbing
rules and regulations, then, after three (3) days from the time notice was
given, the owner of any house or premises may have recourse against the
principal and sureties on the bond required to be kept on file with the
Oklahoma state department of health.
   B.   In the instance of failure of any person(s) to comply with a notice to
correct, rectify or change plumbing so as to cause same to comply with the
plumbing rules and regulations, following notice from the plumbing inspector,
or in the instance of violation of any provision of the plumbing code or the
provisions of this chapter, the plumbing inspector may initiate action for
violation of the plumbing rules and regulations in municipal court. Each day
that such failure to comply or violation is permitted to continue may
constitute a separate offense. Any person found guilty of a violation of the
plumbing rules and regulations may be punished in accordance with the
provisions of section
1-108 of this code. (Ord. 1405, 7-31-1996)
CHAPTER 4
ELECTRICAL REGULATIONS
SECTION:
5-401: Electrical Official And Qualifications
5-402: Duties
5-403: Work Not To Be Concealed Before Inspection
5-404: Payment Of Inspection Fees
5-405: Contractors Not To Connect Until Work Approved
5-406: Exemptions
5-407: Right Of Ingress
5-408: Decision Final
5-409: National Electrical Code Adopted
5-410: Registration
5-411: Permit Necessary For Electrical Work
5-412: Temporary Service Permits
5-413: Temporary Pole Meter Service Permits
5-414: Penalty
5-401: ELECTRICAL OFFICIAL AND QUALIFICATIONS 1 :
The office of electrical official is hereby created. He may be the building
official unless another person is appointed by the city manager. (Prior code §§
4-44, 4-45)
 
Notes
1 1. 59 OS § 1680 et seq.
5-402: DUTIES:
It is the duty of the electrical official to issue all permits, and make
inspections of all work for which a permit has been issued within forty eight
(48) hours after having been notified that work is ready for inspection,
Saturdays, Sundays and legal holidays not included. (Prior code § 4-46)
5-403: WORK NOT TO BE CONCEALED BEFORE INSPECTION:
It is unlawful for any person to conceal or cause to be concealed, any
electrical conductors used for electric light, heat or power, until such times
as they know work has been approved by the electrical inspector; and a tag in
the cabinet, properly signed and dated, so stating, will be sufficient notice.
(Prior code § 4-48)
5-404: PAYMENT OF INSPECTION FEES:
   A.   Inspection fee charges shall be made and collected in such amounts as
set out by the council by motion or resolution. For reinspection or return
trips to reexamine and inspect electrical work, the minimum fee or the schedule
of inspection fees, whichever is greater, shall be charged. In no event shall
the electrical official allow or permit electrical installations to be
connected to service lines until such time as all fees for inspection and
reinspection have been paid in full.
   B.   All inspection fees required to be paid under and by virtue of this
chapter shall be paid to the city treasurer and be placed in the general fund
in and for the city. (Prior code § 4-57)
5-405: CONTRACTORS NOT TO CONNECT UNTIL WORK APPROVED:
It is unlawful for any person, firm, partnership, corporation or individual to
conceal or cause to be concealed any electrical conductors, used for electric
light, heat or power, until such time as they know work has been approved by
the electrical inspector, and is ready for electrical service, and a tag in the
cabinet, properly signed and dated, so stating will be sufficient notice.
(Prior code § 4-53)
5-406: EXEMPTIONS:
For the installing of telephone or signal systems not using over twelve (12)
volts, no registration or bond will be required as set out hereinafter, but the
installation of same must comply with the electrical code adopted by the city.
(Prior code § 4-51)
5-407: RIGHT OF INGRESS:
The electrical official, while in the discharge of his duty, shall have the
authority to enter any building or premises at any reasonable hour, and any
person interfering with the electrical inspector while performing his duty
shall be guilty of a public offense. (Prior code § 4-56)
5-408: DECISION FINAL:
The electrical official and the code enforcement department shall be the judge
of what constitutes the safe installation of electrical conductors, and their
decision shall be final and binding when such decision is in conformity with
the provisions of applicable code requirements. (Prior code § 4-56)
5-409: NATIONAL ELECTRICAL CODE ADOPTED 1 :
The rules and requirements of the National Board Of Fire Underwriters known as
the national electrical code, latest edition, with such changes and additions
as may be made from time to time, are hereby made a part of this chapter, and
adopted and incorporated herein by reference as if set out in full herein. The
Underwriters Laboratories, Inc., list of inspected electrical appliances, with
such changes and additions as may hereafter take place, will be the standard
for all electrical fittings and appliances. At least one copy of the code and
list are on file in the office of the city clerk. (Prior code § 4-58)
 
Notes
1 1. 59 OS § 1680 et seq.
5-410: REGISTRATION 1 :
   A.   All persons, firms, partnerships, corporations or individuals, engaged
or hereafter engaging in the business of installing electrical fixtures, wiring
or apparatus in or on any building within the corporate limits of the city
(except central power station, powerhouses and substations belonging to the
electric light company) shall procure from the city a certificate of
registration. Upon payment of a fee as set by the city council and showing
proof of possession of the appropriate and current state license, the
certificate shall entitle the holder to install electrical conductors,
fixtures, or apparatus, within the corporate limits of the city until the birth
date of the licensee next succeeding after all provisions of this chapter have
been complied with. A journeyman electrician shall pay to the city treasurer
the sum for registration annually in such amount as set by the council which
shall entitle the journeyman electrician to engage in his trade within the
city. Any request for renewal of a certificate must be received by the city
within thirty (30) days after the expiration date of the certificate, along
with the required fees and proof of state license. No prorating of the license
is allowed. (Ord. 1596, 1-25-2005)
   B.   Exempt from the provisions of this registration requirement are owners
of property and minor repairs as defined specifically in state statutes or the
electrical code. (Prior code § 4-52)
 
Notes
1 1. 59 OS §§ 1680 - 1696. See also chapter 17 of this part.
5-411: PERMIT NECESSARY FOR ELECTRICAL WORK:
No person, firm, or corporation, or officer, receiver, representative or
employee of any corporation shall do, or cause to be done, any interior or
exterior wiring or any construction, installation, or alteration of any
electrical wiring apparatus or fixtures within the city without first having
complied with the provisions of this chapter and without first having obtained
a permit for the particular work as required by the electrical code from the
electrical official of the city. The electrical official shall not issue a
stamp of approval or otherwise authorize current connected until the provisions
of this chapter and the electrical code of the city have been fully complied
with. (1985 Code)
5-412: TEMPORARY SERVICE PERMITS:
The electrical official may grant temporary electrical service permits for a
period of thirty (30) days with the privilege of extending same at the
discretion of the electrical official upon the payment of a fee as set by the
council for each thirty (30) days plus inspection fees. (1985 Code)
5-413: TEMPORARY POLE METER SERVICE PERMITS:
The electrical inspector may grant a permit for temporary pole meter service
for a period not to exceed one hundred eighty (180) days with the privilege of
extending same at the discretion of the electrical official. A fee as set by
the council shall be paid for each one hundred eighty (180) days or less period
and for every extension of same, plus inspection fees. (1985 Code)
5-414: PENALTY:
Any person found violating any provision of this chapter or any code adopted
herein shall, upon conviction, be punished as provided in section
1-108 of this code. (1985 Code)

additions, deletions and changes, if any, prescribed in this chapter. At least
one copy of the code is kept on file in the office of the city clerk. (1985
Code; amd. 2015 Code)

follows: (1985 Code; amd. 2015 Code)
      1.   The city of Duncan shall be inserted for the name of the
jurisdiction; and
      2.   The penalty for violation of the code shall be as provided in

1-108 in the city's code of ordinances.

5-601: MECHANICAL OFFICIAL 1 :
The office of mechanical official is hereby created. The mechanical official
may be the building official or other person appointed by the city manager
meeting the applicable qualifications of state law. (Ord. 1404, 7-31-1996)
 
Notes
1 1. 59 OS § 1850.1 et seq.
5-602: DUTIES OF MECHANICAL OFFICIAL:
It is the duty of the mechanical official to inspect all mechanical work
performed in the city. The mechanical official may, as far as necessary in the
performance of his duties, enter in the daytime, any building or premises
inside the corporate limits of the city. It is the duty of the mechanical
official to keep a daily record of all his work, including all notices and
applications received, permits and certificates granted, and all violations of
this chapter and other matters which may pertain thereto. (Ord. 1404, 7-31-
1996)
5-603: REGISTRATION REQUIRED; EXEMPTIONS 1 :
   A.   Every person, firm or corporation, before engaging in the mechanical
trade in the city shall pay to the city treasurer a registration fee for the
purpose of regulating the business, the sums as set by council by motion or
resolution for mechanical contractors, journeymen and apprentices, payable in
advance to be deposited in the general fund of the city. The registration fee
herein assessed shall be construed to be exacted from each establishment or
place of business in the city, and not from the individual employees of
mechanical contractors, firms or establishments. The city shall issue
certificates and receipts for all sums of money collected under this provision
to the person, firm or corporation paying the same. No certificate or receipt
may be issued until the applicant shows proof of possession of the appropriate
state license. No certificate shall extend beyond the birth date of the
licensee of any year. Any request for renewal of a certificate must be received
by the city within thirty (30) days after the expiration date of the
certificate, along with the required fees and proof of state license. No
prorating of the license is allowed. (Ord. 1596, 1-25-2005)
   B.   Exempt from the provisions of this registration requirement are owners

5-604: ADOPTION OF MECHANICAL CODE:
A certain document, at least one copy of which is on file in the office of the
city clerk, being marked and designated as the international mechanical code,
the latest edition thereof, and any appendices, revisions or amendments
thereto, as published by the Building Officials And Code Administrators
International and the International Conference Of Building Officials, is hereby
adopted as the mechanical code of the city regulating the design, construction,
quality of materials, erection, installation, alteration, repair, location,
relocation, replacement, addition to, use or maintenance of the mechanical
systems. Each and all of the regulations, provisions, penalties, conditions and
terms of the mechanical code are hereby referred to, adopted and made a part
hereof, as if fully set out in this code, with additions, insertions and
changes, if any, prescribed in this chapter. (Ord. 1404, 7-31-1996)
5-605: ADDITIONS, INSERTIONS AND CHANGES TO MECHANICAL CODE:
   A.   The following sections are hereby revised as follows:
      1.   Section 101.1 (page 1) insert "the city of Duncan";
      2.   Section 106.5.2 (page 4) insert "as set by the city";

official";
      4.   Section 108.4 (page 5) insert "offense and punished as provided in

5-606: INSPECTION:
All mechanical work and installations inside of private property lines in the
city must be done or installed in accordance with the provisions of the adopted
mechanical code and must be inspected by the mechanical official and a
certificate of inspection issued therefor, before the same may be used. The
fees shall be as set by the council by motion or resolution. (Ord. 1404, 7-31-
1996)
5-607: FAILURE TO COMPLY WITH MECHANICAL RULES:
Should the mechanical official refuse to issue a certificate of approval on any
work due to failure to comply with the mechanical rules and regulations the
official shall notify the person(s) doing the work to make such changes and
revisions as are required to comply with the mechanical rules and regulations.
Such notice shall provide that the required changes and revisions be
accomplished within not more than three (3) days of the date of notice of
failure to comply. (Ord. 1404, 7-31-1996)
5-608: RECOURSE TO MECHANICAL SURETY AND PENALTY:
   A.   In the instance of failure or refusal on the part of a mechanical
contractor to rectify or change such mechanical work so as to cause same to
comply with the mechanical rules and regulations, then, after three (3) days
from the time notice was given, the owner of any house or premises may have
recourse against the principal and sureties on the bond required to be kept on
file with the Oklahoma state department of health.
   B.   In the instance of failure of any person(s) to comply with a notice to
correct, rectify or change mechanical work so as to cause same to comply with
the mechanical rules and regulations, following notice from the mechanical
official, or in the instance of violation of any provision of the mechanical
code or the provisions of this chapter, the mechanical official may initiate
action for violation of the mechanical rules and regulations in municipal
court. Each day that such failure to comply or violation is permitted to
continue may constitute a separate offense. Any person found guilty of a
violation of the mechanical rules and regulations may be punished in accordance
with the provisions of section
1-108 of this code. (Ord. 1404, 7-31-1996)
CHAPTER 7
MOVING BUILDINGS
SECTION:
5-701: Permit Required; Fee
5-702: Application And Fees For Permit
5-703: Bond Required For Permit
5-704: Caution Signs
5-705: Protection Of Trees And Overhead Structures
5-706: Guards Against Danger
5-707: Limit To Size Of Building
5-708: Time Limit
5-709: No Permit Issued, When
5-710: Notice To Fire, Police Departments
5-711: Liability
5-701: PERMIT REQUIRED; FEE:
   A.   It is unlawful for any person, firm, corporation, partnership or
individual to move or cause to be moved on the streets or alleys of the city
any house or building, or part thereof, or any similar structure, without
having first obtained from the building official a permit therefor. The
applicant for a permit shall pay the city treasurer a sum as set by the city
council for each such permit, and shall deposit with the city treasurer of the
city a good and sufficient bond as required in this chapter.
   B.   It is unlawful for any person, firm, corporation, partnership or
individual to move or cause to be moved any house or building, or part thereof,
or any similar structure, on the streets or alleys of the city without having
first obtained such permit, paid such permit fee, and deposited such bond with
the city. (Prior code § 5-86)
5-702: APPLICATION AND FEES FOR PERMIT:
The permit shall be obtained by making application therefor in writing. The
written application shall recite the character of the thing or object to be
moved and transported along or through and upon the streets and avenues, the
proposed route of such transportation, and the place where any equipment used
in effecting such transportation shall be placed and secured. (1985 Code)
5-703: BOND REQUIRED FOR PERMIT:
No permit shall be issued as by the terms of this chapter until such time as
the applicant shall have deposited with the officer issuing such permit a cash
bond in such sum as may be reasonably necessary to protect the city and cover
all loss from damage accruing to it or its citizens by reason of any negligence
or improper occupancy of the streets, sidewalks and any and all property
therein. Any negligence or improper occupancy of the streets, sidewalks or
other public places shall be provided against in the bond and such bond shall
be deposited upon the understanding that it is to cover all of the conditions
as set forth in this section. All such persons as described herein, engaged as
principals in the business herein described, shall file a surety bond to be
approved by the city in the sum of one thousand dollars ($1,000.00)
conditioned, that such person shall save, indemnify, and keep harmless the city
against any and all liabilities, judgments, damages, costs and expenses which
may in any way accrue against the city, in consequence of the granting of such
permit or while acting under the same, and will under all circumstances
strictly comply with the terms of such license and permit. Any such surety bond
shall not be in any manner affected by the fact of the cash deposit and bond
required hereunder. Any such person as referred to herein or his laborer,
servant or agent or employee, shall cause a sufficient passageway to be kept
open for vehicles to pass on one side or both sides of any building, structure,
edifice, object or thing, while the same is being moved upon any street, avenue
or alley, and when possible, the same shall be kept moving each day unless the
actual elements render this impossible. (1985 Code)
5-704: CAUTION SIGNS:
It is the duty of the permittee to place warning lights plainly visible for not
less than two hundred feet (200') on each and every side of the building or
structure which is being moved at the close of day and to keep same on
throughout the entire night and until one hour after sunrise on the morning
following. Such lights shall be so placed and maintained that the view of same
will not be in any sense obstructed. If necessary, as many additional lights as
may be necessary shall be placed at such other points on the building or
structure as will enable any person of reasonable and ordinary prudence to take
notice of the obstruction. (1985 Code)
5-705: PROTECTION OF TREES AND OVERHEAD STRUCTURES:
The person who may have a permit to move a building or structure over any
street within the city shall by virtue of such permit and license derive no
right to injure or impair the condition or usefulness of any shade tree,
electric light, telephone or telegraph poles or lines. No tree of any kind
shall be cut, bruised, scarred under any circumstances, without the expressed
permission in writing of the owner of the same and with the permission of the
building official or public works director. In all cases where necessary to
remove any electric light, telephone or telegraph construction, it shall be the
duty of the person moving such building or structure to give not less than
twenty four (24) hours' notice to the public utility company or person owning
or operating the same, which notice shall state the place, the construction
which it is necessary to be removed, or temporarily changed or altered and the
day on which it is desired to have such clearance made as well as the amount of
time it will be necessary to keep such space clear. It is the duty of the
person moving the building or structure to deposit an amount of money estimated
necessary to cover the cost of the changing or moving of public utility
overhead construction and replacing the same in its former condition in a sum
as set by the city with the city treasurer. Upon such deposit being made with
the city treasurer and such notice being delivered to the owner or operator of
the telephone or telegraph and line construction, it is the duty of the person
owning or operating the overhead construction to make such temporary changes as
are reasonably necessary to comply with the representations set forth in the
notice made and delivered to him. (1985 Code)
5-706: GUARDS AGAINST DANGER:
It is the duty of the house mover to station sufficient persons on guard and to
establish such notices by placards or boards in the immediate vicinity of the
moving activities as will be necessary to apprise any reasonable person of any
potential danger that might be incurred by coming closer to the moving
operations or buildings being moved or the instruments or agencies used in the
moving of the same. (1985 Code)
5-707: LIMIT TO SIZE OF BUILDING:
No permit shall be issued to move any building which in the judgment of the
building official or public works director might by any chance result in an
injury to the pavements, bridges, conduits or other street improvements within
the city. (1985 Code)
5-708: TIME LIMIT:
At the time of application for a permit it is the duty of the mover of any
building or structure to estimate the reasonable time required for the moving
of the building from its present location to its proposed location and shall
state in his application for permit what he deems to be such reasonable time.
The mover shall bind himself to pay a sum as set by the city per day for each
and every day, all or any part of which the building or structure remains on
the street in excess of the number of days allowed in the permit, and his cash
deposit in addition to his bond shall be made liable for the payment of the
amount. Nothing but an act of God shall be a defense against the payment of the
sums. (1985 Code)
5-709: NO PERMIT ISSUED, WHEN:
The city shall not issue any permit on any day, which according to the
estimated number of days required to move the building or structure, shall when
counted from the date of the permit include a Sunday or legal holiday; provided
that this shall apply where the permit includes and provides that the persons
moving such house shall begin on the day of the permit. When a day is set on
which the person moving the building shall begin to move the same and the day
is different from the date of issuing the permit, then no permit shall be
issued in such a way to include a Sunday or holiday within the time allowed for
moving the building. Where the number of days shall exceed five (5) the
provisions of this section shall not apply. (1985 Code)
5-710: NOTICE TO FIRE, POLICE DEPARTMENTS:
Any person desiring to move any building shall show his permit to the chiefs of
the fire and police departments. If for any reason any delay is occasioned by
any unforeseen contingency, it is his duty to inform the fire and police
chiefs, of such facts, to the end that the fire and police chiefs may keep
accurate and recent information on the true conditions of the streets and
alleys for fire prevention purposes. (1985 Code)
5-711: LIABILITY:
No provision or condition of this chapter shall be construed so as to limit the
liability civilly of any person moving any house on or over the city streets,
avenues and alleys from any and all damages which may result as the proximate
cause of such acts to any person or his property or to the city. (1985 Code)
CHAPTER 8
DILAPIDATED BUILDINGS
SECTION:
5-801: Nuisance Declared; Report To Be Made
5-802: Definitions
5-803: Removal; Boarding And Securing; Adoption Of State Law
5-804: Method Of Abatement
5-805: Collection Of Costs
5-806: Clearing Premises From Which Buildings Have Been Removed
5-807: Penalty
5-801: NUISANCE DECLARED; REPORT TO BE MADE:
   A.   It is hereby declared to be a public nuisance for any person to suffer
or permit on premises within the city any dilapidated or unsecured buildings as
defined herein.
   B.   Any officer or employee of the city who discovers or receives a report
or complaint of a dilapidated or unsecured building shall report such
conditions to the building official or such other department or official as the
city manager may designate. Upon receiving and verifying the report or
equivalent information from any reliable source, said official shall abate such
conditions as provided in this chapter or in any other manner as this code
provides. (Ord. 1503, 4-25-2000)
5-802: DEFINITIONS:
For purposes of this chapter:
DILAPIDATED BUILDING: A. A structure which through neglect or injury lacks
necessary repairs or otherwise is in a state of decay or partial ruin to such
an extent that the structure is a hazard to the health, safety, or welfare of
the general public,
   B.   A structure which is unfit for human occupancy due to the lack of
necessary repairs and is considered uninhabitable or is a hazard to the health,
safety, and welfare of the general public,
   C.   A structure which is determined by the administrative officer of the
city council to be an "unsecured building", as defined herein, more than three
(3) times within any twelve (12) month period,
   D.   A structure which has been boarded and secured, as defined herein, for
more than thirty six (36) consecutive months, or
   E.   A structure otherwise declared by the city council to constitute a
public nuisance.
UNSECURED BUILDING: Any structure which is not occupied by a legal or equitable
owner thereof, or by a lessee of a legal or equitable owner, and into which
there are one or more unsecured openings such as broken windows, unlocked
windows, broken doors, unlocked doors, holes in exterior walls, holes in the
roof, broken basement or cellar hatchways, unlocked basement or cellar
hatchways or other similar unsecured openings which would facilitate an
unauthorized entry into the structure. (Ord. 1503, 4-25-2000)
5-803: REMOVAL; BOARDING AND SECURING; ADOPTION OF STATE LAW:
   A.   The provisions of 11 Oklahoma Statutes section
22-112 and all subsequent amendments thereto are hereby adopted for the removal
and dismantling of dilapidated buildings. Notice of the hearing to determine
whether a building is dilapidated shall be given concurrently by posting a copy
of the notice on the property affected and by mail to the property owner and
mortgage holder, if any, without necessity for publication.
   B.   The provisions of 11 Oklahoma Statutes section
22-112.1 and all subsequent amendments thereto are hereby adopted for the
boarding and securing of unsecured buildings. Notice of the hearing to
determine whether an unsecured building should be boarded and secured shall be
given in the same manner as for the removal of dilapidated buildings. Said
notice may be given concurrently with notice of other hearings on the condition
of the property or dilapidated buildings thereon and may include additional
notice of summary abatement, if anticipated.
   C.   The city manager or his designee is hereby authorized to carry out the
duties of the city council for the removal, dismantling or boarding and
securing of dilapidated or unsecured buildings, and for the assessment of costs
incurred in the abatement thereof. The city manager may continue a hearing from
time to time for the convenience of the parties. An appeal from any order of
the city manager may be taken by filing written notice of appeal with the city
clerk within ten (10) days after the order is rendered. (Ord. 1503, 4-25-2000)
5-804: METHOD OF ABATEMENT:
The city manager may accomplish the removal, dismantling or boarding and
securing of buildings by force account or private contract, and he is
authorized to execute contracts in furtherance of the same. If done on a
private contract basis, the contract shall be awarded to the lowest and best
bidder according to such rules and regulations as the city council may
prescribe. (Ord. 1503, 4-25-2000)
5-805: COLLECTION OF COSTS:
At any time prior to the collection of costs for removal, dismantling or
boarding and securing as provided by law, the city may pursue any civil remedy
for collection of the amount owing and interest thereon, including an action in
personam against the owner and an action in rem to foreclose the city's lien
against the property. Upon receiving payment, if any, the city clerk shall
forward to the county treasurer a notice of such payment and directing
discharge of the lien. (Ord. 1503, 4-25-2000)
5-806: CLEARING PREMISES FROM WHICH BUILDINGS HAVE BEEN REMOVED:
   A.   In all cases in which a house or building has been completely or
partially removed, dismantled or demolished upon the volition of the owner, or
pursuant to this code, or as otherwise provided by state law, then the owner or
owners of the premises shall have the premises cleaned up and left entirely
free from trash, including, but not limited to:
      1.   The removal of all lumber, brick, concrete, cement, plaster, nails,
wire and other materials;
      2.   Filling in any cellar space and excavations;
      3.   Filling in or safely and securely closing any cistern or well, and
plugging all openings to the sanitary sewer according to the requirements of
the plumbing inspector; and
      4.   Leveling the premises. (Ord. 1503, 4-25-2000)
5-807: PENALTY:
Any person, firm or corporation that maintains a public nuisance as provided
herein, or that fails or refuses to comply with the requirements of this
chapter, shall be guilty of an offense against the city and upon conviction
thereof shall be punished as provided in section
1-108 of this code. (Ord. 1503, 4-25-2000)
CHAPTER 9
HOUSE NUMBERING
SECTION:
5-901: Provisions For Numbering
5-902: System Of Numbering
5-903: Duty Of Owner To Place Number On Building
5-904: Persons Soliciting The Numbering Of Houses Without Permit; Penalty
5-905: Duty Of Property Owner To Number House; Size Of Number
5-906: City May Number Houses
5-907: Penalty
5-901: PROVISIONS FOR NUMBERING:
All buildings in the city shall be numbered in the following manner: the
baseline, north and south, shall be 1st Street; and all buildings east of the
line shall be known and numbered as east, and all buildings west of the line
shall be known and numbered as west. The baseline east and west shall be Main
Street; and all buildings north of the baseline shall be known and numbered as
north; and all buildings south of the line shall be known and numbered as
south. (Prior code § 4-83)
5-902: SYSTEM OF NUMBERING:
   A.   There shall be one hundred (100) numbers applicable to each block,
commencing with 101 on the odd side and 100 on the even side of the streets,
and the first block from the baseline in either direction shall be given
numbers from 1 to 100; the second block to 200; the third block shall be given
numbers from 200 to 300; and so on in regular order by hundreds, to each block
in succession. The even numbers shall be on the east side of the streets
extending north and south, and on the south side of the streets extending east
and west, the odd numbers, vice versa.
   B.   Each twenty five feet (25') of frontage on each block of each street,
except as hereinafter provided, shall be entitled to a separate number,
excepting whenever it shall occur that an extra short street or place
intervenes between two (2) regular numbered or named streets, the numbers shall
proceed in their regular order, until the next regular numbered or named street
shall occur. The affix of one-half (1/2) shall be attached to the last
preceding number in designating stairways.
   C.   In the event on any twenty five feet (25') of frontage as heretofore
set out, there shall be more than one property, business, or residence desiring
a street number, the number will be indicated separately by alphabetical
arrangements as A, B, and C. In the event of any conflict in numbers the
building official shall determine the numbers in their proper order and
arrangement and the decision of the official in all such matters shall be
final. (Prior code § 4-84)
5-903: DUTY OF OWNER TO PLACE NUMBER ON BUILDING:
It is the duty of the owner of any house in the city to have his house properly
numbered in accordance with this chapter and whenever any such property owner
is in doubt as to the correct number of his premises, he shall apply to the
building official for such number, whose duty it shall be to designate the
proper numbers for the premises without expense to the property owner. (Prior
code § 4-85)
5-904: PERSONS SOLICITING THE NUMBERING OF HOUSES WITHOUT PERMIT; PENALTY:
Any person soliciting the numbering of houses or making it a business of
numbering houses, without a permit therefor from the city, or not in accordance
with this chapter, shall be punished in accordance with section
1-108 of this code for each offense including costs of prosecution; provided
that the foregoing provisions do not apply to any person numbering one or more
houses of which he is the owner. The owner shall use proper precaution to
secure the correct number for the premises in the manner herein provided.
(Prior code § 4-86)
5-905: DUTY OF PROPERTY OWNER TO NUMBER HOUSE; SIZE OF NUMBER:
Each resident of this city and each property owner thereof shall place and keep
in a conspicuous place, on the front of the house, in plain, legible figures
not less than two inches (2") high, the official number of the house according
to the system of numbering on record in the office of building official. (Prior
code § 4-87)
5-906: CITY MAY NUMBER HOUSES:
Upon failure of the person, firm, agent, corporation or owner of any such
property to number the same the city through its building official shall cause
the number to be placed upon each and every building at the expense of the
owner thereof, and collect for the same such amount as shall be fixed from time
to time by suit or by taxing the same against the premises. The person placing
the numbers upon such house or houses at the direction of the city shall not in
any way hold the city liable for such work in placing the same thereon. (1985
Code)
5-907: PENALTY:
Any person, firm, agent, corporation or owner of any such property who shall
fail, neglect or refuse to properly number a residence or place of business or
any houses owned by any such person, firm or corporation, according to the
terms of this chapter, shall be punished as provided in section
1-108 of this code. (1985 Code)
CHAPTER 10
FAIR HOUSING
SECTION:
5-1001: Purposes And Construction
5-1002: Housing Discrimination Acts Prohibited
5-1003: Exemptions
5-1004: Fair Housing Board Created
5-1005: Duties Of Fair Housing Board
5-1006: Procedure For Complaints
5-1007: Notices
5-1008: Penalty
5-1001: PURPOSES AND CONSTRUCTION:
The general purposes of this chapter are:
   A.   To secure for all people equal access to housing in all neighborhoods;
and
   B.   To preserve the public safety, health and welfare. (1985 Code)
5-1002: HOUSING DISCRIMINATION ACTS PROHIBITED:
   A.   It is unlawful for any person, real estate broker, real estate
salesperson, or corporation:
      1.   To refuse to sell, lease, rent, assign or otherwise transfer the
title or other interest in any housing, or real property upon which residential
housing is to be constructed to any person, or to discriminate in the terms or
conditions of the sale, rental or leasing of any residential housing unit,
because of race, color, religion, gender, national origin, age, familial
status, or disability;
      2.   To refuse to negotiate with any person for the sale, rental, or
leasing of any residential property, or to represent that such property is not
available for inspection, sale, rental or lease when in fact it is so
available, because of such person's race, color, religion, gender, national
origin, age, familial status, or disability;
      3.   To solicit or induce, or attempt to solicit or induce, any person
owning any interest in any residential housing to sell, rent or lease, or not
to sell, rent or lease such housing to any person on the grounds of loss of
value due to the present or prospective entry into the neighborhood of a person
or persons of another race, color, religion, gender, national origin, age,
familial status, or disability, either by direct solicitation or inducement or
by the purchase of other property in the neighborhood for the purpose of such
inducement, or to distribute, or cause to be distributed material or making
statements designed to induce a residential property owner to sell or lease his
property due to such change in neighborhood; or
      4.   To file a complaint alleging a violation of this chapter, with
knowledge that such complaint is false in any material respect, or to file such
complaint for the sole purpose of harassment. (Prior code § 4-112; amd. 2015
Code)
5-1003: EXEMPTIONS:
   A.   Nothing herein shall apply to:
      1.   Prohibit persons from giving preference to prospective buyers or
tenants for any reason other than race, color, religion, gender, national
origin, age, familial status, or disability; (Prior code § 4-113; amd. 2015
Code)
      2.   The sale of a dwelling which is, or was at the time when first
offered for sale, the residence of its owner;
      3.   The rental of rooms in an owner occupied residence or in a dwelling
used exclusively as a rooming house;
      4.   The rental or leasing of a housing unit in a building containing no
more than eight (8) housing units; or
      5.   The rental or leasing of a dwelling or housing unit owned by any
religious or fraternal organization, or private club used and occupied for such
organizational purposes. (Prior code § 4-113)
5-1004: FAIR HOUSING BOARD CREATED:
There is hereby created a fair housing board of the city, hereinafter referred
to as "board", which shall be the city council. (Prior code § 4-114)
5-1005: DUTIES OF FAIR HOUSING BOARD:
   A.   It is the duty of the fair housing board to:
      1.   Initiate, receive, and investigate complaints charging unlawful
housing practices;
      2.   Seek conciliation of such complaints, hold hearings, make findings
of fact, and publish its findings of fact; and
      3.   Adopt such rules and regulations as may be necessary within the
limits of this chapter, and carry out the purposes and provisions of this
chapter. (1985 Code)
5-1006: PROCEDURE FOR COMPLAINTS:
   A.   Any person aggrieved by discriminatory practice prohibited by this
chapter may file with the fair housing board a complaint in writing, under
oath. The complaint shall be signed by the person claiming to be aggrieved, and
shall state the name and address of the person alleged to have violated the
provisions of this chapter, and shall further set forth the particulars of the
violation, and may include such other information as may be required by the
board. Complaints filed under this section must be filed within thirty (30)
days after the alleged violation, and failure to file within the time, shall be
considered a waiver of the application of this chapter. The board may issue a
complaint on its own initiative, at any time it is within the knowledge of the
board that a person has violated any of the provisions of this chapter.
   B.   The board shall investigate each complaint filed with the board, and
shall attempt an adjustment of the complaint by means of conference and
conciliation. Sixty (60) days shall be allowed for the purpose of
investigation, conference and conciliation. Upon determination that a complaint
is not well founded, the board shall dismiss the complaint and notify the
complainant and respondent in writing of the dismissal. If the board takes no
action within ninety (90) days of the filing of the complaint, it shall be
considered as dismissed.
   C.   If conference or conciliation does not result in compliance with this
chapter, the board shall cause to be issued and served in the name of the city
a written notice, together with a copy of the complaint, requiring the person
named in the complaint, hereinafter referred to as respondent, to answer
charges of the complaint at a hearing before the board at a time and place to
be specified in the notice.
   D.   At the hearing, provided for in subsection C of this section, the
complaint shall be heard by the board. At the hearing, the complainant or
person aggrieved may appear in person or by counsel, and the respondent may
file a written answer to the complaint and may appear in person or by legal
counsel. The board, when conducting any hearing pursuant to this section, may
permit amendments to any complaint or answer, and the testimony taken at the
hearing shall be under oath, and shall be transcribed at the request of either
party, or at the direction of the board. If the board finds at the hearing that
the respondent has engaged in any discriminatory practice or practices
prohibited by this chapter, it shall state its findings of fact, and shall so
certify the matter to the city attorney for appropriate action. No prosecution
shall be brought under this chapter except upon such certification. If the
board, upon hearing, finds that respondent has not engaged in any
discriminatory practice, it shall state its findings of fact and shall issue
and file an order dismissing the complaint. The board shall establish rules and
regulations to govern and expedite and effectuate the foregoing procedure, and
shall maintain the files provided for herein. (Prior code § 4-115)
5-1007: NOTICES:
Any and all notices required under the provisions of this chapter to be served
upon any person, may be served personally on such person, or by mailing a copy
thereof by certified or registered mail, with return receipt requested, to the
most current business or residence address of such person. (1985 Code)
5-1008: PENALTY:
It is unlawful and an offense for any person to violate any of the provisions
of this chapter. Any person found guilty of violating any provisions shall be
deemed guilty of an offense, and is subject, upon conviction, to punishment as
provided in section
1-108 of this code. (1985 Code)
CHAPTER 11
OIL AND GAS DRILLING AND PRODUCTION
SECTION:
5-1101: Definitions
5-1102: Public Nuisance
5-1103: Permits Required
5-1104: Location Of Wells
5-1105: Permit Fees
5-1106: Drilling Permits
5-1107: Production Permits
5-1108: Completion And Plugging Reports
5-1109: Permit Amendment Or Conversion
5-1110: Application Review
5-1111: Permit Issuance
5-1112: Compliance Bond
5-1113: Liability Insurance
5-1114: Drilling And Production Regulations
5-1115: Premises To Be Maintained And Enclosed
5-1116: Emergency Actions
5-1117: Appeals
5-1118: Penalty And Enforcement
5-1101: DEFINITIONS:
The words and terms used in this chapter shall have the meaning ascribed below
unless the context of their usage shall clearly indicate otherwise:
ABANDONED WELL: A. A well in which no production casing has been run and for
which drilling or testing operations have ceased for thirty (30) consecutive
days; or
   B.   Any other well for which there is no current production or drilling
permit.
CITY: The city of Duncan, Oklahoma, a municipal corporation.
CITY MANAGER: The person currently serving in the capacity of city manager for
the city, or such person or persons as the city manager may designate to
perform the duties assigned to the city manager under the provisions of this
chapter.
CORPORATION COMMISSION: The corporation commission of the state of Oklahoma.
DELETERIOUS SUBSTANCE: Any chemical, salt water, oil field brine, oil, gasoline
or other oil product, waste oil, waste emulsified oil, basic sediment, drilling
or rotary mud or injurious substances produced or used in the drilling,
development, producing, transportation, refining and process of oil, gas or
condensate.
OIL OR GAS WELL, WELL: Any well, hole or bore, of any depth for the purpose of
production or disposal of oil, gas, casing head gas, or liquefied matter or any
byproducts thereof, or for the injection or disposal of any of the foregoing.
PERMIT HOLDER (PERMITTEE): Any person to whom is issued a permit under the
terms of this chapter.
PERSON: Any person, firm, partnership, corporation or association, trust,
cooperative or other similar organization.
POLLUTION: The contamination or other alteration of the physical, chemical or
biological properties of any natural waters of the city, or such discharge of
any liquid, gaseous or solid substance into any water of the city as will, or
is likely to, create a nuisance or render such waters harmful or detrimental or
injurious to:
   A.   Public health, safety or welfare;
   B.   Domestic, commercial, industrial, agricultural, recreational or other
beneficial uses; or
   C.   Livestock, animals or aquatic life.
STATE: The state of Oklahoma, its branches, departments, agencies, boards and
commissions, or the officers thereof. (Ord. 1383, 10-24-1995)
5-1102: PUBLIC NUISANCE:
Whereas the imprudent operation of an oil or gas well and related production
facilities can constitute a menace to the public health, safety and welfare of
the city, it is the intent and purpose of this chapter that oil and gas
production operations be reasonably regulated for the public good. Therefore,
the drilling, mining, or production of oil, gas, or other minerals within the
corporate limits, except in compliance with the provisions of this chapter, is
hereby declared a nuisance against the public health, safety and welfare of the
city. (Ord. 1383, 10-24-1995)
5-1103: PERMITS REQUIRED:
   A.   It is unlawful and an offense for any person to engage in any work
incident to the drilling of an oil or gas well, opening or reentry of an
abandoned oil or gas well unless a permit for drilling, opening or reentry
shall have been first obtained as provided by the terms of this chapter.
   B.   It shall be unlawful and an offense for any person to maintain or
operate an oil and gas well or related production facilities or to engage in
the work incident to the maintenance and operation of the same without a valid
production permit therefor as provided by the terms of this chapter.
   C.   Operators of producing wells within the corporate limits of the city on
the effective date of this chapter, or upon the effective date of any
subsequent annexation, shall be notified of the production permit requirements
of this chapter and shall apply for a production permit therefor within sixty
(60) days of such notice. Approval of such permit shall be conditioned upon
compliance with the provisions of this chapter within ninety (90) days of
permit approval. (Ord. 1383, 10-24-1995)
5-1104: LOCATION OF WELLS:
   A.   It is unlawful for any person to drill, mine or produce or cause to be
drilled, mined, or produced, any oil, gas, or other minerals within the
corporate limits of the city, except where permitted under the zoning ordinance
of the city, and in compliance with the terms in this chapter.
   B.   No permit shall be issued for the drilling of a well or reentry of an
abandoned well at any location which is within one hundred fifty feet (150') of
a surface property boundary line other than a street right of way or within
four hundred feet (400') of any residence, commercial building, church, school,
building intended for human occupancy or freshwater well. Distances prescribed
shall be measured from the proposed permanent enclosure of the facility.
   C.   No permit shall be issued for the drilling of a well or reentry of an
abandoned well within the right of way of a public street or within the
projected right of way or within a building setback line of any existing or
proposed street as identified in the major street plan of the city or other
plan, ordinance or document establishing the same.
   D.   The provisions of this section shall not be construed to prohibit the
maintenance, operation or reworking of a well for which a production permit has
been maintained in compliance with the terms of this chapter. (Ord. 1383, 10-
24-1995)
5-1105: PERMIT FEES:
   A.   The permit fee for drilling, opening or reentry of a well shall be as
set by council for each well. Permit fees shall be payable upon permit
application. No action in review of a permit application shall be taken without
the payment of such fee to the city treasurer. Should an application for permit
for drilling, opening or reentry of a well be denied or withdrawn the city
treasurer shall refund the permit fee less one hundred dollars ($100.00) held
for application processing fee.
   B.   There shall be no fee for production permits. (Ord. 1383, 10-24-1995)
5-1106: DRILLING PERMITS:
   A.   Applications for permits to drill an original well or reenter an
abandoned well shall be submitted in the form and shall include such
information as the city manager shall require to assure compliance with the
provisions of this chapter. Applications shall include, but not necessarily be
limited to, the following information:
      1.   Site surveys and plot maps showing the location of the well and
surrounding surface property lines and buildings and existing oil, gas and
freshwater wells within four hundred feet (400') of the site;
      2.   Plot maps indicating the proposed location of enclosures to be
provided should a producing well be established;
      3.   A complete copy of the notice of intent to drill as submitted to the
corporation commission of the state, including a drilling prognosis to specify
in detail the amount, weight, and size of conductor pipe and surface pipe and
the procedures to be used for cementing such and plugging procedures to be used
in the event production is not established; and
      4.   Affidavit identifying the name, title, address and phone number of
the service agent for the applicant. (Ord. 1383, 10-24-1995)
5-1107: PRODUCTION PERMITS:
   A.   Initial applications for production permits shall be submitted in a
form prescribed by the city manager. Applications shall describe each lease
maintained by the applicant within the city and the surface facilities
associated with such lease, including each well thereon and any associated
surface facilities. To the extent practical, the information requested shall be
provided in the form of spill prevention control and countermeasure plans and
superfund amendment and reauthorization act (SARA title III) reports.
   B.   Production permit renewals shall be issued upon verification that the
information of record is current and accurate and receipt of insurance and bond
renewals. Notice of renewal and request for verification of information shall
be provided to the permit holder not less than thirty (30) days prior to the
expiration of the production permit.
   C.   Production permits shall expire on the expiration or anniversary date
of the liability insurance policy required in section
5-1113 of this chapter. (Ord. 1383, 10-24-1995)
5-1108: COMPLETION AND PLUGGING REPORTS:
   A.   The holder of any permit under the provisions of this chapter shall
provide the city with copies of all reports and documentation required by the
corporation commission of the state in relation to the completion or plugging
of a well, excluding well logs. Information provided to the corporation
commission shall be provided to the city within forty eight (48) hours of
filing with the commission.
   B.   Surface casing shall be set in accordance with the rules and
regulations of the corporation commission or water resources board in all
respects. The permittee shall furnish evidence of compliance, casing logs, upon
request by the city. Such request for casing logs may be made a condition of
drilling permit approval. (Ord. 1383, 10-24-1995)
5-1109: PERMIT AMENDMENT OR CONVERSION:
   A.   Upon receipt of a completion or plugging report, as required in section
5-1108 of this chapter the city manager shall cause the inspection of the
permitted facility in question for compliance with the terms of this chapter.
   B.   In the instance of a completed well, the drilling permit shall remain
in force and effect until the site shall be in compliance with the applicable
production permit provisions of this chapter, or the permit term expires. Upon
compliance with the terms of this chapter, the city manager shall approve the
conversion of the drilling permit to a production permit.
   C.   In the instance of a plugging report, the permitted facility shall be
removed from those maintained under the permit holder's production permit,
provided that the site has been appropriately abandoned. (Ord. 1383, 10-24-
1995)
5-1110: APPLICATION REVIEW:
   A.   Applications for permits required by this chapter shall be reviewed by
the city manager for compliance with the terms and conditions of this chapter
and approved or denied based upon such review.
   B.   Should the city manager find deficiencies or violations of the
provisions of this chapter in review of an application for production permits,
the applicant shall be notified of such deficiencies and advised that the
permit application shall be held in abeyance until such deficiencies are
corrected. Such notice shall provide that production from such sites shall not
continue beyond the expiration date of the previous production permit. (Ord.
1383, 10-24-1995)
5-1111: PERMIT ISSUANCE:
   A.   Permits approved in accordance with the provisions of this chapter
shall be issued by the city manager and shall:
      1.   Be issued only after submission of such bonds and certificates of
insurance in amounts as provided for elsewhere in this chapter;
      2.   Incorporate by reference all provisions of this chapter with the
same force and effect as if reproduced verbatim therein;
      3.   Incorporate by reference all provisions of applicable law and the
rules, regulations and standards adopted in accordance therewith relating to
the protection of human beings, animals and natural resources, including those
of the corporation commission, water resources board, department of
environmental quality and environmental protection agency; and
      4.   Specify that the term of the permit shall be for a period of one
year from the anniversary date of liability insurance required herein and shall
be renewed for like periods thereafter upon application and successful
inspection of the permitted facility as provided in this chapter or until such
time as the facility is properly plugged and abandoned in accordance with the
terms of this chapter.
   B.   Permits shall be issued in two (2) originals signed by the city manager
and the applicant, one of which shall be maintained by each signatory. (Ord.
1383, 10-24-1995)
5-1112: COMPLIANCE BOND:
   A.   The provisions of this section shall apply to any holder or applicant
for a drilling or production permit:
      1.   Required to post or maintain a similar surety for plugging and site
remediation with the Oklahoma corporation commission; or
      2.   Found in violation of the provisions of this chapter within the past
three (3) consecutive production permit terms.
   B.   Prior to the issuance of any permit as required in this chapter the
applicant shall provide a bond, executed by a reliable insurance company
authorized to do business in the state, with the issuing company as surety and
the applicant as principal, running to the city for the benefit of the city and
all persons concerned, conditioned that the principal shall:
      1.   Comply with the terms and conditions of this chapter;
      2.   Promptly pay fines, penalties and other assessments imposed upon the
permit holder by reason of breach of any provisions and conditions of this
chapter;
      3.   Promptly restore streets, sidewalks and other public property of the
city which may be disturbed or damaged in the permittee's operations to their
former conditions;
      4.   Upon completion of drilling, opening and reentry operations or
plugging operations grade level and restore the property to the same surface
conditions as existed prior to commencing operations, as practicably as
possible, in accordance with the provisions of this chapter;
      5.   Maintain the site free of litter, trash, waste, and other substances
or material not essential to the maintenance and operation of facility; and
      6.   Hold harmless the city from any liability attributable to granting
the permit.
   C.   The compliance bond required in this section shall become effective on
or before the date filed with the city and remain in force and effect for at
least twelve (12) months after the expiration of permit term.
   D.   The amount of the compliance bond required in this section shall be in
a principal amount of fifteen thousand dollars ($15,000.00) with respect to any
holder of a drilling permit.
   E.   The amount of the compliance bond required in this section shall be in
a principal amount of five thousand dollars ($5,000.00) for such period as the
permit holder maintains the production permit. (Ord. 1383, 10-24-1995)
5-1113: LIABILITY INSURANCE:
   A.   Each holder of a permit under the terms of this chapter shall carry a
policy or policies of standard comprehensive public liability insurance,
including contractual liability, covering bodily injuries and property damage,
naming the permit holder and the city, issued by an insurer authorized to do
business within the state. The policy or policies shall in the aggregate
provide the following minimum coverage:
      1.   Bodily injuries: One hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00) per
person and one million dollars ($1,000,000.00) per accident; and
      2.   Property damage: Five hundred thousand dollars ($500,000.00).
   B.   Certificates of insurance submitted in compliance with the provisions
of this section shall provide that the policy shall not be canceled without
notice to the city at least fifteen (15) days prior to the effective date of
such cancellation.
   C.   In the event the policy is canceled, the permit or permits held in
conjunction therewith shall immediately thereupon terminate without any action
on the part of the city and the permittee's rights to operation under such
permits shall cease until permit holder files additional insurance bonds or
surety as required herein. (Ord. 1383, 10-24-1995)
5-1114: DRILLING AND PRODUCTION REGULATIONS:
   A.   Persons drilling, operating, or maintaining any oil and gas well shall
use all necessary care and take all precautions which shall be reasonably
necessary under the circumstances to protect the public. The provisions of this
section shall be deemed to be the minimum requirements for the preservation of
the public health, safety, and welfare, and compliance with the terms hereof
shall not be deemed to relieve any person of any additional duty or liability
imposed by law.
   B.   The drilling, operation or maintenance of any oil or gas well and
related facilities shall be subject to the following regulations, and
violations thereof are hereby declared unlawful and an offense:
      1.   No deleterious substance shall be disposed of by draining or
diverting the same into or upon any public highway, street or alley, drainage
ditch, storm sewer, sanitary sewer, gutter or paving; nor shall any of such
substance be permitted to escape from the property owned, leased or controlled
by the person conducting such operations by seepage or overflow;
      2.   No steam engine, gasoline, natural gas, diesel or other internal
combustion engine shall be operated without being muffled;
      3.   All permits for drilling, opening or reentry of a well shall
prescribe the use of blowout prevention unless specifically exempted by the
city council;
      4.   No earthen pits shall be permitted without the review and approval
of the city council. All metal pits or other pits and their contents shall be
removed from the premises within sixty (60) days after completion of the well;
      5.   All storage tanks or other tanks intended to contain inflammable
substances shall be protected by earthen embankments constructed in compliance
with the provisions of the spill prevention containment and countermeasure plan
requirements as promulgated by the environmental protection agency. No such
tanks shall be erected or installed nearer to any surface property boundary or
structure than permitted in accordance with section
5-1104 of this chapter;
      6.   Approved equipment, devices and methods for the safety of life and
property, such as are commonly known in the oil drill and producing business,
must be used in the city in the carrying on of all the operations covered by
this chapter, and the failure to use any such equipment, devices or methods in
any substantially important question shall be a grounds for immediately
stopping further work until such failure has been corrected;
      7.   Derricks, metal pits and other equipment not necessary to production
shall be removed from a permitted well site within sixty (60) days of the
cessation of drilling;
      8.   No pipeline, power transmission system, communications system or
other facility shall be erected or installed upon, within or under any public
right of way except in accordance with such permits as may be required by the
city; and
      9.   Permits for drilling or reentry of wells may include provisions
requiring compliance with adopted standards for driveway improvements. (Ord.
1383, 10-24-1995)
5-1115: PREMISES TO BE MAINTAINED AND ENCLOSED:
   A.   The premises of any well and associated surface facilities shall be
kept free from accumulations of rubbish, litter, tall weeds and grass, unused
materials or equipment, excessive rotary mud and waste oil or oily substances
or other deleterious substance, as far as such premises may be reasonably kept
free of the same in the carrying on of operations.
   B.   All surface facilities associated with oil and gas production shall be
secured by a fence of not less than six feet (6') in height provided with three
(3) strands of barbed wire affixed to the top thereof. Such fence shall be
constructed and maintained so as to ordinarily keep persons and animals out of
the enclosure in accordance with the following:
      1.   Such fence shall be of 9-gauge wire mesh material, or such other
material as may be approved within the terms and conditions of the permit;
      2.   The enclosure shall provide no openings of greater than four inches
(4") in any dimension, including any separation between the bottom of the fence
and adjacent grade;
      3.   Fences and gates shall be kept locked when the permit holder or his
or her employees are not within the enclosure; and
      4.   The provisions of this section may be complied with by the provision
of a single enclosure of multiple surface facilities or individual enclosures
for each surface facility in accordance with plans submitted and approved in
conjunction with permit review and approval procedures.
   C.   All lease equipment shall be painted and maintained in a good state of
condition, operation and appearance.
   D.   Each enclosure, as required above, shall have posted in a prominent
place a metal sign of no less than two (2) square feet in area upon which the
following information shall be conspicuous:
      1.   Name of operator;
      2.   Lease name;
      3.   Location of site by reference to the United States survey;
      4.   Identify number of permit issued by the city; and
      5.   A current emergency response phone number.
   E.   Each enclosure, as required above, shall have hazard warning signs
prominently posted so as to be clearly visible from all approaches to the
enclosure. Such signs shall be not less than two (2) square feet in area.
   F.   All tanks or vessels equipped with thief or similar hatches shall be
fitted with mechanisms permitting the locking thereof and shall be maintained
locked except in the presence of the operator's employees or agents. (Ord.
1383, 10-24-1995)
5-1116: EMERGENCY ACTIONS:
   A.   The city manager or his or her appointee shall have the authority to
require the immediate shutting in or closing of any well if it is found that
there exists within a one hundred foot (100') radius of the enclosure of any
facility or well, any flammable or explosive vapor in a quantity sufficient to
constitute, in his or her judgment or the judgment of the fire marshal, a fire
hazard or health hazard.
   B.   If the city finds that a hazard to life or natural resources exists,
the city manager or his or her appointee shall order immediate rectification of
the cause. If the permit holder takes no immediate action to reduce a hazard,
or if the situation be so perilous as to constitute an imminent threat to
safety, then the city manager or his or her appointee may order the prompt
cessation of activity, and if necessary the clearing of the premises. (Ord.
1383, 10-24-1995)
5-1117: APPEALS:
   A.   Applicants aggrieved by any order, directive, or ruling by the city
manager or his or her appointee under the provisions of this chapter may appeal
the same to the city council, which shall hear the matter at its next scheduled
meeting, provided that the aggrieved party has submitted a written appeal to
the city manager not less than five (5) workdays prior to such meeting. The
lodging of such an appeal shall not stay the enforcement of any provision of
this chapter.
   B.   Any appeal of the provisions of this chapter involving a request for
variation of the provisions of this chapter relating to the location of wells
shall require not less than fifteen (15) days' notice of hearing to all surface
owners of property within six hundred feet (600') of the site in question.
(Ord. 1383, 10-24-1995)
5-1118: PENALTY AND ENFORCEMENT:
   A.   Any person found in violation of the provisions of this chapter may be
punished as provided in section
1-108 of this code. Each day in which a violation continues may constitute a
separate offense.
   B.   In addition to any penalty prescribed above, the city may, upon
direction of the city council, seek compliance with the provisions of this
chapter through action in a court of competent jurisdiction. (Ord. 1383, 10-24-
1995)
CHAPTER 12
SEWER LINE CONNECTION REGULATIONS
SECTION:
5-1201: Definitions
5-1202: Defective And Prohibited Connections
5-1203: Administrative Procedure
5-1204: Corrective Action
5-1201: DEFINITIONS:
For purposes of this chapter, the following definitions are hereby adopted:
DEFECTIVE SERVICE LINE: A line transporting wastewater from a user facility to
the public wastewater collection system that in addition allows the entrance of
infiltration or inflow.
INFILTRATION: Water entering the publicly owned treatment works at any
location, public or private, by permeation through the ground and subsequent
entry through defective pipes, pipe joints, connections, manhole walls or
similar such means of passage.
INFLOW: Water entering the publicly owned treatment works at any location,
public or private, by means of surface stormwater or irrigation runoff, or
piped transportation of such waters.
PROHIBITED CONNECTION: Any piping arrangement or transportation system that
conveys groundwater, stormwater or irrigation runoff, or any condensate to the
public wastewater collection system. (Ord. 1326, 3-24-1992)
5-1202: DEFECTIVE AND PROHIBITED CONNECTIONS:
   A.   To minimize groundwater infiltration and surface water inflow to the
public wastewater system that overloads pipelines and inhibits wastewater
treatment, the city hereby requires the owner of any property on which a
defective sewer line or a prohibited connection is located to repair the
service line or remove the prohibited connection at the owner's expense.
   B.   The city will investigate and determine if a service line is defective.
Cracked, broken, crushed or similarly damaged lines, lines with separated
joints, or lines with any condition that allows infiltration of groundwater
shall be considered defective.
   C.   The city will investigate and determine if a connection to the public
sewer is a prohibited connection. Prohibited connections may be direct to the
public sewer or indirect through the property service line. Roof drains, yard
drains, driveway and parking area drains, foundation drains, exterior stairwell
drains, uncapped cleanouts, sumps or any other system that conveys groundwater
or surface runoff to a public wastewater system may be considered a prohibited
connection, even though such connection may not have been prohibited under
existing ordinance, regulations or standards at the time of construction. (Ord.
1326, 3-24-1992)
5-1203: ADMINISTRATIVE PROCEDURE:
The code enforcement officer will provide written notice to the property owner
by certified mail that corrective action is required. The written notice will
specify the action that is needed such as partial repair, replacement or
disconnection. The property owner shall have sixty (60) days from the date of
the notice to complete the work. If the property owner fails to complete the
work, the code enforcement officer will file appropriate damages in municipal
court for violation of this code. In addition to prosecution in municipal
court, the city may pursue a civil action by injunction in any court of
competent jurisdiction to temporarily or permanently enjoin the continuation of
wastewater collection service because of a public health nuisance. Further, the
city may suspend water service to property until the violations are corrected.
(Ord. 1326, 3-24-1992)
5-1204: CORRECTIVE ACTION:
Plumbing work shall be done in accordance with all city, state and federal
codes, regulations and standards. The city in no way whatsoever assumes any
responsibility or liability for corrective action undertaken by the property
owner or plumbing contractor. All prohibited connections shall be disconnected
immediately at the public sewer or sanitary service line and capped with a
watertight seal. Any repairs to the service tap fitting shall be made by a
licensed plumbing contractor registered with the city. Any repairs to a public
sewer shall be made by a licensed plumbing contractor registered with the city,
or by city personnel. All corrective work shall be inspected and approved by
the city prior to being covered and returned to service. Connection of
terminated service shall be at the owner's expense. Any person damaging a
public sewer main shall be responsible for reasonable repair costs for such
damage, as determined by the city. (Ord. 1326, 3-24-1992; amd. Ord. 1351, 6-14-
1994)
CHAPTER 13
BUILDING DEMOLITION
SECTION:
5-1301: Permit Required
5-1302: Conditions Of Permit
