recorded with any recording officer as provided by general law; and in addition
thereto, means any periodical or current magazine regularly published with not
less than four (4) issues per year, and sold to the public.
NONCOMMERCIAL HANDBILL: Any printed or written matter, any sample, device,
dodger, circular, leaflet, pamphlet, newspaper, magazine, paper, booklet, or
any other printed or other reproduced original or copies of any matter of
literature not included in the aforesaid definitions of a "commercial handbill"
or "newspaper".
PARK: A park, reservation, playground, beach, recreation center, or any other
public area in the city, owned or used by the city and devoted to active or
passive recreation.
PRIVATE PREMISES: Any dwelling, house, building, or other structure, designed
or used either wholly or in part for private residential purposes, whether
inhabited or temporarily or continuously uninhabited or vacant, and includes
any yard, grounds, walk, driveway, porch, steps, vestibule, or mailbox
belonging or appurtenant to such dwelling house, building, or other structure.
PUBLIC PLACE: Any and all streets, sidewalks, boulevards, alleys, or other
public ways, and any and all public parks, squares, spaces, grounds, and
buildings.
REFUSE: All putrefied and nonputrefied solid wastes (except body wastes),
including garbage, rubbish, ashes, street cleanings, dead animals, abandoned
automobiles, and solid market and industrial wastes.
RUBBISH: Nonputrefied solid wastes consisting of both combustible and
noncombustible wastes, such as paper, wrappings, cigarettes, cardboard, tin
cans, yard clippings, leaves, wood, glass, bedding, crockery, and similar
materials.
VEHICLE: Every device in, upon, or by which any person or property is or may be
transported or drawn upon a highway, including devices used exclusively upon
stationary rails or tracks. (1985 Code)
8-502: LITTER IN PUBLIC PLACES:
No person shall throw or deposit litter in or upon any street, sidewalk, or
other public place within the city except in public receptacles, in authorized
private receptacles for collection, or in official city dumps. (1985 Code)
8-503: PLACEMENT OF LITTER IN RECEPTACLES SO AS TO PREVENT SCATTERING:
Persons placing litter in public receptacles or in authorized private
receptacles shall do so in such a manner so as to prevent it from being carried
or deposited by the elements upon any street, sidewalk, or other public place,
or upon private property. (1985 Code)
8-504: SWEEPING LITTER INTO GUTTERS PROHIBITED:
No person shall sweep into or deposit in any gutter, street, or other public
place within the city the accumulation of litter from any building or lot or
from any public or private sidewalk or driveway. Persons owning or occupying
property shall keep the sidewalk in front of their premises free of litter.
(1985 Code)
8-505: MERCHANTS' DUTY TO KEEP SIDEWALKS FREE OF LITTER:
No person owning or occupying a place of business shall sweep into or deposit
in any gutter, street, or other public place within the city the accumulation
of litter from any building or lot or from any public or private sidewalk or
driveway. Persons owning or occupying places of business within the city shall
keep the sidewalk in front of their business premises free of litter. (1985
Code)
8-506: LITTER THROWN BY PERSONS IN VEHICLES:
No person, while a driver or passenger in a vehicle, shall throw or deposit
litter upon any street or other public place within the city, or upon private
property. (1985 Code)
8-507: TRUCKLOADS CAUSING LITTER:
No person shall drive or move any truck or other vehicle within the city unless
such vehicle is so constructed or loaded as to prevent any contents, or litter
from being blown or deposited upon any street, alley, or other public place.
Nor shall any person drive or move any vehicle or truck within the city, the
wheels or tires of which carry onto or deposit in any street, alley, or other
public place, mud, dirt, sticky substances, litter, or foreign matter of any
kind. (1985 Code)
8-508: LITTER IN PARKS:
   A.   No person shall throw or deposit litter in any park within the city
except in public receptacles and in such a manner that the litter will be
prevented from being carried or deposited by the elements upon any part of the
park or any street or other public place. Where public receptacles are not
provided, all such litter shall be carried away from the park by the person
responsible for its presence and properly disposed of elsewhere as provided
herein. (Ord. 1349, 4-12-1994; amd. 2015 Code)
8-509: LITTER IN LAKES AND FOUNTAINS:
   A.   No person shall throw or deposit litter in any fountain, pond, lake,
stream, bay or other body of water in a park or elsewhere within the city.
   B.   It shall be unlawful for any person(s) to deposit, throw or dispose of
rubbish, garbage, litter, refuse or other trash or materials in waste or
garbage receptacles provided on city lake properties except as herein
authorized below:
      1.   Recreational users of city lakes may dispose of materials associated
with their recreational use of the lake property;
      2.   Officials, employees and agents of the city may dispose of materials
accumulated in the course of their duties; and
      3.   Holders of cabin site leases may dispose of household trash,
garbage, rubbish, etc., associated with their use of such cabin sites. (Ord.
1349, 4-12-1994)
8-510: THROWING OR DISTRIBUTING COMMERCIAL HANDBILLS IN PUBLIC PLACES:
No person shall throw or deposit any commercial or noncommercial handbill in or
upon any sidewalk, street, or other public place within the city. Nor shall any
person hand out or distribute or sell any commercial handbill in any public
place. Provided, however, that it shall not be unlawful on any sidewalk,
street, or other public place within the city for any person to hand out or
distribute, without charge to the receiver thereof, any noncommercial handbill
to any person willing to accept it. (1985 Code)
8-511: PLACING COMMERCIAL AND NONCOMMERCIAL HANDBILLS ON VEHICLES:
No person shall throw or deposit any commercial or noncommercial handbill in or
upon any vehicle. Provided, however, that it is not unlawful in any public
place for a person to hand out or distribute without charge to the receiver
thereof, a noncommercial handbill to any occupant of a vehicle who is willing
to accept it. (1985 Code)
8-512: DEPOSITING COMMERCIAL AND NONCOMMERCIAL HANDBILLS ON UNINHABITED OR
VACANT PREMISES:
No person shall throw or deposit any commercial or noncommercial handbill in or
upon any private premises which are temporarily or continuously uninhabited or
vacant. (1985 Code)
8-513: PROHIBITING DISTRIBUTION OF HANDBILLS ON PREMISES PROPERLY POSTED:
No person shall throw, deposit or distribute any commercial or noncommercial
handbill upon any private premises, if requested by anyone thereon not to do
so, or if there is placed on the premises in a conspicuous position near the
entrance thereof, a sign bearing the words: "No Trespassing", "No Peddlers or
Agents", "No Advertisement", or any similar notice, indicating in any manner
that the occupants of the premises do not desire to be molested or have their
right of privacy disturbed or to have any such handbills left upon such
premises. (1985 Code)
8-514: DISTRIBUTING COMMERCIAL AND NONCOMMERCIAL HANDBILLS AT INHABITED PRIVATE
PREMISES:
   A.   No person shall throw, deposit, or distribute any commercial or
noncommercial handbill in or upon private premises which are inhabited, except
by handing or transmitting the handbill directly to the owner, occupant, or
other person then present in or upon such private premises. In the case of
inhabited private premises which are not posted, as provided in this chapter, a
person, unless requested by anyone upon such premises not to do so, may place
or deposit such handbill on the premises so long as the material is safeguarded
or adequately secured from being blown or drifted about such premises or
sidewalks, streets, or other public places, and except that mailboxes may not
be so used when so prohibited by federal postal law or regulations.
   B.   The provision of this section shall not apply to the distribution of
mail by the United States, nor to newspapers (as defined herein) except that
newspapers shall be placed on private property in such a manner as to prevent
their being carried or deposited by the elements upon any street, sidewalk, or
other public place, or upon private property. (1985 Code)
8-515: DROPPING LITTER FROM AIRCRAFT:
No person in an aircraft shall throw out, drop, or deposit within the city any
litter, handbill, or any other object. (1985 Code)
8-516: POSTING NOTICE PROHIBITED:
   A.   No person shall post or affix any notice, poster, or other paper or
device, calculated to attract the attention of the public, to any lamppost,
public utility pole, or upon or within any public street, alley, right of way,
or sidewalk, or any public structure or building, except as may be authorized
or required by law.
   B.   The city council at its discretion, may consider requests made by civic
organizations to relax the requirements and prohibitions addressed in
subsection A of this section. The request must be submitted to the council at
least thirty (30) days prior to a citywide event which will benefit the whole
community. The civic organization making said request must specify the name of
the event, the date of the event, its purpose and, if applicable, the event
location.
   C.   The verbal approval granted by the council will be given in open
meeting requiring a simple majority vote of the legislative body. The approval
will be granted for a single event and will not be construed as a continuing
approval for any subsequent or annual event which may occur. A civic
organization shall be deemed to be an association or society of people working
together to benefit the community and its citizens. The council shall not
consider the request of an individual or entity whose request shall be for the
benefit of a person or business. The location of placement of any notice,
poster or paper device which results from the approval of the legislative body
shall be specified at the time of approval.
   D.   This section shall not be construed to amend, alter, or modify any
other section of this code.
   E.   The requesting organization shall be responsible for removal of all
signage which was put in place as a result of the city council approval. (Ord.
1601, 6-14-2005)
8-517: LITTER ON OCCUPIED PRIVATE PROPERTY:
No person shall throw or deposit litter on any occupied private property within
the city, whether owned by such person or not, except that the owner or person
in control of private property may maintain authorized private receptacles for
collection in such a manner that litter will be prevented from being carried or
deposited by the elements upon any street, sidewalk, or other public places, or
upon any private property. (1985 Code)
8-518: OWNER TO MAINTAIN PREMISES FREE OF LITTER:
The owner or person in control of any private property shall at all times
maintain the premises free of litter. Provided, however, that this section
shall not prohibit the storage of litter in authorized private receptacles for
collection. (1985 Code)
8-519: LITTER ON VACANT LOTS:
No person shall throw or deposit litter on any open or vacant private property
within the city, whether owned by such person or not. (1985 Code)
8-520: OFFENSIVE LITTERING:
   A.   A person commits the crime of offensive littering if he creates an
objectionable stench or degrades from the natural cleanliness or safety of
property by intentionally:
      1.   Discarding or depositing any rubbish, trash, garbage, debris or
other refuse upon the land of another without permission of the owner, or upon
any public way;
      2.   Draining, or causing or permitting to be drained, sewage or the
drainage from a cesspool, septic tank, recreational or camping vehicle without
holding tank or other contaminated source, upon the land of another without
permission of the owner, or upon public way; or
      3.   Permitting any rubbish, trash, garbage, debris or other refuse to be
thrown from a vehicle which he is operating.
   B.   As used in this section, "public way" includes, but is not limited to,
roads, streets, alleys, lanes, trails, beaches, parks and all recreational
facilities operated by the state, county, or a local municipality for use by
the general public. (1985 Code)
8-521: POLITICAL ADVERTISING ON RIGHTS OF WAY:
   A.   A "political advertising sign" is defined as any sign, poster or
placard printed, painted, made, or designed for the purpose of furthering or
advertising the candidacy of any person who is or intends to become or may be a
candidate for the election to any public office, whether such public office be
in the local, state or federal government, or any subdivision thereof.
   B.   It is unlawful for any person, firm or corporation to erect or display
any advertising sign or advertising of any other character upon any public
utility easement or upon or within any public street, alley, right of way,
sidewalk, public place, public building or park.
   C.   No person, firm or corporation shall place, tack, nail, staple or glue
any advertising sign on any telephone, telegraph, electric, cable or street
lighting pole within this city.
   D.   Any advertising sign erected, placed or displayed in violation of the
provisions hereof shall be a public nuisance. No property right shall exist in
such sign erected, placed or displayed in violation of the provisions hereof
and such sign may be removed and destroyed by any person. (1985 Code)
8-522: DISPOSING OF REFUSE IN CONTAINERS BELONGING TO OTHER USERS PROHIBITED,
PENALTY:
   A.   It is unlawful for any person to deposit, throw or dispose of rubbish,
garbage, litter, refuse or other trash or materials in waste or garbage
receptacles provided to persons, firms, or corporations paying a fee to the
city or public utilities authority.
   B.   Any individual using a trash receptacle of which he or she is not the
owner, lessor, or ratepayer or named authorized user shall be guilty of an
unlawful act regardless of the location of the receptacle.
   C.   Any individual guilty of violation of this section shall be subject to
the provisions of section
8-523 of this chapter. (Ord. 1352, 7-26-1994)
8-523: PENALTY:
Any person who violates any provision of this chapter is guilty of an offense
and, upon conviction thereof, shall be punished as provided in section
1-108 of this code. (1985 Code)
CHAPTER 6
TOBACCO AND VAPOR PRODUCTS
SECTION:
8-601: Definitions
8-602: Use On City Owned Property And Buildings Is Prohibited
8-603: Penalty
8-601: DEFINITIONS:
As used in this chapter, the following terms shall have the meanings
respectively ascribed to them herein, except where the context clearly
indicates a different meaning:
CITY OWNED BUILDING: Means any building or real property owned or operated by
the City of Duncan, including the parking lot associated therewith.
CITY-OWNED PARKS AND PLAYGROUNDS: Means any parcel of open land within the City
limits which is owned by the City of Duncan and used for recreational
activities, including all pools, splash- pads, walking and bicycle trails, ball
fields, parks, skate parks, other fields or facilities used for sporting
events, or any parkland that is equipped with play structures such as swings,
climbing structures, water features or the like.
TOBACCO USE: Means any use of tobacco in any form, including, but not limited
to chewing, dipping, smoking, or burning.
VAPOR PRODUCT: Means noncombustible products, that may or may not contain
nicotine, that employ a mechanical heating element, battery, electronic
circuit, or other mechanism, regardless of shape or size, that can be used to
produce a vapor in a solution or other form. "Vapor products" shall include any
vapor cartridge or other container with or without nicotine or other form that
is intended to be used with an electronic cigarette, electronic cigar,
electronic cigarillo, electronic pipe, or similar product or device and any
vapor cartridge or other container of a solution, that may or may not contain
nicotine, that is intended to be used with or in an electronic cigarette,
electronic cigar, electronic cigarillo or electronic device. (Ord. 1775, 4-10-
2018)
8-602: USE ON CITY OWNED PROPERTY AND BUILDINGS IS PROHIBITED:
   A.   The possession of lighted tobacco in any form is a public nuisance and
dangerous to public health, as well as an unhealthy example for children. As
such, the possession of lighted tobacco in any form is prohibited when such
possession is on or in any City-owned parks and playgrounds, or City owned
building.
   B.   In addition to the prohibitions set forth in subsection A of this
section, all buildings and real property owned or operated by the City of
Duncan shall be designated as both tobacco-free and vapor-free. The use of
tobacco in any form in said buildings or on such real property is prohibited.
Furthermore, the use of vapor products in said buildings or on such real
property is also prohibited. (Ord. 1775, 4-10-2018)
8-603: PENALTY:
Any person who knowingly violates the provisions of this chapter is guilty of a
misdemeanor, and, upon conviction thereof, shall be punished by a fine of fifty
dollars ($50.00). (Ord. 1775, 4-10-2018)
PART 9
LICENSING AND BUSINESS REGULATIONS
CHAPTER 1
OCCUPATIONAL LICENSE TAX GENERALLY
SECTION:
9-101: License Tax Levied On Certain Persons
9-101: LICENSE TAX LEVIED ON CERTAIN PERSONS 1 :
   A.   A license tax is hereby levied on every person, firm, association or
corporation engaging in, exercising or pursuing any of the following
businesses, professions, trades, occupations or privileges in this city, in
such amounts as may be set by the city council by motion or resolution:
      1.   Book agents and canvassers taking orders of subscriptions;
      2.   Junk dealers;
      3.   Pawnbrokers;
      4.   Auctioneers and vendors of medicine and other goods, wares or
merchandise upon the streets:
         a.   Within the fire limits, as defined; or
         b.   Outside fire limits; (Prior code § 5-1)
      5.   Electrical, plumbing, mechanical or building contractors; and (Prior
code § 5-1; amd. 2015 Code)
      6.   House movers, only when in possession of a valid permit from the
city and appropriate state license. (Prior code § 5-1)
 
Notes
1 1. 11 OS §§ 22-106, 22-107.
CHAPTER 2
PEDDLERS, TRANSIENT MERCHANTS AND CONTRIBUTION SOLICITORS; REGULATIONS,
LICENSES AND PENALTIES
SECTION:
9-201: Permit And License Required
9-202: Definitions
9-203: Exceptions
9-204: Application, Transient Merchant's License
9-205: Application, Peddler's License
9-206: Application, Contribution Solicitation Registration
9-207: Investigation, Approval Or Disapproval
9-208: License Fees
9-209: Bond For License
9-210: Service Of Process
9-211: Period Of Validity
9-212: Transfer
9-213: Prohibited Acts
9-201: PERMIT AND LICENSE REQUIRED 1 :
It is unlawful for any person to engage in the business of "peddler",
"transient merchant" or "contribution solicitor" as defined in section
9-202 of this chapter, within the corporate limits of the city, without first
obtaining a permit and license therefor or completing registration therefor as
provided therein. (Prior code § 5-2)
 
Notes
1 1. 11 OS §§ 22-106, 22-107.
9-202: DEFINITIONS:
For the purpose of this chapter, the following terms shall have the meanings
respectively ascribed to them in this section:
CONTRIBUTION SOLICITOR: Any person, group or organization which attempts, by
request or plea, to obtain money from a person, not a member of the same group
or organization for any cause or purpose when made at other than established
place of meetings, business, service or activity of the group or organization.
PEDDLER: Door to door, street to street, place to place or temporary vendors of
sales or services without a fixed, determined and permanent location in the
city, at which he transacts his business, carries on his occupation or
practices his profession; including vendors who do not sell from stock but
exhibit samples only for the purpose of securing orders for future delivery of
sales or services.
PERSON: Any person, firm or corporation, association, club, copartnership or
society or any other organization.
TRANSIENT MERCHANT: Includes an itinerant merchant, itinerant vendor, hawker or
huckster and is defined as any person, firm or corporation whether as owner,
agent, consignee or employee whether a resident of the city or not who engages
in a temporary business of selling and delivering goods, wares or merchandise
within the city and who in furtherance of such purpose, hires, leases, uses or
occupies any building, structure or shop for the exhibition and sale of such
goods, wares and merchandise including person, firm or corporation who, while
occupying a temporary location does not sell from stock, but exhibits samples
only for the purpose of securing orders for future delivery. (Prior code § 5-2)
9-203: EXCEPTIONS:
   A.   The regulations and licensing requirements of this chapter shall not
apply to:
      1.   Any sales under court order;
      2.   A bona fide auction sale;
      3.   Traveling salespersons, commercial travelers or the like who
exclusively or primarily sell to retailers or solicit orders for future
delivery from retailers;
      4.   The sale of farm, garden, artistic or hobby products by the person
producing or creating the same;
      5.   The sale of a newspaper subscription in which the seller is a person
engaged in both the delivery and sale of the newspaper;
      6.   Sales of items at less than one dollar fifty cents ($1.50) per item;
      7.   Contribution solicitation where the person being solicited to
contribute personally knows the identity of the persons soliciting the
contribution or the name of the group or organization he represents and the
nature of the services performed or offered by the group or organization;
      8.   The seasonal sale of Christmas trees; and
      9.   The occasional sale of admission by school students to a function of
their school. (Prior code § 5-4; amd. Ord. 1431, 3-25-1997)
9-204: APPLICATION, TRANSIENT MERCHANT'S LICENSE:
   A.   Applicants for licenses for transient merchants shall file a written
application signed by the applicant, if an individual, by all partners if a
partnership and by a corporation officer if a corporation, with the city
treasurer showing:
      1.   Name and address of person or persons having the management or
supervision of the applicant's business during the time that it is proposed to
be carried on in the city; the location or address of such person or persons
when engaged in such business; the permanent address or addresses of such
person or persons; the capacity in which such person or persons will act; the
name and address of the person, firm, or corporation for whose account the
business will be carried on, if any, and if a corporation, under the laws of
what state the same is incorporated;
      2.   The place or places in the city where it is proposed to carry on
applicant's business and the length of time during which it is proposed that
the business shall be conducted;
      3.   Place or places, other than permanent place of business of the
applicant, within six (6) months next preceding the date of the application
where the applicant has conducted a transient business; and
      4.   A statement of the character of the goods, wares or merchandise to
be sold or offered for sale, by the applicant in the city, whether the same are
intended to be sold from stock in possession or from stock in possession and by
sample; such other reasonable information as to the identity or character of
the person or persons having management or supervision of applicant's business
or the method or plan of doing business as the city treasurer may deem proper
to fulfill the purpose of this chapter in the protection of the public good.
(Prior code § 5-5)
9-205: APPLICATION, PEDDLER'S LICENSE:
   A.   Applicants for a peddler's license under this chapter, whether a
person, firm or corporation, shall file with the city treasurer a written
application signed by the applicant, if an individual, by all partners, if a
partnership, or by the president if a corporation, showing:
      1.   Name and address of person or persons having the management or
supervision of the applicant's business during the time that it is proposed to
be carried on in the city; the location or address of such person or persons
when engaged in such business; the permanent address or addresses of such
person or persons, the capacity in which such person or persons will act; the
name and address of the person, firm, or corporation for whose account the
business will be carried on, if any, and if a corporation, under the laws of
what state the same is incorporated;
      2.   The place or places in the city, where it is proposed to carry on
applicant's business and the length of time during which it is proposed that
the business shall be conducted;
      3.   Place or places, other than permanent place of business of the
applicant, within six (6) months next preceding the date of the application
where the applicant has conducted a transient business; and
      4.   A statement of the character of the goods, wares or merchandise to
be sold or offered for sale by the applicant in the city, whether the same are
intended to be sold from stock in possession or from stock in possession and by
sample, such other reasonable information as to the identity or character of
the person or persons having management or supervision of applicant's business
or the method or plan of doing business as the city treasurer may deem proper
to fulfill the purpose of this chapter in the protection of the public good.
(Prior code § 5-6)
9-206: APPLICATION, CONTRIBUTION SOLICITATION REGISTRATION 1 :
   A.   A fraternal, religious, veteran or other nonprofit organization not
covered by 18 Oklahoma Statutes section 552.4 may apply for registration as a
contribution solicitor by filing with the city a written application signed by
an authorized representative of such group, showing:
      1.   The name of the organization, its purpose, its officers and
directors, period of solicitation and solicitor's form of remuneration; and
      2.   The applicant's certification that the group is one of the persons
or organizations exempt from the licensing requirements of the Oklahoma
solicitation of charitable contributions act, 18 Oklahoma Statutes sections
552.1 through 552.16. (Prior code § 5-7; amd. 2015 Code)
 
Notes
1 1. 18 OS § 552.1 et seq.
9-207: INVESTIGATION, APPROVAL OR DISAPPROVAL:
   A.   All applicants for licensing or registration shall be immediately
referred to the city treasurer and by him or other persons acting in his stead,
investigated as to the truth thereof. The city treasurer shall have ten (10)
business days within which to investigate and take action thereon.
   B.   If the city treasurer finds no past history of the applicant indicating
violations of this section and that the application is properly made and
truthful he shall forthwith advise the applicant. The city treasurer shall
issue a license, upon payment of the fee therefor and the filing of the
required bond to the approved applicant and shall approve the completion of
registration by a contribution solicitor.
   C.   In all matters of denial by the city treasurer of the license or
registration, the applicant shall be forthwith advised thereof and the
application shall be referred to the council and considered by it at its next
regular meeting. The applicant shall be afforded an opportunity to be heard at
such meeting. (Prior code § 5-8)
9-208: LICENSE FEES:
   A.   Fees for licenses granted herein shall be as set by the council from
time to time by motion or resolution:
      1.   Transient merchant's license: Annual and per day;
      2.   Peddler's license: Annual or per day. (Prior code § 5-9)
9-209: BOND FOR LICENSE:
   A.   Before any license as provided by this chapter shall be issued, such
applicant shall file with the city a bond running to the city as follows:
      1.   A person engaging in business as a transient merchant, a bond in the
sum of one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) secured by the applicant, as principal
and two (2) sureties upon whom service of process may be made in the state;
      2.   A person engaging in business as a peddler, a bond in the sum of one
thousand dollars ($1,000.00) secured by the applicant, as principal and two (2)
sureties upon whom service of process may be made in the state; and
      3.   All such bonds shall be approved by the city attorney and
conditioned that the applicant shall comply fully with all of the provisions of
the ordinances of the city, and the statutes of the state, regulating and
concerning the sale of goods, wares and merchandise and will pay all judgments
rendered against the applicant for any violation of the ordinance or statutes
or any of them, together with all judgments and costs that may be recovered
against him by any person or persons for damage growing out of any
misrepresentation or deception practiced by any person transacting such
business with such applicant, whether such misrepresentation or deception were
made or practiced by the owner or by their service, agents or employees, either
at the time of making the sale or through any advertisement of any character
whatsoever, printed or circulated with reference to the goods, wares and
merchandise sold or any part thereof. Any action on the bond may be brought in
the name of the city to the use of the aggrieved person. (Prior code § 5-10)
9-210: SERVICE OF PROCESS:
   A.   Before any license for a transient merchant or peddler as herein
provided, shall be issued, such applicant shall file with the city an
instrument nominating and appointing the city treasurer, his true and lawful
agent with full power and authority to acknowledge service of notice of process
for and on behalf of the applicant in respect to any matters connected with or
arising out of the business transaction under the license and the bond given as
required by this chapter, or for the performance of the conditions of the bond
or for any breach thereof, which the instrument shall also contain recitals to
the effect that the applicant for the license consents and agrees to service of
any notices or process applying for the license under this chapter, according
to the laws of the state or any other state and waiving all claims or right of
error by reason of such acknowledgment of service or manner of service.
   B.   Immediately upon service of process upon the city treasurer, the city
treasurer shall send to the licensee at his last known address, by registered
mail, a copy of the notice. (Prior code § 5-11)
9-211: PERIOD OF VALIDITY:
Licenses granted pursuant hereto, shall be valid for a period of one year from
the date of issuance or approval. (Prior code § 5-17)
9-212: TRANSFER:
No license shall be transferred without the consent of the city manager as
evidenced by an endorsement on the face of the license by the city treasurer
showing to whom the license is transferred and the date of the transfer. (Prior
code § 5-13; amd. 2015 Code)
9-213: PROHIBITED ACTS:
   A.   It is unlawful for any transient merchant, peddler or contribution
solicitor to engage in such business or activity for an unlawful business or
organizational purpose or activity.
   B.   It is unlawful for any transient merchant, peddler or contribution
solicitor to practice harassment, nuisance, theft, deceit or menacing,
troublesome or otherwise unlawful activities during the course of such business
or activities.
   C.   It is unlawful for any peddler or contribution solicitor to enter or
attempt to gain entrance on premises where a sign is posted with the words
"Peddlers and Solicitors Prohibited" or "Solicitors Prohibited".
   D.   It is unlawful for any peddler or contribution solicitor to refuse to
leave any premises when requested by the owner, lessee or person in charge or
possession thereof. (Prior code § 5-14)
CHAPTER 3
PAWNBROKERS
SECTION:
9-301: Definition
9-302: License Required
9-303: Bond; Conditions
9-304: Pawnbroker's Register; Contents; How Kept
9-305: Duty Of Pawnbroker To Report To Police
9-306: Register Open To Inspection
9-307: Receiving Certain Property Forbidden
9-308: Selling Pledge Before Default
9-301: DEFINITION:
Any person who loans money on deposit of personal property, or who deals in the
purchase of personal property on condition of selling the same back again at a
stipulated price, or who makes a public display of his business by a sign
generally used by pawnbrokers to denote their business, such as three (3)
yellow or gilt balls, is hereby declared to be a "pawnbroker". (Prior code § 5-
19)
9-302: LICENSE REQUIRED:
No person shall carry on or engage in the business of a pawnbroker in the city
without first having obtained a license therefor in the city. The license shall
conform to those now provided or which may hereafter be provided by this
chapter. (Prior code § 5-20)
9-303: BOND; CONDITIONS:
Every person hereafter applying for a license to engage in or carry on the
business of pawnbroker shall, before such license is issued to him, enter into
a bond with the city, with approved sureties, in the penal sum of one thousand
dollars ($1,000.00), conditioned that the applicant will strictly and
faithfully observe all ordinances, regulations and requirements of the city
relating to pawnbrokers or their businesses, and will pay all costs, fines and
penalties incurred on the account of his failure or neglect in that behalf, and
will pay all damages resulting to any person by reason of his wrongfully
taking, purchasing or receiving in pledge or on deposit any stolen property or
the property of any minor, which bond shall be filed with the city treasurer
and may be sued upon by any person damaged, as aforesaid, in the name of the
city, for the use of such person, but in no event shall the city be liable for
the cost of such suit. (Prior code § 5-21)
9-304: PAWNBROKER'S REGISTER; CONTENTS; HOW KEPT:
Every pawnbroker shall keep at his place of business a register in which he
shall enter in writing a minute description of all property taken, purchased or
received by him, including any number that may be in or upon any article,
together with the time, name and place of residence, including street and
number if within the city, of the person leaving the property, also the amount
loaned, interest charged and the time that the loan falls due, which registry
shall be kept clean and legible. He shall make such entry immediately after the
receipt or purchase of such property. Each entry shall be made in ink and shall
not in any manner be obliterated or erased. He shall give a plainly written or
printed ticket, having upon it a full and complete copy of all entries required
by ordinance to be kept in such registry to the person leaving such property.
(Prior code § 5-22)
9-305: DUTY OF PAWNBROKER TO REPORT TO POLICE:
It is the duty of every pawnbroker to make out and deliver to the chief of
police, whenever required, a legible and correct copy from the registry of all
personal property or other valuable thing received, deposited or purchased at
any time. (Prior code § 5-23)
9-306: REGISTER OPEN TO INSPECTION:
The register so kept by the pawnbroker shall be at all times kept open to
inspection by any policeman of the city or by any county or state peace
officer. The pawnbroker shall, upon request, show and exhibit to any officer
for inspection any article purchased, taken or received by him. (Prior code §
5-24)
9-307: RECEIVING CERTAIN PROPERTY FORBIDDEN:
No pawnbroker shall take or receive in pledge or on deposit any article or
property of or from a minor or owned by any minor or any common drunkard, or
person under the influence of intoxicating liquor, or narcotic drugs, or any
stolen property or property which for any reason he may have reason to believe
cannot be lawfully or rightfully pawned or pledged by the person offering it.
(Prior code § 5-25)
9-308: SELLING PLEDGE BEFORE DEFAULT:
Any pawnbroker who shall sell any article received by him in pledge before the
time for redemption has expired, and every pawnbroker who wilfully refuses to
disclose the name of the purchaser and the price received by him for any
article received by him in pledge, and subsequent sums, is guilty of an offense
and punishable as provided in section
1-108 of this code. (Prior code § 5-26)
CHAPTER 4
JUNK DEALERS
SECTION:
9-401: Licenses
9-402: Bond; Condition
9-403: Registry Of Property
9-404: Duty To Report To Police
9-405: Registry Open To Inspection
9-406: Purchases Forbidden
9-407: Junk Dealer Defined
9-408: Purchases Forbidden At Certain Hours
9-401: LICENSES 1 :
   A.   No person shall carry on or engage in business as a junk dealer, keeper
of a junk shop or dealer in secondhand goods in the city, without first
obtaining a license therefor, and a secondhand dealer shall be construed as any
person who shall purchase any kind of previously used goods.
   B.   All exhibitors at coin shows, art shows or similar type shows, where
sponsored by a local organization, and upon obtaining approval of the chief of
police of the city, are exempted from the licensing requirement of this section
and the requirement to retain property purchased for fifteen (15) days as
provided in section
9-403 of this chapter. (Prior code § 5-27)
 
Notes
1 1. 59 OS § 1501 et seq.
9-402: BOND; CONDITION:
Every person applying for a license to engage in or carry on the business of a
junk dealer, keeper of a junk shop or dealer in secondhand goods, shall, before
such license is issued, enter into an approved bond with the city in the penal
sum of one thousand dollars ($1,000.00), conditioned that the applicant will
strictly and faithfully observe all ordinances, regulations and requirements of
the city relating to the conduct of a junk shop, business of a junk dealer or
dealer in secondhand goods, and will pay all costs, fines and penalties
incurred on the account of failure or neglect in that behalf, and pay all
damages resulting to any person by reason of any wrongful taking, purchasing or
receiving of any stolen property or the property of any minor, which bond shall
be filed with the city treasurer and may be sued upon by any person damaged in
the name of the city for the use of such person, but in no event shall the city
be liable for the costs of such suit. (Prior code § 5-28)
9-403: REGISTRY OF PROPERTY:
   A.   Every junk dealer, keeper of a junk shop or dealer in secondhand goods,
shall keep at his place of business a registry in which he shall enter the
following:
      1.   The date of purchase of each item;
      2.   The name and address of the seller or transferor;
      3.   The items purchased or received;
      4.   The price paid for each item; and
      5.   The signature of the seller or transferor.
   B.   All entries shall be made in ink, and shall not in any manner be
obliterated or erased.
   C.   All persons, firms or corporations, carrying on such business, shall
keep all property purchased in their place of business within the city, in the
same condition the property was in at the time of purchase or receipt for at
least fifteen (15) days after the date of purchase or receipt of such property
and keep same available for inspection during the fifteen (15) day period
before disposing of such property. (Prior code § 5-29)
9-404: DUTY TO REPORT TO POLICE:
It is the duty of every junk dealer, keeper of a junk shop or dealer in
secondhand goods, to make out and deliver to the chief of police, upon request,
a legible and correct copy of any part or parts of the registry for any day or
days in which goods have been received or purchased; provided that no junk
dealer, keeper of a junk shop or secondhand goods shall be required to keep a
registry or furnish such description of any property purchased from any person
having an established place of business in the city, nor of goods sold at
public sale; but such goods must be accompanied by a bill of sale or other
evidence of open and legitimate purchase, and must be shown to any member of
the police department when required. (Prior code § 5-30)
9-405: REGISTRY OPEN TO INSPECTION:
Any registry so kept shall, at all times, be kept open to inspection by any
policeman of the city or by any state or county officer. The dealer shall, upon
request, show and exhibit to any officer for inspection any article purchased
by him. (Prior code § 5-31)
9-406: PURCHASES FORBIDDEN:
No junk dealer, keeper of a junk shop or dealer in secondhand goods shall
receive any article of property of or from a minor, or owned by any minor, or
from any drunkard or person who is under the influence of intoxicating liquor
or narcotic drugs, or any stolen property or any property which, for any
reason, he may believe the same cannot be lawfully or rightfully sold by the
person offering it. (Prior code § 5-32)
9-407: JUNK DEALER DEFINED:
Any person who shall carry on the business of buying secondhand brass, copper,
iron, precious metals, precious stones, jewelry, leather belting, plumbing or
electrical fixtures, burlap bags, tools, machinery or materials or supplies
commonly used in the drilling, completing, operating or repairing of oil and
gas wells, is hereby defined as a "junk dealer". (Prior code § 5-33)
9-408: PURCHASES FORBIDDEN AT CERTAIN HOURS:
No junk dealer, keeper of a junk shop or dealer in secondhand goods shall take
or receive from any persons any articles of property between the hours of nine
o'clock (9:00) P.M. and six o'clock (6:00) A.M. (Prior code § 5-34)
CHAPTER 5
RECREATION CENTERS
SECTION:
9-501: Recreation Centers Defined
9-502: License Required
9-503: License Requirements
9-504: Restrictions On Location Of And Operation Of Recreation Centers
9-505: Suspension Or Revocation Of License
9-501: RECREATION CENTERS DEFINED:
   A.   For purposes of this chapter a recreation center shall be any place,
business or premises which maintains more than one pool table, snooker table or
billiard table or one or more electronic or video games, pinball machines,
table games or other similar services, provided that the following shall not be
considered recreation centers:
      1.   Private homes;
      2.   Duly licensed bottle clubs, taverns, bars and dance hall;
      3.   Churches and church recreation or activity centers;
      4.   Businesses maintaining either:
         a.   Not more than one table for pool, snooker or billiards;
         b.   Not more than five (5) or a combination of not more than five (5)
of any of the following: electronic or video games, pinball machines, table
games or similar amusement games or devices; or
         c.   Provided that the tables, games, machines or devices occupy a
floor space equivalent to less than five percent (5%) of the maximum occupancy
of the business, as established by the building code of the city. (Prior code §
5-35)
9-502: LICENSE REQUIRED:
It is unlawful for any person, firm, corporation, partnership or association to
operate or maintain a "recreation center" as defined in section
9-501 of this chapter without a valid annual license therefor issued by the
city treasurer of the city. (Prior code § 5-36)
9-503: LICENSE REQUIREMENTS:
   A.   Application for an annual license shall be made on forms provided by
the clerk of the city.
   B.   Licenses shall be issued on an annual basis and shall expire on April
30 of the year for which it is issued.
   C.   The annual fee for the license for the operation of a recreation center
shall be as set by the city council by motion or resolution, payable upon the
issuance of the annual license.
   D.   Holders of recreation center licenses shall conspicuously display such
licenses on the premises of the licensed recreation center. (Prior code § 5-37)
9-504: RESTRICTIONS ON LOCATION OF AND OPERATION OF RECREATION CENTERS:
   A.   It is unlawful for any person, firm, partnership or association to:
      1.   Operate a recreation center at any location in violation of the
city's zoning ordinance or the constitution and laws of the state;
      2.   Operate a recreation center between the hours of twelve o'clock (12:
00) midnight and seven o'clock (7:00) A.M.; provided, however, that upon the
close of business on Saturday, no recreation center shall open before one
o'clock (1:00) P.M. on the following Sunday;
      3.   Permit any intoxicated person whether by alcohol, drugs or other
substances to be in or about the premises; and
      4.   Sell, barter, give away or permit the consumption of alcoholic
beverages or beer in or about the premises of such recreation center. (Prior
code § 5-38)
9-505: SUSPENSION OR REVOCATION OF LICENSE:
   A.   All complaints concerning recreation centers shall be submitted to the
chief of police for investigation. If the chief of police finds that a
violation of the provisions of this chapter has been committed, he shall file a
complaint with the city, setting forth the alleged acts constituting the
violation. Upon the filing of such a complaint, the city shall fix a date for
hearing of the complaint by the council of the city, and shall cause to be
served upon the licensee a copy of the complaint and notice of the time and
place of the hearing. The complaint and notice of hearing may be served upon
the manager, operator, partner or person shown on the application for the
license as having supervisory control over the premises of the recreation
center or if such person may not be found, by mailing the same by registered or
certified mail addressed to such person at the licensed premises. At the
hearing thereon, the complainant, the licensee or any interested person may be
present and present such evidence as may be relevant and material. If at the
conclusion of such hearing, the city council finds that the licensee has
violated any of the provisions of this chapter, the city council shall suspend
for not more than fifteen (15) days or revoke the license issued hereunder.
Upon suspension or revocation, the licensee shall immediately cease operating
as a recreation center.
   B.   Following the revocation of any recreation center license, an
application for a license as a recreation center upon the same premises shall
not be accepted by the city treasurer for a period of thirty (30) days
following the revocation. (Prior code § 5-39)
CHAPTER 6
COIN OPERATED AMUSEMENT DEVICES
SECTION:
9-601: Definitions
9-602: License Fee
9-603: Application For License
9-604: Display Of License
9-605: Prohibited Devices Not Legalized
9-601: DEFINITIONS:
   A.   The following words and phrases when used in this chapter shall have
the following meaning:
    COIN OPERATED AMUSEMENT DEVICES: Any and all mechanical devices which upon
the payment or insertion of a coin, script, token or similar object which
causes, permits or is incentive for, the propelling or motivating of any ball,
marble, electronic simulation or other gadget or object that produces or
creates or makes possible the production or creation of a game of skill,
amusement, entertainment or test of strength including, but not limited to,
shuffleboards, coin operated devices utilizing tables, boards or cases of any
size whatsoever, balls, sticks, cues, pegs or marbles; and whether or not any
motivating force involved is furnished by the player or the device.
   POOL, BILLIARD OR SNOOKER TABLE: Any table specifically manufactured for the
purpose of playing pool, billiards or snooker, whether or not the tables are
coin operated.
   B.   "Coin operated amusement devices" as defined herein shall not include
coin operated machines operated by penny coins only; or coin operated vending
machines used exclusively for the purpose of selling tangible, personal
property, such as cold drinks, tobacco products, candies, postage stamps or
other similar merchandise; or services such as pay telephones, parking meters,
gas or electric meters or other distribution of needful services. (Prior code §
5-40)
9-602: LICENSE FEE:
   A.   Every person who owns and has available to the public, or who permits
to be operated by the public in or on his place of business any coin operated
amusement devices, pool tables, billiard tables or snooker tables, shall pay
for an annual license for each such device.
   B.   There is levied an annual license fee on each amusement device in such
sum as set by the city council by motion or resolution.
   C.   The term public as used herein shall not include churches and church
recreation or activity centers. (Prior code § 5-41)
9-603: APPLICATION FOR LICENSE:
   A.   Application for an annual license on such devices shall be made to the
treasurer.
   B.   The application form shall contain the name of the applicant, a
description of the device, location of the device and such other information
deemed necessary by the treasurer to identify the device.
   C.   Any number of machines may be included in one application.
   D.   Upon payment of the license fee and approval of the application, the
treasurer shall issue a license for the device or devices covered by the
application. (Prior code § 5-42)
9-604: DISPLAY OF LICENSE:
Before any coin operated amusement device, pool table or snooker table is put
into operation or placed where the same may be operated by the public, and at
all times when the same is being operated, or is available to the public for
operation, a license, issued by the city, shall be firmly affixed to the device
covered thereby and plainly visible to and readable by the public. (Prior code
§ 5-43)
9-605: PROHIBITED DEVICES NOT LEGALIZED:
Nothing in this chapter shall be construed to legalize any device that may be
prohibited by the laws of this state or the ordinances of the city. The
treasurer may assume that any device described in any application, and for
which a license fee is paid, is lawful; and no claim for a refund of any
license fee will be entertained based upon an owner's or operator's inability
to operate such devices because of any law of this state or city or for any
other reason. (Prior code § 5-44)
CHAPTER 7
PRIVATE SECURITY OFFICERS, REGULATIONS
SECTION:
9-701: Purpose
9-702: Definitions
9-703: Issuance Of Commissions And Permits
9-704: Application
9-705: Contents
9-706: Physical Examination
9-707: Investigation, Interview, Ineligibility For Commission
9-708: Bond Requirements
9-709: Appointment; Action On Application; Temporary Commission
9-710: Orientation
9-711: Annual Application Required For Commissions And Permits
9-712: Changes In Service Areas; Processing Fee; Discontinuance Of Service
9-713: Badge And Uniform
9-714: Time And Place Of Permanent Security Service
9-715: Service Restricted To Authorized Area
9-716: Authority To Arrest
9-717: Rules And Regulations
9-718: Suspension, Revocation Or Inquiry Regarding Commission Or Permit; Public
Hearing
9-719: Nonliability Of The City
9-701: PURPOSE:
The purpose of this chapter is to preserve the public health, safety, morals
and general welfare by regulation and control of the business of private
security officers. (Prior code § 5-51)
9-702: DEFINITIONS:
The following words and phrases, when used herein, shall have the following
meaning:
BUSINESS DAY: Monday through Friday inclusive, but excluding holidays.
GUARD SERVICE: Stationary armed guards serving private citizens at a particular
and specified place or location.
PATROL SERVICE: A motorized armed patrol serving private citizens or companies
in a specified geographical area, which area shall be established by naming the
streets forming the exterior boundaries of the area served.
PERMANENT SECURITY SERVICE: Regularly armed schedule service furnished hourly,
daily, weekly, monthly or for any other period at a specified area, place or
location.
PRIVATE SECURITY COMPANIES: Any organization or person offering services as an
independent contractor and employing armed private security officers who are
commissioned under the provisions of this chapter. A one man operation shall
not be considered a private security company.
PRIVATE SECURITY OFFICER: Any officer commissioned to provide patrol or guard
service as an independent contractor and who shall be authorized to carry
firearms under the provision of this chapter.
TEMPORARY SECURITY SERVICE: Service not offered on a regularly armed scheduled
basis. (Prior code § 5-52)
9-703: ISSUANCE OF COMMISSIONS AND PERMITS:
The chief of police, subject to the provisions of this chapter, is hereby
authorized to grant commissions to private officers and permits to private
security companies. (Prior code § 5-53)
9-704: APPLICATION:
   A.   To apply for a commission:
      1.   Each person applying for appointment for commission shall make a
written application on forms provided by the chief of police; and
      2.   A processing fee as set by the council shall be charged for each
application and for each annual renewal.
   B.   To apply for a permit:
      1.   Each private security company applying for a permit shall make a
written application on forms provided by the chief of police; and
      2.   A processing fee as set by the council shall be charged for each
application and for each annual renewal. (Prior code § 5-54)
9-705: CONTENTS:
   A.   Applications for commissions or permits shall contain the following
information:
      1.   Private security officer commission for guard service:
         a.   Company, if any, employing the applicant;
         b.   A standard personal history statement completed on a form
provided by the chief of police; and
         c.   Such other and additional information deemed necessary by the
chief of police or city manager;
      2.   Private security company permit for guard service:
         a.   Names of the officers, principals or resident manager of the
company;
         b.   A standard personal history, and statement completed on a form
provided by the chief of police; and
         c.   Such other and additional information deemed necessary by the
chief of police or city manager relating to those persons;
      3.   Private security officer commission for patrol service:
         a.   The specific places or area where services would be rendered;
         b.   Hours of the day when services would be rendered if the applicant
is self-employed;
         c.   The company, if any, employing the applicant;
         d.   A standard personal history statement completed on a form
provided by the chief of police; and
         e.   Such other and additional information deemed necessary by the
chief of police or city manager; and
      4.   Private security company permit for patrol service:
         a.   The names of the officers, principals or resident manager of the
company;
         b.   A standard personal history statement completed on a form
provided by the chief of police; and
         c.   The specific area of properties where the service would be
furnished, and the hours of the day that service would be furnished. (Prior
code § 5-55)
9-706: PHYSICAL EXAMINATION:
After application for commission is filed, the applicant shall submit a report
from a duly licensed physician, of a physical examination taken within one
year. (Prior code § 5-56)
9-707: INVESTIGATION, INTERVIEW, INELIGIBILITY FOR COMMISSION:
   A.   Prior to the issuance of a commission, the police department shall
conduct a complete background inquiry of the applicant, and the applicant shall
be personally interviewed by the chief of police or his representative and the
applicant's photograph and fingerprints shall be obtained.
   B.   Each applicant will be interviewed as to his ability to safely handle
firearms.
   C.   The chief of police shall refuse commissions to all persons who have
been convicted of a felony under the laws of the state or of any other state,
or of the United States, or any offense involving moral turpitude, and to all
minors, drug addicts, unnaturalized foreign born persons, and such other
persons as he has reasonable cause to believe are not of sound mind. (Prior
code § 5-57)
9-708: BOND REQUIREMENTS:
   A.   Prior to the issuance of a commission each individual applicant shall
file with the city a surety bond or certificate of insurance of general
liability in the amount of ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00) written by a duly
qualified bonding or insurance company licensed to do business in the state.
   B.   Prior to the issuance of a permit each company applicant may file a
bond or certificate of insurance in the amount of one hundred thousand dollars
($100,000.00) in lieu of the individual bonds of its employees.
   C.   The bond or certificate of insurance shall be renewed and filed
annually with the application for renewal of the commission or permit.
   D.   The requirements of this section are satisfied if a copy of the general
liability bond or certificate of insurance is on file with the state. (Prior
code § 5-58)
9-709: APPOINTMENT; ACTION ON APPLICATION; TEMPORARY COMMISSION:
   A.   If the chief of police, subject to the requirements of this chapter and
approval of the city manager, finds the applicant eligible for a commission,
the applicant shall be appointed as a private officer to service in accordance
with the provisions of this chapter.
   B.   The chief of police shall act on all applications within fifteen (15)
business days from the time of the filing of the applications.
   C.   Pending action by the chief of police on applications, a temporary
commission may be issued in a case where the delay in granting it would cause
undue hardship on the applicant. (Prior code § 5-59)
9-710: ORIENTATION:
A commissioned private officer shall attend those classes of orientation
reasonably appropriate to his service to be rendered as designated by the chief
of police and given as directed by the chief of police. (Prior code § 5-60)
9-711: ANNUAL APPLICATION REQUIRED FOR COMMISSIONS AND PERMITS:
Reapplication shall be made annually for each commission and permit. The
application for renewal need not be reprocessed but shall be filed with the
chief of police by June 15. Unless the applications are received by June 30,
the commission or permit shall be terminated without further action on July 1.
(Prior code § 5-61)
9-712: CHANGES IN SERVICE AREAS; PROCESSING FEE; DISCONTINUANCE OF SERVICE:
   A.   Application for approval and the payment of a processing fee as set by
the council shall be required:
      1.   Before a private security officer or company performing patrol
service may service additional areas;
      2.   Before a private security officer or company performing guard
service may furnish permanent security service at an additional area; and
      3.   Before a private security officer or company shall furnish temporary
security service at an additional area.
   B.   When permanent service is discontinued in an area or at a location,
written notification shall be sent to the chief of police. (Prior code § 5-62)
9-713: BADGE AND UNIFORM:
A duly commissioned private officer when on duty shall have on his person his
commission and shall wear uniform, badge or other emblems of authority as
approved by the chief of police, which shall in any event be clearly
distinctive and different from that of regular city police officers and shall
designate the officer as private officer, security officer, or security
service. (Prior code § 5-63)
9-714: TIME AND PLACE OF PERMANENT SECURITY SERVICE:
The chief of police, with the approval of the city manager, shall designate the
specific place or area and hours of the day that each private officer or
company may furnish permanent security patrol service. (Prior code § 5-64)
9-715: SERVICE RESTRICTED TO AUTHORIZED AREA:
Duly commissioned private officers or private security companies shall at all
times service only the place or specifically defined geographical area where
they are authorized to serve under the provisions of this chapter. (Prior code
§ 5-65)
9-716: AUTHORITY TO ARREST:
A duly commissioned private officer is not a member of the police department
and shall not have the authority of a police officer. He shall, while on duty
at his assigned place, have the right to carry a pistol or revolver and make
arrests only as a private citizen is granted authority by Oklahoma Statutes.
(Prior code § 5-66)
9-717: RULES AND REGULATIONS:
The chief of police shall promulgate and publish, with the approval of the city
manager and council, those additional rules and regulations consistent with
this chapter and as may be necessary to its implementation. Copies shall be
furnished applicants upon request. (Prior code § 5-67)
9-718: SUSPENSION, REVOCATION OR INQUIRY REGARDING COMMISSION OR PERMIT; PUBLIC
HEARING:
   A.   The commission of any private security officer or permit of any private
security company may be suspended or revoked at any time by the chief of police
for violation of any of the requirements necessary for a commission or permit
or for violation of any rule or regulation established pursuant to this chapter
or during pendency of inquiry into the discharge of a firearm.
   B.   Upon a violation occurring, the chief of police or his representative
shall give the private security officer or private security company notice of
any suspension or revocation hearing at least five (5) days prior to the date
of public hearing, and such notice shall be furnished by mail. The suspension
or revocation hearings will be conducted by a three (3) member board consisting
of:
      1.   The chief of police or his representative;
      2.   The city manager or his representative; and
      3.   The city attorney. (Prior code § 5-68)
9-719: NONLIABILITY OF THE CITY:
Any commissioned private officer, while in the performance of his duties as a
private officer, shall not be deemed to be an agent, servant or employee of the
city and the city shall not be liable for his actions to third parties or for
any injury or damage he might suffer. (Prior code § 5-57)
CHAPTER 8
PRIVATE INVESTIGATORS
SECTION:
9-801: Definitions
9-802: Exemptions
9-803: License Required
9-804: Application For License
9-805: Investigation Of Fingerprints By Chief Of Police
9-806: Standards For Issuance Of License
9-807: Action On Application
9-808: License Fee
9-809: Employees
9-810: Identification Cards
9-811: Conditions Of Licensing
9-812: Appeal From Action By City Treasurer
9-813: Action To Revoke Or Suspend License
9-814: Conduct Of Committee Hearings
9-815: Appeal Procedure
9-816: Composition Of The Private Investigator's Review Committee
9-801: DEFINITIONS:
The following words and phrases when used herein shall have the following
meaning:
ASSISTANT PRIVATE INVESTIGATOR: Any person not eligible for a private
investigator's license but who is engaged in the business of private
investigator under the direct supervision and control of a licensee hereunder.
BUSINESS OF PRIVATE INVESTIGATOR: Shall consist of the business of making, for
hire or reward or any consideration whatsoever, an investigation or
investigations by a person or persons for the purpose of obtaining information
with reference to any of the following matters:
   A.   Private or public crimes;
   B.   Credibility of witnesses or other persons;
   C.   Habits, conduct, movements, associations, transactions, reputation or
character of persons;
   D.   The location or recovery of lost or stolen property;
   E.   Securing of evidence to be used before investigating committees, boards
of award or arbitration or in the trial of civil or criminal cases and
proceedings;
   F.   Wrongs to persons or property done or threatened; or
   G.   Causes, origin or responsibility for fires or accidents or injuries to
real or personal property, strikes or labor disputes.
COMMITTEE: The city private investigator's review committee. (Prior code § 5-
70)
9-802: EXEMPTIONS:
The provisions of this chapter shall not apply to any investigator or officer
belonging to the police force of the federal, state, county, or city government
appointed or elected by due authority of law while engaged in the performance
of his official duties; nor to any given person in the employ of the police
force or police department of the state or of the county or city while engaged
in the performance of his official duties; nor to any attorneys at law or legal
interns in the regular practice of their profession; nor any person, firm or
corporation legally and solely employed as insurance adjusters who engage in
investigative activities connected only with adjustment of claims against an
insurance company; nor any person, firm or corporation whose sole business is
the furnishing of information as to the business and financial standing and
credit of persons, firms, or corporation; nor to any person making any
investigation of any matter in which such person or his sole employer is
involved or interested; nor to any investigator employed exclusively for one
employer in connection with the business of a collection agency; nor to any
person employed exclusively by private investigators for secretarial purposes;
nor to any person or persons employed for, or in the business of furnishing for
hire or reward, guard or guards, watchman or watchmen, patrolman or patrolmen,
or other persons to protect or to prevent the theft or the unlawful taking of
goods, wares and merchandise. (Prior code § 5-71)
9-803: LICENSE REQUIRED:
No person shall operate, advertise or otherwise hold himself out as a private
investigator in the city without first obtaining a license as hereinafter
provided from the city treasurer or his designee. (Prior code § 5-72)
9-804: APPLICATION FOR LICENSE:
   A.   Application for license issued hereunder shall be made upon blank forms
prepared and made available by the city treasurer or his designee, and shall
state:
      1.   The full name, age, residence, telephone number and present and
previous employment record of the applicant;
      2.   Applicant's citizenship;
      3.   The firm name and specific location of the place of business of
applicant;
      4.   Number of years' experience applicant has had as a private
detective, or in related fields;
      5.   Length of time applicant has been a bona fide resident of the state
immediately preceding the filing of the application;
      6.   Summary of military service, including date thereof and whether or
not applicant was honorably discharged;
      7.   All convictions of applicant for felonies and misdemeanors involving
moral turpitude;
      8.   Place and date of birth;
      9.   Affidavits from at least three (3) persons who have personally known
the applicant for a period of at least three (3) years prior to the filing of
such application, as to the moral character of the applicant; provided such
persons be not related to the applicant by blood or marriage; and
      10.   Affidavits from those who can personally attest to the applicant's
experience during specific time periods in the business of private investigator
or as assistant private investigator, sufficient when added together, to
establish that the applicant has met the minimum standards for issuance of
license.
   B.   The application required hereunder shall be accompanied by a full set
of fingerprints and a recent photograph and shall be verified by the applicant.
   C.   The application required shall be accompanied by an application fee as
set by the council. (Prior code § 5-73)
9-805: INVESTIGATION OF FINGERPRINTS BY CHIEF OF POLICE:
Within ten (10) days after receipt of an application as provided for herein,
the chief of police shall cause such fingerprints of known criminals made, and
if any record is found affecting such prints, the chief of police shall
immediately notify the city treasurer. (Prior code § 5-74)
9-806: STANDARDS FOR ISSUANCE OF LICENSE:
   A.   The city treasurer shall issue a license hereunder when he finds:
      1.   That the applicant has complied fully with the provisions pertaining
to the application for license;
      2.   That the applicant has never been convicted of any felony or any
misdemeanor involving moral turpitude as determined by the chief of police;
      3.   That the applicant is a citizen of the United States Of America, or,
if not a citizen, submits proof that he is an alien lawfully admitted within
the country;
      4.   That the applicant is at least twenty one (21) years of age;
      5.   That the applicant has not been discharged from the armed services
of the United States under other than honorable conditions; and
      6.   That the applicant has at least two thousand (2,000) hours'
experience engaged in the business of private investigator or as assistant
private investigator. For the purpose of this section, the applicant may have
gained such experience in the business of private investigator while in the
employ of any branch of federal, state, county, or city government.
   B.   The standards herein set forth shall be exclusive and no additional
requirements can be imposed except by amendment of this chapter. (Prior code §
5-75)
9-807: ACTION ON APPLICATION:
   A.   The city treasurer shall act upon the application within thirty (30)
days after receiving same. If all application requirements are met, a license
shall be issued to the successful applicant upon the payment of a license fee
as herein provided.
   B.   If the city treasurer disapproves or denies the application, he shall
notify the applicant in writing within ten (10) days thereafter, giving
specific reasons for the disapproval or denial.
   C.   Any applicant aggrieved shall have the right of appeal, after notice to
the committee as herein provided. (Prior code § 5-76)
9-808: LICENSE FEE:
A license fee as set by the city council by motion or resolution shall be paid
to the city annually by all persons licensed hereunder. (Prior code § 5-77)
9-809: EMPLOYEES:
   A.   The licensed private investigator may employ, to assist him in the
business of private investigator, as many persons as he shall deem necessary
pursuant to the following conditions:
      1.   The licensee shall at all times accept full responsibility for the
conduct in the business of each and every person so employed;
      2.   The licensee shall be responsible to see that all such employees
meet the requirements of subsections 9-806A2 through A5 of this chapter;
      3.   Within ten (10) days after employment of an assistant private
investigator, the licensed private investigator by whom such person has been
employed shall cause an employee registration form provided by the city
treasurer to be filed with the city treasurer upon payment of a registration
fee as set by the council;
      4.   The chief of police shall issue a photo identification card to the
employee pursuant to the regulation providing for identification cards; and
      5.   The employee's status as assistant private investigator
automatically terminates upon the expiration, revocation or suspension of the
responsible employer/private investigator. It is the duty of the private
investigator to surrender the employee's identification card when made
necessary by this provision. (Prior code § 5-78)
9-810: IDENTIFICATION CARDS:
   A.   The chief of police shall issue a photo identification to an applicant
for a private investigator's license upon determination that the application
has been approved by the city treasurer and that the license fee has been paid.
Such card shall state the name of the applicant, the name of the applicant's
business firm, the words "Private Investigator", and the expiration date of the
license.
   B.   The chief of police shall issue a photo identification card to an
assistant private investigator upon determination that the appropriate
registration fee has been paid and that the employee has not been convicted of
a felony or any misdemeanor involving moral turpitude after having compared the
employee's fingerprints with those of known criminals. Such card shall state
the name of the employee, the words "Assistant Private Investigator employed
by", and the name of the employee's business firm. (Prior code § 5-79)
9-811: CONDITIONS OF LICENSING:
   A.   Licenses issued hereunder shall not be transferable. In addition, a
licensee who changes business firms must notify the city treasurer in writing
within seven (7) days of the effective date of such change. At the same time,
the licensee shall turn in his identification card and those of any assistant
private investigators employed by him, and upon paying a five dollar ($5.00)
processing charge for each new card desired, shall be issued a new photo
identification card or cards identical in all respects except for the change in
the business firm name.
   B.   The city treasurer shall issue renewal licenses to all licensees whose
licenses have not been suspended or revoked at the time the licenses have
expired, and for ninety (90) days thereafter, upon payment of the license fee.
   C.   All licenses issued hereunder shall expire on June 30 of each year.
   D.   The private investigator's review committee may, after hearing, suspend
for definite periods of time, or revoke a license, or refuse a license issued
under this chapter:
      1.   If such licensee has knowingly violated any of the provisions of
this chapter;
      2.   If the licensee has knowingly made a false report in writing to his
client or other person entitled to receive such information, in respect to any
of the matters for which the licensee may be employed;
      3.   If the licensee, during his employment by the client, shall accept
money or gratuities from any person whose affairs he may have been employed by
such client to investigate;
      4.   If the licensee has knowingly or wrongfully divulged to any person
other than his client or employer, except as his client or employer shall
direct and except as may be required by law, any information acquired by him
during such employment, with respect to any of the work to which he, or any
other employee of such licensee, shall have been assigned by the licensee, or
with respect to any of the work, business, or affairs of the trustee;
      5.   If the licensee has, knowingly or wilfully, falsely stated or
represented any matter of information contained as a part of an application for
license hereunder;
      6.   If the licensee wilfully fails or refuses to render to a client
services or a report as agreed between the parties for which compensation has
been paid or tendered in accordance with the written agreement of the parties;
      7.   If such licensee wilfully fails or refuses to return to a client the
unused portion of a retainer or compensation which has been paid or tendered,
in accordance with the written agreement of the parties;
      8.   If the licensee is convicted of a felony or a misdemeanor involving
moral turpitude;
      9.   If the licensee has practiced any fraud, deceit or intentional
misrepresentation; and
      10.   If an employee of a licensee has committed any of the
aforementioned acts at the direction and with the knowledge of the licensee.
   E.   Identification cards issued hereunder shall remain the property of the
city and shall be surrendered by the licensee to the city treasurer upon
expiration, revocation or suspension of a license. (Prior code § 5-80)
9-812: APPEAL FROM ACTION BY CITY TREASURER:
Appeals from any action of the city treasurer may be taken by the person
aggrieved to the committee by filing within thirty (30) days of the receipt of
notice of such action a written notice of appeal with the chairman of the
committee stating the grounds for appeal. Upon receipt of such notice of appeal
the committee shall, within twenty (20) days thereafter, hold a public hearing
thereon. At the conclusion of such hearing, the committee shall affirm, modify
or reverse the action taken by the city treasurer. (Prior code § 5-81)
9-813: ACTION TO REVOKE OR SUSPEND LICENSE:
   A.   The committee shall, upon receipt by the committee chairman of a
verified written complaint of any person setting forth facts which, if proven,
would constitute grounds for revocation or suspension of a license as set forth
herein, cause an inquiry to be made of all information presented for its
consideration. Only upon completion of the inquiry where a majority of the
committee then present and voting are satisfied that the inquiry reveals
reasonable grounds to proceed, will a hearing be conducted.
   B.   The committee shall cause notice to the licensee of the following prior
to concluding the inquiry:
      1.   That information has been presented to the committee that the
licensee has allegedly committed an act or acts which may amount to grounds for
revocation or suspension;
      2.   That the committee will conduct an inquiry designed to ascertain the
basis of such information;
      3.   That the licensee will be afforded an opportunity to be heard before
the committee; and
      4.   That if the inquiry reveals reasonable grounds to conduct a hearing,
the procedures outlined herein shall apply.
   C.   After inquiry and a determination by the committee that a hearing
should be conducted, the committee shall schedule a hearing on a date certain
wherein the licensee shall have been given not less than fourteen (14) days',
nor more than twenty eight (28) days', advance notice of the date of the
hearing.
   D.   Notice of the licensee required herein shall consist of the following:
      1.   Notification that the committee is in receipt of information that
the licensee is alleged to have committed an act or acts which may be grounds
for revocation or suspension;
      2.   That the committee on its own inquiry has reasonable belief that the
act or acts of the theretofore presented information have occurred;
      3.   That the committee has scheduled a fact finding hearing, on a date
from fourteen (14) to twenty eight (28) days from the notice, to ascertain the
full facts surrounding the information; and
      4.   That the licensee has full right of appearance and representation
before the committee on the date as specified.
   E.   Any notice required herein shall be in writing and may be served by
delivery of the notice personally to the licensee or by mailing the notice by
registered mail to the place of business last theretofore specified by such
licensee in his last communication with the committee.
   F.   Upon good cause shown, the committee may continue for up to fourteen
(14) days the hearing as scheduled.
   G.   The committee shall, after full consideration, notify the licensee and
the city treasurer in writing of its decision and the reasons therefor within
fourteen (14) days from the date the decision was rendered. (Prior code § 5-82)
9-814: CONDUCT OF COMMITTEE HEARINGS:
All hearings before the committee as required herein shall be held as scheduled
before a majority of the committee members and be of a fact finding nature and
will not be adversarial in scope or in nature. Strict legal rules of evidence
shall not be followed for the reason that the proceedings before the committee
shall be to ascertain all facts surrounding the matter before the committee,
matters of an irrelevant or immaterial nature excepted. (Prior code § 5-83)
9-815: APPEAL PROCEDURE:
Any person aggrieved by the committee's decision to deny, revoke or suspend a
private investigator's license shall have the right to appeal to the district
court. (Prior code § 5-84)
9-816: COMPOSITION OF THE PRIVATE INVESTIGATOR'S REVIEW COMMITTEE:
