12-1018: Methods And Calculations
12-1019: Enforcement And Penalty
12-1001: PURPOSE AND INTENT:
It is the purpose of this chapter to set forth the minimum requirements for
drainage system improvements and erosion control within the city and to
establish the public and private responsibilities for the provision thereof.
(Ord. 1387, 1-30-1996)
12-1002: DEFINITIONS:
The definition of terms set forth in this chapter shall be given the meaning
indicated below unless the context clearly requires a different meaning:
BASE FLOOD OR BASE STORM: The flood or storm having a one percent (1%) chance
of being equaled or exceeded in any given year, also being defined as having a
return frequency of one hundred (100) years.
DEVELOPER: Any person, persons, corporation, or other entity who in his or her
own behalf, or as an agent of another, engages in development, subdivision,
construction of structures, or alteration of land in preparation for
development, subdivision or construction.
DEVELOPMENT: Any alteration of land for the purpose of achieving its
development, subdivision or change in use, including any preparation for
building of or erection of a structure or installation of paved surfaces,
grading, fill or other change in existing land contours.
DRAINAGE SYSTEM: The surface and subsurface system for the removal of water
from the land, including both the natural elements of streams, marshes, swales,
and ponds, whether of an intermittent or continuous nature, and manmade
elements which include culverts, ditches, channels, creeks, retention
facilities, detention facilities, gutters, streets, and storm sewer systems.
ENGINEER: A licensed professional engineer registered in the state or a
reciprocating state as recognized by the Oklahoma board of registration for
professional engineers and land surveyors.
MINOR MAINTENANCE: Any activity for the maintenance of a drainage system
specifically excluding repair or replacement of paved channel liners,
replacement of revetments or riprap, or replacement of soil lost due to
meandering of a channel. Minor maintenance includes, but is not limited to,
mowing, replacement of vegetation, and filling of erosion gullies.
NATURAL DRAINAGE: The dispersal of surface waters through ground absorption and
by drainage channels formed by the existing surface topography which exist as
of January 30, 1996, or formed by any natural or approved manmade changes in
the surface topography. (Ord. 1387, 1-30-1996)
12-1003: APPLICATION:
All subdivisions of land, developments or improvements to any land in the
corporate limits of the city as now and as may be hereafter established shall
be subject to the provisions of this chapter except as specifically exempt in
accordance with section
12-1006 of this chapter. (Ord. 1387, 1-30-1996)
12-1004: APPEALS:
If any determination based upon the provisions of this chapter is felt to be
unreasonable or inapplicable, a developer or property owner may appeal such
determination to the planning commission. Upon written request for the appeal
which shall include all justifications and reasons for that appeal, the
question will be heard at the next available meeting of the planning
commission. The report and recommendations of the commission shall then be
forwarded to the city council which may act to approve, deny or conditionally
approve the appeal. (Ord. 1387, 1-30-1996)
12-1005: WARNING AND DISCLAIMER:
The provisions of this chapter are considered reasonable and appropriate for
regulatory purposes with respect to provision of stormwater and drainage system
improvements. This does not imply that compliance with the provisions herein
shall relieve any person or persons of any duty or responsibility imposed by
law. Neither shall this chapter create liability on the part of the city or any
officer or employee thereof for any flood damages that result from reliance on
this chapter or any administrative decision lawfully made thereunder. (Ord.
1387, 1-30-1996)
12-1006: EXEMPTIONS:
   A.   The following activities are specifically exempted from the
requirements of this chapter:
      1.   Home gardening or other minor clearing or excavation work not
incident to a change in the use of the land;
      2.   Emergency repairs necessary for the preservation of life, health or
property;
      3.   Routine maintenance or repair work on public or private roads and
rights of way or utility easements and rights of way; or
      4.   Construction of, or additions to, single-family, two-family and
accessory residential buildings, provided there is no encroachment upon
drainage easements or modification of approved drainage system elements and
construction is elevated or floodproofed in accordance with the terms of this
chapter. (Ord. 1387, 1-30-1996)
12-1007: RESPONSIBILITIES OF DEVELOPERS:
   A.   It shall be the responsibility of any developer to:
      1.   Provide drainage system improvements, easements and rights of way
dedications in accordance with the provisions of this chapter;
      2.   Prepare all drawings, plans, specifications, statements, studies,
justifications, and other data required by this chapter in a form that permits
an orderly and comprehensive review and approval to assure that all assigned
responsibilities have been sufficiently and correctly incorporated;
      3.   Prevent soil dispersal, sedimentation, erosion, or other similar
forms of pollution from any surface on the site during development activities
in accordance with the provisions of this chapter;
      4.   Prevent any and all drainage interferences, obstructions or other
adverse effects upon drainage into, through or adjacent to the development from
upstream or higher elevation source by the use of temporary or permanent bypass
channels, channel improvements or other facilities as may be required; and
      5.   Construct all buildings to a finish floor elevation of at least one
foot (1') above the base flood elevation or floodproof all buildings to at
least one foot (1') above the base flood elevation or provide minimum finish
floor elevations for each lot or parcel at least one foot (1') above the base
flood elevation on the face of any final subdivision plat. (Ord. 1387, 1-30-
1996)
12-1008: RESPONSIBILITIES OF THE CITY OF DUNCAN:
   A.   It shall be the responsibility of the city to:
      1.   Develop and implement a drainage master plan or plans to encompass
existing drainage problems and foreseeable drainage burdens caused by future
development, provided that the absence of such a drainage master plan shall not
invalidate other requirements of this chapter;
      2.   Maintain and repair drainage channels and their slopes when located
within or upon rights of way dedicated to the city;
      3.   Maintain and repair floodway and flood fringe areas that are within
dedicated public areas, rights of way, park lands, or publicly owned
developments;
      4.   Maintain and repair drainage system components within publicly
dedicated drainage easements and rights of way, exclusive of minor maintenance
as set forth in section
12-1009 of this chapter;
      5.   Develop and implement standards and specifications required to
clearly and accurately interpret the physical requirements of this chapter;
      6.   Require minimum finish floor elevations or floodproofing to an
elevation of at least one foot (1') above the base flood as a condition of
building permits within developments or subdivisions approved under the terms
of this chapter; and
      7.   Comply with the provisions of this chapter in the design and
construction of public improvements. (Ord. 1387, 1-30-1996)
12-1009: PROPERTY OWNER RESPONSIBILITIES:
   A.   It shall be the responsibility of all owners of property, whether
developed, undeveloped or undergoing development, to:
      1.   Mow and provide minor maintenance of drainage channels and their
slopes for that portion of the channel lying within their property lines;
      2.   Keep clear all drainage channels within the boundaries of their
properties in accordance with the requirements of this chapter;
      3.   Control all stormwater runoff and drainage from points and surfaces
on the property; and
      4.   Take reasonable and prudent measures so as not to cause drainage
interferences, obstructions, blockages or any other adverse effects upon
drainage, into, through or out of their property. (Ord. 1387, 1-30-1996)
12-1010: DEVELOPMENT PERMITS:
   A.   All persons who intend development of any land shall submit all
documentation required by section
12-1012 of this chapter in application for development permit approval, unless
granted a waiver thereof from the public works department based upon submittals
sufficient to adequately demonstrate that the proposed development shall have
no significant impact upon existing drainage facilities or conditions.
   B.   Application to subdivision review:
      1.   Preliminary plats and improvement plans submitted in conjunction
with subdivision applications shall be accompanied by or incorporate the
documentation required in section
12-1012 of this chapter;
      2.   Final plats submitted for review and approval shall include or be
accompanied by the following documents:
         a.   Minimum finished floor elevations not less than one foot (1')
above the base flood elevation for each lot or parcel within the subdivision;
         b.   All required dedications of drainage easements or rights of way;
         c.   As built plans showing all drainage system improvements or
construction; and
         d.   Certification of the engineer preparing the drainage system
improvement plans that such improvements have been installed in accordance with
the approved plans therefor;
      3.   In the instance that all improvements have not been completed, prior
to the request for release of the final plat, the application shall be
accompanied by a performance bond or other surety sufficient to guarantee the
completion thereof.
   C.   The documentation required in section
12-1012 of this chapter shall be submitted in conjunction with or prior to
application for building or other permits. Development not requiring a permit
under provisions of other ordinances shall submit the required documentation to
the public works department of the city. (Ord. 1387, 1-30-1996)
12-1011: REVIEW AND APPROVAL:
   A.   All documentation and plans required by this section must be approved
by the city prior to their implementation:
      1.   In the instance of subdivisions, a certificate of approval shall be
filed with the planning commission as a part of the preliminary plat and
improvement plan record; and
      2.   In the instance of developments other than subdivisions, approval
shall be attached to the building permit, if required, or issued as a separate
certificate to the developer. Approval shall be subject to the submission of
executed drainage easements or rights of way dedications, as appropriate.
   B.   The city may submit any required documents to other state or federal
agencies or consultants, in addition to any city department for their review
and comment prior to the city's approval. (Ord. 1387, 1-30-1996)
12-1012: PLANS, SPECIFICATIONS AND DOCUMENTATION:
   A.   Prior to the initiation of any development within the scope of this
chapter, the developer shall cause plans, specifications and documentation
herein required to be prepared by an engineer and submitted to the city for
review and approval. At a minimum, such plans, specifications and documentation
shall provide the following submittals:
      1.   Predevelopment Report: This report shall include information
accurately describing the following conditions of the site:
         a.   Dimensions, size and location;
         b.   Existing topography;
         c.   Soil types;
         d.   Vegetation;
         e.   Flood hazard areas;
         f.   Other significant surface features;
         g.   Existing land use;
         h.   Existing runoff volume and rates; and
         i.   Existing runoff routing;
      2.   Plans And Specifications: Detailed plans for drainage system
improvements and the control of erosion and sedimentation shall contain the
following information:
         a.   Construction plans, details and specifications for all drainage
system improvements;
         b.   An estimate of soil loss during and after development;
         c.   Proposals for the control of erosion and sedimentation in
accordance with the requirements of the Oklahoma pollutant discharge
elimination system;
         d.   Proposed topography of the site after development or improvement
including the method of handling runoff and stormwater;
         e.   Data showing the nature and extent of the proposed clearing,
grading and development or improvement operations; and
         f.   Description of hydraulic methods, assumptions, calculations and
results used in preparation of drainage improvement plans;
      3.   Drainage Impact Statement: A written statement of the impact on
upstream and downstream drainage prepared by an engineer shall be submitted and
approved by the city. The accuracy and validity of any drainage impact
statement and attachments shall be capable of withstanding serious challenge at
any stage in the review and approval process in order to be accepted as a part
of the project;
      4.   Easements And Rights Of Way:
         a.   A description of proposed easements or rights of way within the
boundaries of property under the control of the developer and as necessary to
comply with the provisions of section
12-1013 of this chapter;
         b.   Where easements or rights of way are required beyond the limits
of the property under the control of the developer, the developer shall attempt
to secure such easements or rights of way on behalf of the city; and
         c.   Where efforts to secure easements or rights of way by the
developer in compliance with subsection A4b of this section are unsuccessful,
the city may agree to pursue such easements or rights of way as it may find
appropriate in the public interest;
      5.   Compliance With Other Regulations:
         a.   All plans and documentation required by this chapter must comply
with all city standards, regulations, ordinances, and with any approved
drainage master plan or drainage studies; and
         b.   A floodplain development permit is required to be obtained prior
to any construction activity within the 100-year floodplain as required by the
flood hazard area development regulations in chapter 6 of this part. (Ord.
1387, 1-30-1996)
12-1013: PROVISION OF IMPROVEMENTS:
   A.   In addition to drainage system improvements within a development, the
city may require storm drainage improvements beyond the boundaries of the
development, preferably within open channels, where necessary to facilitate the
flow of stormwater from or through the development and provide a continuous
storm drainage system from the point of discharge from the development to the
nearest existing channel, drainage easement or right of way.
   B.   Where compliance with the terms of this chapter requires construction
of drainage improvements beyond the boundaries of property under control of the
developer, the city may agree to participate in such construction as it may
find appropriate in the public interest.
   C.   Improvements provided by the developer shall be fully and properly
maintained by the developer prior to acceptance by the city.
   D.   The city may require performance and maintenance bonds for drainage
system improvements to be dedicated to the city in the same manner and amount
as required for public street improvements. (Ord. 1387, 1-30-1996)
12-1014: CONSTRUCTION OF DRAINAGE SYSTEMS:
   A.   Drainage systems shall be constructed in full accordance with approved
designs and specifications, without variation, except as may be authorized by a
change order or field change approved by the city:
      1.   The developer, landowner or legal agent thereof engaging in any land
improvement or change covered by this chapter shall be responsible for any and
all construction activity as covered by approved designs, plans and data.
Projects and tasks proposed in the plans and documents required by this chapter
shall be implemented as proposed under the supervision of the engineer
preparing such plans and documents;
      2.   This section shall not be construed to exclude the developer or his
responsible supervisor from providing installations in conformance with the
requirements and constraints of this chapter whether a part of the design
documents, or inadvertently or otherwise excluded;
      3.   Upon determination and notification by the city that construction or
any part thereof is in violation of this chapter or approved construction
plans, such work shall be immediately discontinued and shall not be restarted
until such violation is corrected;
      4.   All facilities, structures, and installations made under the
provisions of this chapter shall be constructed in a workmanlike manner and
using methods and procedures that shall assure a quality installation. The
construction of any drainage system shall conform to the Oklahoma department of
transportation specifications for the construction of drainage system unless
otherwise specifically approved by the city;
      5.   The developer shall provide barricades, guardrails, walkways,
shoring, warning signs and flashers, and such other measures as deemed
necessary to protect workmen, traffic, pedestrians and any other person near or
adjacent to a hazard from injury or damage. Such protection shall be provided
upon start of an operation, and shall be fully maintained until there is no
longer a hazard and approval has been given for removal of the protection.
Signing shall be in accordance with part VI, "Traffic Controls For Street And
Highway Construction And Maintenance Operations" of the current manual on
uniform traffic control devices;
      6.   The structural integrity of all drainage structures shall be
maintained during all phases of construction;
      7.   A construction notice to proceed must be obtained from the city
prior to the start of construction of any drainage system or improvement which
is:
         a.   Owned by or to be dedicated to the city;
         b.   To be constructed on a city right of way or easement;
         c.   A required "off site" improvement; or
         d.   Otherwise required by the city.
Construction inspections may be made during and after construction by the city
and may serve as the basis of all approvals or disapprovals; and
      8.   The erosion and sedimentation control plan shall be implemented in
accordance with the provisions of the Oklahoma pollutant discharge elimination
system. Developers, property owners and contractors shall keep streets,
gutters, inlets, drainage pipes, swales, ditches, drainage channels, and all
drainage devices and structures clean and free from debris, sedimentation, soil
and any materials during construction. (Ord. 1387, 1-30-1996)
12-1015: STORMWATER MANAGEMENT PRINCIPLES:
   A.   It is the intent and purpose of this chapter that the primary component
of drainage systems shall be natural channels within drainage easement or
rights of way. Streets, alleys and enclosed conduits shall principally serve
and be designed to carry stormwater to natural channels in accordance with the
provisions of this chapter:
      1.   Open Channels: Natural drainage channels and techniques shall be
given priority consideration in preparation of drainage system designs and
shall be designed or improved as an integral part of the landscape:
         a.   The design of any development should provide for the maximum
practical use of open channels and natural streams;
         b.   Drainage channel improvements shall be designed to preserve and
protect large trees and other worthy botanical and geological features to the
greatest possible extent; and
         c.   Wherever channel improvements are required to accommodate
calculated flows in a specified manner, the designs shall provide maximum
utilization of turf, sodding and other natural drainage techniques;
      2.   Storm Sewers: Closed, underground drainage conduits should be
employed as appropriate to meet site or geographic conditions or to meet the
requirements of this chapter and all specifications and performance standards
pertaining thereto;
      3.   Streets And Alleys: Stormwater runoff into or within a street or
alley shall be permitted provided the developer fully and adequately
demonstrates that the street or alley or any improvement thereof will provide
drainage in full conformance with all other provisions of this chapter and will
prevent runoff or overflow into adjacent or nearby property beyond the capacity
of the existing or proposed drainage system;
      4.   Erosion Control: All persons engaged in land development or
modifications shall prevent the erosion of soil and movement of sedimentation
into, onto or through streets, gutters, catch basins, culverts or other
drainage channels and shall prevent erosion as a result of flows from streets,
gutters, culverts or other drainage system components:
         a.   Where it can be demonstrated that there is no alternative to
rapid runoff water because of identifiable restrictions, the developer shall be
required to provide measures to prevent erosion, damage, flooding or other
adverse effects; and
         b.   The city may require the cleaning, straightening or repair of any
natural drainage channel or natural features of other drainage channels when
necessary to provide for the free flow of water or to eliminate or prevent
erosion upstream and downstream. (Ord. 1387, 1-30-1996)
12-1016: DRAINAGE SYSTEM PERFORMANCE CRITERIA:
   A.   The following criteria shall be applied to the design of drainage
system improvements required under the provisions of this chapter. Drainage
system elements shall be designed to accommodate stormwater runoff based upon
full development of the contributing drainage basin area as indicated in the
latest general or land use plan for the city, or as determined by the public
works department in consultation with the engineer:
      1.   Detention Or Retention Facilities: Reserved;
      2.   Open Channels: Open channels, flumes or swales shall be designed to
carry the base flood within the limits of the dedicated easement or right of
way;
      3.   Storm Sewers: Storm sewers and appurtenances shall be designed in
accordance with the standards and practices of the Oklahoma department of
transportation. Storm sewers and appurtenances shall have the following minimum
performance criteria:
         a.   The combination of storm sewer and its overflow outlet shall have
the capacity to convey the 50-year return frequency rainfall event within the
drainage easements or rights of way. The storm sewer shall have the capacity to
convey not less than the 10-year return frequency rainfall event;
         b.   The performance of the overflow outlets for the storm sewer
system during the base flood or storm shall be indicated under the condition
that the storm sewer is plugged or inoperative; and
         c.   The minimum velocity in a storm sewer flowing full shall be three
feet (3') per second. Velocities less than three feet (3') per second may be
approved if properly designed sediment traps which are accessible for
maintenance are provided at the upstream end of the sections where the velocity
is to be less than three feet (3') per second;
      4.   Streets: Streets shall have the following performance criteria with
respect to drainage. Alternative designs may be considered and approved where
physical, topographic, or other constraints make compliance with these
performance criteria impractical:
         a.   Streets with curb and gutters shall have the following
performance criteria:
            (1)   Arterial streets shall maintain two (2) clear, ten foot (10')
lanes of traffic during 25-year return frequency rainfall event;
            (2)   Drainage on collector streets shall not exceed two inches
(2") in depth at the crown of the street during the 25-year return frequency
rainfall event; and
            (3)   Drainage on residential streets shall not exceed three and
one-half inches (31/2") in depth at the crown of the street during the 25-year
return frequency rainfall event;
         b.   Streets without curb and gutters shall have the following
performance criteria:
            (1)   Arterial streets shall maintain two (2) clear, ten foot (10')
lanes of traffic during the 25-year return frequency rainfall event; and
            (2)   Residential or collector streets shall maintain two (2)
clear, eight foot (8') lanes of traffic during the 25-year return frequency
rainfall event;
         c.   The performance of streets during the base flood or storm shall
be indicated;
      5.   Pedestrian And Vehicular Bridges: Structures with a clear span of
twenty feet (20') or greater, whether for pedestrian or vehicular traffic shall
be designed in accordance with the standards and practices of the Oklahoma
department of transportation county bridge program; and
      6.   Safety And Convenience:
         a.   When stormwater is conveyed via streets, flumes, swales or open
channels, consideration should be given to pedestrian and traffic convenience
and safety;
         b.   At intersections of an arterial street with any other street,
special provisions may be required to avoid sheeting of water across arterial
intersections, inundation of crosswalks, sidewalks, driving lanes and other
safety or nuisance problems. These special provisions may include additional
easements or rights of way, structures, flumes, fences or additional pavement
width. (Ord. 1387, 1-30-1996)
12-1017: EASEMENTS AND RIGHTS OF WAY:
   A.   Drainage easements or rights of way shall be adequate to accommodate
the design frequency discharge within the limits of such dedication:
      1.   Where such dedication is not adjacent to and parallel with street
right of way or other public property the city may require dedications in
excess of that necessary to accommodate the design frequency discharge in order
to facilitate maintenance access;
      2.   In no case shall a drainage easement or right of way for surface
facilities provide a width of less than ten feet (10') unless adjacent to and
parallel with a dedicated street or other public open space;
      3.   In no case shall a drainage easement or right of way for storm sewer
facilities provide a width of less than fifteen feet (15') unless adjacent to
and parallel with a dedicated street or other public open space;
      4.   Where a drainage easement overlaps or parallels a utility easement
the city may require such additional width as necessary to permit installation
of utilities without obstruction or interference with drainage system elements.
In such instances, development plans shall indicate the location of utility
facilities within the coincident easements;
      5.   Where portions of a development are within a floodplain, identified
in the flood insurance study for the city, easements or rights of way shall be
sufficient to assure compliance with the flood hazard area development
regulations as contained within the land development code;
      6.   Drainage system elements with a contributing drainage basin area of
one hundred twenty (120) acres or greater shall be within rights of way
dedicated to the city;
      7.   Drainage system components with a contributing drainage basin area
of greater than forty (40) and less than one hundred twenty (120) acres may be
within dedicated drainage easements provided that such easement shall be in
excess of any minimum lot size requirements established within applicable
zoning or subdivision regulations;
      8.   Drainage system components with a contributing drainage basin of
less than forty (40) acres may be within dedicated drainage easements; and
      9.   In no case shall a subdivision design require that surface drainage
from any tract or lot to cross more than two (2) separate tracts or lots
without being contained or diverted into a dedicated street, drainage right of
way or drainage easement. (Ord. 1387, 1-30-1996)
12-1018: METHODS AND CALCULATIONS:
   A.   Rate Of Flow: The calculation of runoff rates shall be by the rational
formula using antecedent precipitation factors. The rational formula and
acceptable values shall be as follows:
   Formula: Q = C Ca I A
   Where:
 
C  = Runoff coefficient
Ca = Antecedent precipitation factor
I  = Intensity of rainfall in inches per hour
A  = Drainage area in acres
 
   Acceptable values of Ca are as follows:
 
2 - 10 years 1.0
25 years     1.1
50 years     1.2
100 years    1.25
The product of C Ca must not exceed 1
 
Acceptable values for C according to the description of the drainage area shall
be within the following ranges:
            DESCRIPTION OF AREA
 
Business:
 Downtown              0.70 0.95
 Other business        0.50 0.70
Residential:
 Single-family         0.30 0.50
 Detached multi-family 0.40 0.60
 Attached multi-family 0.60 0.75
 Suburban              0.25 0.40
 Apartments            0.50 0.70
Industrial:
 Light                 0.50 0.80
 Heavy                 0.60 0.90
Parks, cemeteries       0.10 0.25
Playgrounds             0.20 0.35
Unimproved areas        0.10 0.30
 
Acceptable values for C according to the description of surface characteristics
shall be within the following ranges:
            CHARACTER OF SURFACE
 
Asphalt                   0.70 0.95
Concrete                  0.80 0.95
Roofs                     0.75 0.85
Lawns:                         
 Sandy soil:                  
  <2 percent slope      0.05 0.10
  2 - 7 percent slope   0.10 0.15
  >7 percent slope      0.15 0.35
 Heavy soil:                  
  <2 percent slope      0.13 0.17
  2 - 7 percent slope   0.18 0.22
  >7 percent slope      0.25 0.35
Agricultural land:             
 Bare, packed, smooth    0.30 0.60
 Bare, packed, rough     0.20 0.50
 Cultivated:                  
  Heavy soil, no crop   0.30 0.60
  Heavy soil, with crop 0.20 0.50
  Sandy soil, no crop   0.20 0.50
  Sandy soil, with crop 0.10 0.25
 Pasture:                     
  Heavy soil            0.15 0.45
  Sandy soil            0.05 0.25
 Woodlands               0.05 0.25
 
   B.   Rainfall Intensity: The following formula is acceptable for calculation
of rainfall intensity for various storm recurrence intervals using the factors
provided:
 
Formula: I =       a     
             (Td + b)c
 
   Where:
 
I          = Intensity of rainfall in inches per hour
T d        = Duration or time of concentration
a, b and c = Values taken from the table below for specified recurrence
             intervals
 
            STORM RECURRENCE INTERVAL
 
Factors 2-Year 5-Year 10-Year 25-Year 50-Year 100-Year
a       56.43  72.0   82.0    95.0    108.0   120.0
b       11.5   15.0   15.0    15.0    15.0    15.0
c       0.81   0.80   0.80    0.80    0.80    0.80
 
   C.   Time Of Concentration: The following formulas are acceptable for
calculation of time of concentration as applied in the rational formula:
 
Overland flows: Formula: T = K(L0.37)
                             S0.2
Channel flows:  Formula: T = K(L0.77)
                             S0.385
 
   Where:
 
K = Surface coefficient
L = Length of flow in feet
S = Average slope in feet per foot
 
 
K values for overland flow:
      Surface      K Value       Surface           K Value
                                                 
 Pavement          0.372    Commercial             0.445
 Bare soil         0.604    Residential            0.511
 Poor grass        0.900    Cultivated soil        0.775
 Average grass     1.000    Timber, thin grass     0.942
 Dense grass       1.130    Pasture                1.040
                                                     
K values for channel flow:
      Surface      K Value       Surface           K Value
                                                 
 Curbed street     0.0035   Straight clean stream  0.00592
 Concrete channel  0.006    Average stream         0.00835
 Sodden swale      0.008    Meandering stream      0.01020
 Bar ditch         0.012    Pooling stream         0.01020
 
   D.   Structure Sizing: The sizing of all drainage facilities or structures
shall be done by the use of established available engineering principles and
practice and the methods shall be acceptable to the city.
      1.   The structure sizing shall include an analysis of the existence of
inlet or outlet control conditions and a backwater analysis where applicable;
      2.   Where Manning's equation is used, the value for coefficients will be
taken from the following references:
         a.   Open Channels:
            (1)   "Open Channel Hydraulics", Chow, Ven T., McGraw-Hill Book
Co., New York, N.Y., 1959;
            (2)   "USDA Handbook SCS-TP-61", W.O. Ree; and
            (3)   "Roughness Characteristics Of Natural Channels", USGS water
supply paper no. 1849, Washington, D.C., 1967;
         b.   Closed Conduits:
            (1)   "Seelye's Handbook";
            (2)   "Handbook Of Hydraulics", King, H.W.;
            (3)   "Eschbach Handbook"; and
            (4)   "Modern Sewer Design", American Iron And Steel Institute.
   E.   Vegetative Linings:
      1.   Natural open channels with vegetative linings shall be designed
considering infrequent mowing unless other conditions are demonstrated and
justified. Guaranteed maintenance for exceptions must be established; and
      2.   Cover vegetation for channel linings must be selected according to
the "Stephens County Best Management Practices For Erosion Control" and shall
be approved by the city.
   F.   Design Standards And Practices: Where the provisions of this chapter
are insufficient to prescribe best design principles and practice, the design
standards and practices of the Oklahoma department of transportation shall be
used. (Ord. 1387, 1-30-1996)
12-1019: ENFORCEMENT AND PENALTY:
   A.   Any person, firm or corporation found in violation of any provision of
this chapter shall be fined as provided in section
1-108 of this code. A separate offense shall be deemed committed for each day a
violation continues.
   B.   Where the city or its officers determines that construction or other
activity regulated within the scope of this chapter is in violation of the
provisions herein or in violation of approved construction plans and
specifications, the city may issue notice to stop work or notice of
deficiencies directing corrective actions. Failure of the owner, developer,
contractor or their agents to comply with such notice shall be deemed a
violation of this chapter, punishable as provided above.
   C.   Nothing in this section shall be deemed to prohibit action to enforce
or seek compliance with the terms and conditions of this chapter through action
in a court of competent jurisdiction. (Ord. 1387, 1-30-1996)
CHAPTER 11
LANDSCAPE REGULATIONS
SECTION:
12-1101: Purpose And Intent
12-1102: Scope And Applicability
12-1103: Definitions
12-1104: Landscape Point System
12-1105: Expansion Of Existing Nonconforming Development
12-1106: Selection Of Landscape Material
12-1107: Installation Of Landscaping
12-1108: Maintenance Of Landscaping
12-1109: Landscape Plan Submittal Requirements
12-1110: Enforcement And Appeals
12-1101: PURPOSE AND INTENT:
   A.   The purpose of this chapter is to require landscape elements,
particularly plant materials, within proposed developments in an organized and
harmonious fashion that will enhance, protect and promote the economic and
aesthetic environment of the City of Duncan, and provide for the prosperity,
comfort and enjoyment of its citizens. The City recognizes the value of
landscaping in achieving the following goals:
      1.   Promote the re-establishment of vegetation in urban areas for
health, ecological and aesthetic benefits.
      2.   Provide new planting in concert with natural vegetation and careful
grading.
      3.   Encourage the preservation of existing trees.
      4.   Promote compatibility between land uses by reducing the visual,
noise and lighting impacts of development on users of the site and abutting
properties.
      5.   Unify development, and enhance and define public and private places.
      6.   Provide an overall planting scheme that will:
         a.   Reduce soil erosion, and the volume and rate of discharge of
stormwater runoff.
         b.   Aid in energy conservation by shading and sheltering structures
from energy losses caused by weather and wind.
         c.   Mitigate the loss of natural resources.
         d.   Provide visual screens and buffers that mitigate the impact of
conflicting land uses to preserve the appearance, character and value of
existing neighborhoods.
         e.   Provide shade, comfort and seasonal color.
         f.   Reduce glare, noise and heat.
         g.   Provide greater perceptual clarity along major streets and roads
by more consistent planting of property sized street trees.
      7.   It is further recognized that good landscaping attracts potential
residents and businesses to the City of Duncan, and creates a safer, more
attractive and more pleasant living and working environment for all residents
and visitors of Duncan.
      8.   These regulations are intended at minimum standards for landscape
treatment. Owners and developers are encouraged to exceed this standard in
seeking more creative solutions, both for the enhanced value of their land and
for the collective health and enjoyment of all citizens of Duncan. (Ord. 1767,
6-27-2017)
12-1102: SCOPE AND APPLICABILITY:
All applicants for building permits to construct new buildings and/or parking
areas or to expand existing buildings and/or parking areas for any use
designated as "non-residential" per the International Code Council shall be
required to meet the provisions of this chapter. The provisions of this chapter
do not apply to the construction or expansion of one and two family residential
dwellings or accessory structures, regardless of the zoning districts in which
they are located. (Ord. 1767, 6-27-2017)
12-1103: DEFINITIONS:
BERM: An earthen mound designated to provide visual interest, screen
undesirable views and/or decrease noise.
CALIPER: The diameter of a tree trunk less than twelve inches (12") in
diameter. For trees less than four inches (4") in diameter, it is measured six
inches (6") from the ground. For trees between four inches (4") and twelve
inches (12") in diameter, it is measured twelve inches (12") from the ground.
DETA: The Duncan Enhancement Trust Authority as established by the City
Council.
EVERGREEN: A plant with foliage that persists and remains green year-round.
EXISTING SIGNIFICANT TREE: An existing tree with a caliper greater than eight
inches (8") that is determined to be in good health. Landscape points will be
awarded by the Director of the Department of Community Development based on the
health and general shape and appearance of the tree.
GROUNDCOVER: An evergreen or deciduous planting less than twenty four inches
(24") in height, excluding turf grass.
LANDSCAPE PLAN: Graphic and written criteria, specifications, and detailed
plans to arrange and modify the effects of natural and manmade features such as
plantings, ground and water forms, circulation, walks, structures, and other
features to comply with provisions of this chapter. All landscape plans shall
include calculations of the site and parking lot landscaping points required,
along with a table indicating how said requirement has been met.
LANDSCAPED AREA: Any area that contains trees, shrubs, and/or groundcover that
is eligible for point credits.
PARKING LOT ISLAND: An unpaved area within a parking lot that is surrounded on
at least three (3) sides by the paved parking area but separated from the paved
area by a barrier curb.
PLANTING PLAN: The preparation of graphic and written criteria of plant
placement, plant specification of type, size and spacing, and other features to
comply with the provisions of this chapter.
PLANTING SEASON: The most favorable time to plant trees in Duncan is
established as the months between and including October and April.
SHRUB: A living self-supporting woody deciduous or evergreen species no less
than eight inches (8") in height and no greater than fifteen feet (15') in
height, which will remain fully vegetated throughout the year.
TREE: A living self-supporting woody or evergreen plant that normally grows to
a minimum height of fifteen feet (15') and which has one or several self-
supporting stems or trunks and numerous branches.
TURF GRASS: Existing or installed grass that has been sodded, seeded, or hydro-
mulched. Turf grass eligible for point credits must be located within the
property lines of a development. The maximum credit for turf is twenty five
percent (25%) of the total landscape points required for any development. All
turf credited points shall completely cover all exposed areas of soil after one
full growing season.
XERISCAPE: Landscaping which incorporates only drought tolerant plant
materials, as indicated in the approved City of Duncan planting materials list,
which after establishment will not require supplemental water from irrigation.
(Ord. 1767, 6-27-2017)
12-1104: LANDSCAPE POINT SYSTEM:
   A.   Point System:
      1.   The minimum amount of landscaping required for an individual
development project is that amount of landscaping with a total point value (as
determined from the table below) equal to or exceeding the total required
landscape points, being the sum of the "site points" and the "parking lot
points". Site points are determined by the size of the developed area, and
parking lot points are determined by the number of parking spaces. For the
purposes of calculating landscape points, the developed area may be submitted
in the form of the legal description of the property or scaled, dimensioned and
well-defined area of development that is referenced on the site plan.
      2.   Number of landscaping points required:
 
Size Of Developed Area Number Of Points Required
Commercial development:       
                             Site points = 25
 1 to 5,000 square feet      Parking lot points = 2 points per required parking
                             space and 1 point for each proposed additional
                             parking space beyond required spaces
                             Site points = 25 plus 1 point for each additional
                             200 square feet of building area
 More than 5,000 square feet Parking lot points = 2 points per required parking
                             space and 1 point for each proposed additional
                             parking space beyond required spaces
Industrial development:       
                             Site points = 25
 1 to 5,000 square feet      Parking lot points = 2 points per required parking
                             space and 1 point for each proposed additional
                             parking space beyond required spaces
                             Site points = 25 plus 1 point for each additional
                             1,000 square feet of building area
 More than 5,000 square feet Parking lot points = 2 points per required parking
                             space and 1 point for each proposed additional
                             parking space beyond required spaces
 
      3.   When only a portion of a larger tract is developed then only the
developed area shall be considered when determining the number of points
required. All required landscaping shall be placed within the developed area.
      4.   Sixty percent (60%) of the total landscaping shall be within the
front and side yards.
      5.   One hundred percent (100%) of the parking lot points must be located
within five feet (5') of the paved area associated with parking and
maneuvering.
      6.   Forty percent (40%) of the landscaping requirement attributable to
the parking area (parking lot points) shall be located within parking lot
islands. For the purposes of this requirement, a parking lot island is any
landscaped space greater than or equal to five feet (5') in width that is
located or extends into a paved parking area for approximately the length of
one or more spaces.
      7.   A maximum of twenty five percent (25%) of the required points may be
used for turf grass, river rock or other ground cover, and a maximum of fifty
percent (50%) of the ground cover in any yard area may be non-live materials.
      8.   A minimum of twenty five percent (25%) of the required points shall
be used for evergreen plantings.
      9.   Only ten percent (10%) of the landscaping requirement may be used
within designated detention basins. Any additional landscaping provided within
these detention basins shall not be assigned any landscape points for
compliance with the provisions of this chapter.
      10.   Developments providing additional landscaping such that the total
number of landscaping points provided is at least twenty percent (20%) more
than the total required landscaping points, may reduce the total required
number of parking spaces for said development by a maximum of ten percent
(10%). This provision shall not apply to developments requiring less than ten
(10) parking spaces.
      11.   The developer may use any combination of plantings to obtain the
necessary number of points for the development. Different lots and landscapes
will lend themselves to different types of plantings. The regulations attempt
to encourage creativity and diversity in landscaping. Different types of
plantings shall be worth point values as shown in table 1, "Landscape Point
Values", of this section.
      12.   Landscaping placed in a public right-of-way or easement shall be
limited to turf and/or other groundcover, unless otherwise approved by the
Director of the Department of Community Development. All such landscaping shall
be irrigated and maintained by the developer and may be counted towards
compliance with the provisions of this chapter.
      13.   All existing trees and other landscaping for which credit is
requested must be in good health and located within the developed area. Any
such credits are subject to approval by the Director of the Department of
Community Development and will be awarded based on the type, size and condition
of the existing trees and other landscaping in accordance with table 1,
"Landscape Point Values", of this section.
      TABLE 1

12-1105: EXPANSION OF EXISTING NONCONFORMING DEVELOPMENT:
   A.   All developments which are in existence prior to the effective date of
this chapter may continue as legal nonconforming development until such time as
a building permit is issued to expand the structure and/or parking area.
   B.   Any application for a building permit for an expansion of a structure
or parking lot within a legal nonconforming development shall require the
development to be brought into compliance with this chapter on a graduated
scale based upon the ratio of the area of the building expansion to the area of
the existing structures. Said ratio shall be applied to the total amount of
site and parking lot landscaping points required for development. The required
landscaping shall be placed throughout the development as indicated herein.
   C.   When not all structures within a legal nonconforming development are
being expanded, the number of landscaping points required may be determined
either from the ratio of the area of expansion to the area of the affected
building or the ratio of the area of expansion to the total area of all the
buildings within the development. The ratio used would be applied to the
landscaping points required for the expanded building or entire development as
appropriate. The required landscaping would be placed around the affected
building and associated parking or throughout the entire development depending
on which method is used.
   D.   In addition to the allowable methods of irrigation as listed in this
chapter, a hose attachment located within one hundred feet (100') of all
required landscape area and plant materials shall be allowed as an acceptable
method of provided irrigation for landscaping installed with expanded legal
nonconforming developments.
   E.   For the construction or expansion of parking area not associated with a
new or expanded building, the total site and parking lot points would be
determined based on the developed area and number of parking spaces as provided
herein, with the required landscaping being placed within and around the new or
expanded parking area, or distributed throughout the development associated
with said parking area, provided that such distribution is in accordance with
the provisions of this chapter. (Ord. 1767, 6-27-2017)
12-1106: SELECTION OF LANDSCAPE MATERIAL:
   A.   When selecting plant materials to be used for compliance with the
provisions of this chapter, attention should be given to the suitability of the
material for use in southwestern Oklahoma, specifically the exposure, soil
requirements, hardiness, and drought tolerance. The developer is strongly
encouraged to consider selecting plant materials from Oklahoma Proven as
published by the Department of Horticulture and Landscape Architecture at
Oklahoma State University or the City of Duncan planting materials list.
   B.   Only trees selected from Oklahoma Proven as published by the Department
of Horticulture and Landscape Architecture at Oklahoma State University, or the
City of Duncan planting materials list may be credited towards compliance with
the provisions of this chapter.
   C.   Certain trees due to their susceptibility to disease, decay, insects
and/or their production of seeds, fruits, sap or other objectionable material
are considered nuisances and are prohibited from being included on any
landscaping plan submitted under this chapter. Such trees shall be identified
within the City of Duncan planting materials list.
   D.   Trees not listed in the City of Duncan planting materials list as
either recommended or prohibited, may be included within the project
landscaping, but shall not be awarded landscaping points. (Ord. 1767, 6-27-
2017)
12-1107: INSTALLATION OF LANDSCAPING:
   A.   All landscape plans must meet safety distance and height requirement
for an unobstructed view at sight triangles and driveways.
   B.   All planting beds within new construction shall be a minimum of five
feet (5'). Planting areas within existing parking areas shall be a minimum of
three feet (3'). Within narrower areas only turf or other ground cover may be
used towards compliance with the provisions of this chapter.
   C.   All planting beds should include mulch and edging. Tree locations shall
include mulch.
   D.   The use of artificial grass or any form of synthetic material does not
meet the definition of landscaping as required herein. Such materials may be
used in conjunction with other approved materials, but shall not be assigned
any landscape points for compliance with the provisions of this chapter.
   E.   Special features may be assigned points by the Director of the
Department of Community Development in accordance with section
12-1104, table 1, "Landscape Point Values", of this chapter for features such
as fountains, ponds, statues, sculptures, and benches when used in conjunction
with approved materials and are considered as an enhancement to the project
site.
   F.   Landscaping points that may be assigned to non-live plant materials and
features is limited to fifty percent (50%) of the total required points.
Additional non-live plant materials and features shall not be assigned any
landscape points for compliance with the provisions of this chapter.
   G.   The developer shall be required to install an irrigation system to all
required landscape areas to insure that sufficient water is delivered to plant
materials utilizing one or more of the following methods:
      1.   An automatic or manual underground irrigation system (such as a
conventional spray, bubbler, etc.) that is equipped with a rain and freeze
sensor (for points awarded).
      2.   An automatic water-saving irrigation system (such as drip, porous
pipe, leaky pipes, etc.) that is equipped with a rain and freeze sensor (for
points awarded).
      3.   Required landscape areas, including areas utilizing extreme drought
tolerant "xeriscape" plant materials may be irrigated with a hose attachment
located within one hundred feet (100') of all required plant materials (no
points awarded). (Ord. 1767, 6-27-2017)
12-1108: MAINTENANCE OF LANDSCAPING:
   A.   It shall be the responsibility of the property owner to maintain in
good condition all the improvements required by this chapter. Any required
landscaping components shall be maintained and repaired if those components
become damaged. Any vegetation that dies shall be replaced no later than the
following planting season (spring or fall).
   B.   All development and property subject to the provisions of this chapter
shall be maintained by regular weeding, irrigation, fertilizing, mowing, and
pruning of plant materials in conformance with good horticultural practices.
   C.   All landscaping materials not properly maintained such that they become
overgrown, exhibit evidence of weed and/or pest infestation, or fall into
disrepair will be considered a public nuisance under the provisions of this
Code and abated under the provisions therein.
   D.   All required plant materials which are removed or perish for any
reason, must be replaced with similar materials of greater than or equal point
value as the removed/perished materials as they were credited at the time of
planting.
   E.   If Stage 3 water restrictions are invoked by the City of Duncan per
section
17-220 of this Code, enforcement of the provisions of section
17-220 of this Code will be suspended during said restriction and for one
hundred twenty (120) days thereafter.
   F.   When it is determined by the Community Development Director, or his/her
designee, that improvements required by this chapter are not being maintained,
it shall be his/her duty to give notice in writing to the property owner in
accordance with section
12-1110 of this chapter. (Ord. 1767, 6-27-2017)
12-1109: LANDSCAPE PLAN SUBMITTAL REQUIREMENTS:
   A.   At the time a building permit application is submitted for review, a
landscape plan, separate and apart from all other required plans, shall be
submitted and made part of the file.
      1.   Landscape plans may be prepared as follows:
         a.   By any person and/or developer provided the plan is limited to
plant specification and placement only;
         b.   By a landscape architect that is registered in the State of
Oklahoma; or
         c.   By a licensed architect or professional engineer that is licensed
in the State of Oklahoma, provided the services are incidental to the
performance of his or her normal practice as an architect or engineer.
      2.   All landscape plans shall include the following information:
         a.   North arrow and scale.
         b.   Location of existing property lines and dimensions of the tract
which is accurately drawn to scale.
         c.   Exact locations and outline of rights-of-way, both existing and
proposed.
         d.   Location of all existing and proposed buildings, and parking
areas. Parking information shall include the exact number of parking spaces
being provided.
         e.   Location and size of any permanent fixtures or structures
including, but not limited to, sidewalks, walls, fences, trash enclosures,
storage areas, lighting fixtures, signage and benches/seating areas, which are
relevant to the landscape plan.
         f.   Location, size and type of all above-ground and underground
utilities with notation, when appropriate, as to any safety hazards to avoid
during the installation of landscaping. Alternatively, a letter of no objection
may be provided by the utility company.
         g.   Location, size, type, spacing (on center), and quantity of all
proposed plant materials and existing plant materials to remain for credit of
landscape points along with an appropriate key of all plant species given the
common and scientific name which shall be organized by type (example: ground
cover, shrub species, tree species) and the nature (example: evergreen,
deciduous).
         h.   Method of irrigation on plans and defined area of coverage. If an
automatic irrigation system is not required, the location of all hose
connections and other watering sources shall be noted on the plans.
         i.   All required screening, with reference to height and type of
construction.
         j.   Calculation of the site and parking lot landscaping points
required for the development, including the square footage of the developed
area and number of parking spaces being provided.
         k.   A table listing all plant materials by scientific and common
name, size, type, quantity, point value and total landscaping points being
provided. (Ord. 1767, 6-27-2017)
12-1110: ENFORCEMENT AND APPEALS:
When it is determined by the City that improvements required by this chapter
are not being maintained, the City shall give notice in writing to the property
owner. Such notice shall specify in what manner the improvements are in need of
maintenance and a date by which compliance must be completed. The property
owner shall have not less than thirty (30) days to comply with the notice. Any
person aggrieved by any such notice or disagreeing with any administrative
decision or requirements of a notice may file an appeal with the Board of
Adjustments within thirty (30) days of receiving the notice. Failure to provide
the improvements required by this chapter or failure to maintain required
improvements in the manner prescribed by this chapter shall constitute an
offense and violation of this chapter. (Ord. 1767, 6-27-2017)
PART 13
PUBLIC SAFETY
CHAPTER 1
FIRE PREVENTION CODE
SECTION:
13-101: Adoption Of Fire Prevention Code
13-102: Enforcement
13-103: Definitions
13-104: Storage Of Flammable Liquids Prohibited
13-105: Bulk Storage Of Liquefied Petroleum Gases And Explosives Restricted
13-106: Modifications
13-107: Appeals
13-108: New Materials, Processes Or Occupancies Which May Require Permits
13-109: Penalty
13-110: Fire Hydrant Spacing For New Construction
13-111: Smoke Detectors
13-101: ADOPTION OF FIRE PREVENTION CODE:
There are hereby adopted by the city for the purpose of prescribing regulations
governing conditions hazardous to life and property from fire or explosion,
those certain codes known as the fire prevention code, issued by the National
Fire Protection Association, to include the international fire code and
appendices B, C, D and E, uniform fire code, life safety code 101 and the NFPA
code, being particularly the latest editions thereof and the whole thereof,
save and except such portions as may be hereinafter deleted, modified or
amended. At least one copy of said codes have been and now are filed in the
office of the clerk of the city and the same are hereby adopted and
incorporated as fully as if set out at length herein. (Prior code § 8-1; amd.
Ord. 1230, 10-9-1984; 2015 Code)
13-102: ENFORCEMENT:
The codes hereby adopted shall be enforced by the fire marshal and the chief of
the fire department or their designees. (Prior code § 8-2; amd. 2015 Code)
13-103: DEFINITIONS:
Wherever the word "jurisdiction" is used in the fire prevention code hereby
adopted it shall be held to mean the city. Whenever the words "corporation
counsel" are used in the fire prevention code, they mean the attorney for the
city. Where the word "permit" appears in the fire prevention code, it means
"prior approval by the fire marshal, fire chief or their designees". (Prior
code § 8-3; amd. Ord. 1230, 10-9-1984; 2015 Code)
13-104: STORAGE OF FLAMMABLE LIQUIDS PROHIBITED:
   A.   Storage of flammable liquids in outside aboveground tanks is prohibited
without approved I-3 zoning and prior approval by the fire marshal and the
building official.
   B.   New bulk plants for flammable liquids are prohibited without approval
by the fire marshal and the building official.
   C.   This section shall not prohibit any such installations in existence as
of January 1, 1961. (Prior code § 8-4)
13-105: BULK STORAGE OF LIQUEFIED PETROLEUM GASES AND EXPLOSIVES RESTRICTED:
Bulk storage of liquefied petroleum gas and storage of explosives and blasting
agents is prohibited, without approved I-3 zoning and prior approval of the
fire marshal and building official. (Prior code § 8-5)
13-106: MODIFICATIONS:
The chief of the fire department, with the approval of the city manager, shall
have power to modify any of the provisions of the fire prevention code and all
codes indicated in section
13-101 of this chapter, upon application in writing by the owner or lessee, or
his duly authorized agent, when there are practical difficulties in the way of
carrying out the strict letter of the code, provided that the spirit of the
code shall be observed, public safety secured, and substantial justice done.
The particulars of such modification when granted or allowed and the decision
of the chief of the fire department thereon shall be entered upon the records
of the department, and a signed copy shall be furnished the applicant. (Prior
code § 8-6; amd. 2015 Code)
13-107: APPEALS:
Whenever the chief of the fire department shall disapprove an application or
refuse to grant a license or permit, or whenever it is claimed that the
provisions of the code do not apply or that the true intent and meaning of the
code have been misconstrued or wrongly interpreted, the applicant may appeal
from the decision of the chief of the fire department to the city manager, in
writing, within thirty (30) days from the date of the decision of the chief.
(Prior code § 8-7; amd. 2015 Code)
13-108: NEW MATERIALS, PROCESSES OR OCCUPANCIES WHICH MAY REQUIRE PERMITS:
The city manager, the chief of the fire department, the building official and
the fire marshal shall act as a committee to determine and specify, after
giving affected persons an opportunity to be heard, any new materials,
processes or occupancies, which shall require permits, in addition to those
newly enumerated in the code. The fire marshal shall post such list in a
conspicuous place in his office, and distribute copies thereof to interested
persons. (Prior code § 8-8)
13-109: PENALTY:
Any person who violates any provision of the code adopted by this chapter or
fails to comply therewith or who shall violate or fail to comply with any order
made thereunder, or who shall build in violation of any detailed statement of
specifications or plans submitted and approved thereunder, or any certificate
or permit issued thereunder, and from which no appeal has been taken, or who
shall fail to comply with such an order as affirmed or modified by the city
council or by a court of competent jurisdiction, within the time fixed for such
compliance, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and shall be punished as
prescribed in section
1-108 of this code. The imposition of one penalty for any violation shall not
excuse the violation or permit it to continue. All such persons shall be
required to correct or remedy such violations or defects within a reasonable
time. When not otherwise specified, each ten (10) days that prohibited
conditions are maintained shall constitute a separate offense. (Prior code § 8-
15)
13-110: FIRE HYDRANT SPACING FOR NEW CONSTRUCTION:
   A.   Fire hydrants shall be located at a maximum spacing of three hundred
feet (300') in mercantile and manufacturing districts and five hundred feet
(500') in residential districts.
   B.   In mercantile and manufacturing districts, fire hydrants shall be
located in such a manner that no hose line will exceed three hundred feet
(300') to reach any portion of the exterior of the building.
   C.   A fire hydrant shall be located within fifty feet (50') of all fire
department sprinkler connections. (Ord. 1261, 1-13-1987)
13-111: SMOKE DETECTORS:
   A.   All existing hotels, motels, dormitories, apartments, lodging or
rooming houses, board and care facilities, and one- and two- family dwellings,
that are leased or rented shall be protected with smoke detectors which are
listed or approved by a nationally recognized testing organization or
laboratory. Such detectors shall be an ionization or a photoelectric AC or DC
power supply type device. When activated, such detectors shall be suitable to
warn the occupants of the presence of smoke and the possibility of fire danger.
   B.   Such detectors shall be provided and installed by the owner of all
leased or rented residential occupancies. Such detectors shall be maintained in
good working order by the owner.
   C.   It is the duty of the occupants of apartments and one- or two- family
dwellings to maintain the smoke detector batteries.
   D.   It is the duty of the occupant not to intentionally or negligently
interfere with or damage the detector or its proper functioning.
   E.   Prior to the time of any transfer of ownership or when any alterations,
repairs or additions requiring a building permit and having a valuation in
excess of one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) occur, the owner of an existing
single-family dwelling not having an operable smoke detector shall install a
minimum of one approved smoke detector in the dwelling.
   F.   The smoke detectors described in this section shall be installed as
herein provided before June 15, 1988. (Ord. 1285, 5-10-1988)
