13-301: POLICE DEPARTMENT CREATED; CHIEF 1 :
There is a police department, the head of which is the chief of police,
appointed by the city manager for an indefinite term. The chief of police is an
officer of the city, and has supervision and control of the police department.
(Prior code § 1-9)
 
Notes
1 1. 11 OS § 34-101 et seq.
13-302: DUTIES:
It is the duty of the police department to apprehend and arrest on view or on
warrant and bring to justice all violators of the ordinances of the city and
the charter; to suppress all riots, affrays, and unlawful assemblies which may
come to their knowledge, and generally to keep the peace; to serve all
warrants, writs, executions, and other processes properly directed and
delivered to them; to apprehend and arrest persons violating federal or state
law as provided by law, and to turn them over to proper authorities; and in all
respects to perform all duties pertaining to the offices of police officers.
(Prior code § 1-10)
13-303: NOT TO MISTREAT OR INTERFERE WITH POLICE DOGS:
It is unlawful for any person to wilfully or maliciously torture, torment,
beat, kick, strike, injure, disable, or kill any dog used by the police
department of the city in the performance of the functions or duties of such
department, or to interfere with or meddle with any such dog while being used
by the department or any officer or member. Any person violating any provision
of this section shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor. (Prior code § 1-11)
13-304: MUTUAL AID AGREEMENTS 1 :
Approval is given for service of members of the regular police department of
this city as police officers of any other city or town in an emergency
situation in the state, not more than one hundred (100) miles distant from this
city, when such service is requested by the mayor or chief of police of the
city or town. Requests for service under this section shall be made in writing
or by telephone, or other means of communication, to the mayor or city manager,
who, if he determines that the request can be granted consistently with the
continuance of the proper police protection to the inhabitants of this city,
shall direct the chief of police to furnish the number of officers requested
and to arrange for their transportation to the requesting municipality. (1985
Code)
 
Notes
1 2. 11 OS § 34-103.
CHAPTER 4
EMERGENCY MANAGEMENT PROGRAM
SECTION:
13-401: Definitions
13-402: Plan Development; Agreement With County
13-403: City Authority
13-404: Nonliability Of City
13-405: Emergency Interim Successors
13-401: DEFINITIONS 1 :
For the purpose of this chapter, the following terms shall have the meanings
ascribed to them in this section:
EMERGENCY: Any occasion or instance for which, in the determination of the
president of the United States or the governor of the state of Oklahoma, or the
mayor of the city of Duncan, federal, state, or county assistance is needed to
supplement the city of Duncan's efforts and capabilities to save lives and to
protect property and public health and safety, or to lessen or avert threat of
a catastrophe within the city of Duncan.
EMERGENCY MANAGEMENT: The preparation for and the coordination of all emergency
functions by organized and trained persons, who will extend existent
governmental functions and provide other necessary nongovernmental functions,
to prevent, minimize and repair injury and damage resulting from natural or
manmade disasters developing to such an extent to cause an extreme emergency
situation to arise which by declaration of the mayor of the city of Duncan
jeopardizes the welfare of the citizens of the city. These emergency functions
include, but are not limited to, firefighting, law enforcement, medical and
health, search and rescue, public works, warnings, communications, hazardous
materials and other special response functions, evacuations of persons from
affected areas, emergency assistance services, emergency transportation, and
other functions related to preparedness, response, recovery and mitigation.
EMERGENCY OPERATIONS PLAN: That plan which sets forth the organization,
administration and functions for emergency management by the city of Duncan.
HAZARD MITIGATION: Any cost effective measure which will reduce or eliminate
the effects of a natural or manmade disaster.
MANMADE DISASTER: A disaster caused by acts of man including, but not limited
to, an act of war, terrorism, chemical spill or release, or power shortages
that require assistance from outside the city of Duncan.
NATURAL DISASTER: Any natural catastrophe, including, but not limited to, a
tornado, severe storm, high water, floodwaters, wind driven water, earthquake,
landslide, mudslide, snowstorm, or drought which causes damage of sufficient
severity and magnitude to warrant hazard mitigation or the use of resources
from outside the city of Duncan to alleviate damage, loss, hardship or
suffering caused thereby.
SIGNIFICANT EVENTS: All hazardous material releases of any size and type,
earthquakes, fires involving large buildings or facilities and large grass or
wild fires, explosions, bomb threats, terrorist/civil disturbance, aircraft
crash, natural disaster, utility disruption, dam breach, technological/manmade
incident, search and rescue, structural collapse, and any other incident that
poses significant consequences to the city of Duncan.
UNAVAILABLE: Absent from the place of session, other than on official business
of the city of Duncan, or unable, for physical, mental or legal reasons, to
exercise the powers and discharge the duties of mayor, vice mayor, or
designated employee. (Ord. 1725, 7-22-2014)
 
Notes
1 1. 63 OS § 683.3.
13-402: PLAN DEVELOPMENT; AGREEMENT WITH COUNTY 1 :
The city shall develop an emergency management program in accordance with the
Oklahoma emergency management act of 2003 2 . The city is authorized to enter
into an emergency management services agreement with the board of county
commissioners of Stephens County, for the county to provide emergency
management services, and an emergency operations plan. Further, that the county
emergency management director shall develop an emergency operations plan in
accordance with existing federal, state and local statutes, including the state
of Oklahoma emergency management act as well as the Robert T. Stafford disaster
relief and emergency assistance act, 42 USC §§ 5121 - 5207. The plan shall be
reviewed annually. (Ord. 1725, 7-22-2014)
 
Notes
1 1. 63 OS § 683.11.
2 2. 63 OS § 683.1 et seq.
13-403: CITY AUTHORITY 1 :
In carrying out the provisions of this chapter, in which any disaster as
defined in section
13-401 of this chapter occurs, the mayor shall have the authority to declare an
emergency and the power to enter into contracts and incur obligations necessary
to combat such disaster, protecting the health and safety of persons and
property, and providing emergency assistance to the victims of such disaster.
The city is authorized to exercise the powers vested under this section in the
light of the exigencies of the extreme emergency situation without regard to
time consuming procedures and formalities prescribed by law, excepting
mandatory constitutional requirements, pertaining to the performance of public
work, entering into contracts, the incurring of obligations, the employment of
temporary workers, the rental of equipment, the purchase of supplies and
materials, and the appropriation and expenditure of public funds. (Ord. 1725,
7-22-2014)
 
Notes
1 3. 63 OS § 683.11.
13-404: NONLIABILITY OF CITY 1 :
Neither the city nor any officer or employee of the city nor a volunteer whose
services have been accepted and utilized by an officer or employee of the city
for carrying out the functions of this chapter shall be civilly liable for any
loss or injury resulting to any person's company, corporation or other legal
entity as a result of any decision, determination, order or action of such
employee or volunteer in the performance of assigned duties and
responsibilities under this chapter during a stated emergency unless such loss
or injury was caused by the gross negligence, or wilfully and unnecessarily or
by the wanton act of such officer or employee or volunteer. Nothing in this
chapter shall be construed to waive the sovereignty or immunity of the city
from being sued. (Ord. 1725, 7-22-2014)
 
Notes
1 1. 63 OS § 683.17.
13-405: EMERGENCY INTERIM SUCCESSORS 1 :
   A.   In carrying out the provisions of this chapter, in which any disaster
as defined in section
13-401 of this chapter occurs, in the event the mayor is "unavailable" as
defined in section
13-401 of this chapter, then his emergency interim successor shall be the vice
mayor and he shall exercise all powers and duties of the mayor's office. In the
event both the mayor and vice mayor are "unavailable" as defined in section
13-401 of this chapter, the next emergency interim successor shall be the
director of the department of public safety, and he shall exercise all powers
and duties of the mayor's office. In the event the mayor, vice mayor, and
director of the department of public safety are "unavailable" as defined in
section
13-401 of this chapter, the next emergency interim successor shall be the chief
of police, and he shall exercise all powers and duties of the mayor's office.
   B.   An emergency interim successor shall exercise these powers and
discharge these duties only until such time as the lawful incumbent officer or
an emergency interim successor higher in rank in order of succession exercises,
or resumes the exercise of, the powers and discharge of the duties of the
office, or until, where an actual vacancy exists, a successor is appointed to
fill such vacancy or is elected and qualified as provided by law. (Ord. 1725,
7-22-2014)
 
Notes
1 2. 63 OS § 686.3.
CHAPTER 5
UNCLAIMED PROPERTY 1
SECTION:
13-501: Complete Record Required
13-502: Disposition Of Unclaimed Property
13-503: Exchange Of Unclaimed Or Confiscated Weapons
13-504: Property Of Deceased Persons
13-505: Property Found By A Private Person
13-506: Recovery By Owner
 
Notes
1 1. 15 OS § 511 et seq.; 22 OS §§ 1321 et seq., 1261 et seq.
13-501: COMPLETE RECORD REQUIRED:
All personal property which comes into the possession of any police officer,
which has been found or stolen or taken off the person or out of the possession
of any prisoner or person suspected of, or charged with, being a criminal, and
which is not known to belong to some person laying claim thereto, shall be, by
the officer securing possession thereof, delivered into the charge of the chief
of police. The chief shall, in a permanent record book kept for that purpose,
make a record sufficient to identify the property, with the date and
circumstances of the receipt thereof, the name of the person from whom it was
taken and the place where it was found; and the record shall also disclose the
subsequent disposal thereof, giving the date of sale, name and address of the
purchaser, and the amount for which it was sold. (Prior code § 17-1)
13-502: DISPOSITION OF UNCLAIMED PROPERTY:
Any unclaimed personal property, other than animals or weapons, which remains
in the possession of the chief of police, unclaimed, or the ownership of which
is not to him satisfactorily established, for a period of ninety (90) days,
shall be sold, and the proceeds of the sale shall be paid over to the city
treasurer, who shall issue his receipt therefor, and deposit the same to the
credit of the general fund of the city, except such personal property as in the
opinion of the city manager can be more advantageously used by some department
or office of the city government. Ten (10) days before a sale of such unclaimed
property, the chief of police shall sign and have posted in a conspicuous place
in the city treasurer's office, where it will be plainly visible to persons who
visit that office, notice of the time, place, and manner of such sale, and
general description of the property to be sold. However, if in the opinion of
the city manager, all or any portion of the personal property may be more
advantageously used in any city department or office, he shall so instruct the
chief of police in writing, and the chief shall thereupon deliver the personal
property designated to that department or office of city government and make a
permanent record of its disposition. (Prior code § 17-2; amd. 2015 Code)
13-503: EXCHANGE OF UNCLAIMED OR CONFISCATED WEAPONS:
   A.   Unclaimed or confiscated weapons which have been in the possession of
the police department for one hundred twenty (120) days or more may be traded
by the chief of police, with the approval of the city manager or his designee,
for new weapons for use by the police department. The unclaimed or confiscated
weapons may only be traded to such gun dealers who have complied with
applicable state and federal regulations concerning firearms and, in the
opinion of the chief of police and the city manager or his designee, are
reputable.
   B.   In trading such unclaimed or confiscated weapons, the chief of police
shall, with the approval of the city manager or his designee, advertise for
bids for such trade. Such advertisement for bids shall be done in accordance
with prevailing and established bid procedure as formulated by the purchasing
entity of the city; however, in no case may the fair market value of the
weapons received in such trade exceed two thousand five hundred dollars
($2,500.00), unless such trade is accomplished pursuant to formal bid
procedure.
   C.   The value of such unclaimed and confiscated weapons as hereinabove
discussed shall in all cases be determined by their fair market value of the
new weapons received in such trade. (1985 Code)
13-504: PROPERTY OF DECEASED PERSONS:
The personal property of a deceased person shall be delivered only to the next
of kin of such person or to the legally appointed representative of his estate.
If the personal property is claimed by the legally appointed representative of
the estate of the deceased, a certified copy of the order of the district court
appointing such person shall be deemed sufficient authority to support the
claim. If the personal property is claimed by the next of kin, the claimant
shall furnish an affidavit to the effect that he is the person entitled to
possession of the property. The affidavit shall be deemed sufficient authority
to support the claim. If personal property of the deceased person remains
unclaimed for a period of ninety (90) days, it shall be disposed of in the
appropriate manner provided in this chapter. (1985 Code)
13-505: PROPERTY FOUND BY A PRIVATE PERSON:
Any personal property found by a person other than a public official or
employee, which is delivered to any police officer for identification, if not
claimed or identified within thirty (30) days, shall, within ten (10)
additional days thereafter, if requested by the finder, be returned to him, and
a record of such disposal made thereof. If the finder does not request return
of the property to him within such additional ten (10) days, then the chief of
police shall sell the property as if it had been found by a public official or
employee, or on instruction by the city manager deliver it to some department
or office of the city government for its use. (Prior code § 17-3)
13-506: RECOVERY BY OWNER:
If any property is sold as herein provided, and the owner thereof takes and
recovers possession of same from the purchaser, the amount paid therefor shall
be returned to the purchaser, upon verified claim being submitted and approved
by the city council. (Prior code § 17-4)
CHAPTER 6
UNIFORM SYSTEM FOR ADDRESS NAMING AND NUMBERING
SECTION:
13-601: Purpose And Intent
13-602: Jurisdiction
13-603: Numbering System
13-604: Street Name Signs
13-605: Definitions
13-606: Naming City Streets
13-607: Renaming Existing Streets
13-608: Addressing
13-609: Display Of Address Numbers
13-610: New Address Assignment
13-611: Administrator
13-612: Amendments
13-613: Mayor And Council's Review
13-614: Variances And Exceptions
13-615: Appeals
13-616: Enforcement
13-617: Limitation Of Liability
13-618: Separability
13-601: PURPOSE AND INTENT:
The purpose and intent of this chapter is to provide a uniform system of
addresses for all properties and buildings throughout the City of Duncan's
jurisdiction in order to facilitate adequate public safety and decrease
emergency response time. (Ord. 1766, 3-14-2017)
13-602: JURISDICTION:
The jurisdiction of this chapter includes the entire geographic area of the
City limits of Duncan. The City of Duncan Lakes is included in this chapter.
(Ord. 1766, 3-14-2017)
13-603: NUMBERING SYSTEM:
   A.   Frontage unit (standard interval) shall be assigned for every 5.28 feet
of ground whether improved property or vacant lot on every street within the
entire geographical area of City of Duncan.
   B.   Even numbers shall always be on the south and east side of the street
and odd numbers shall always be on the north and west side of the street.
   C.   There should be no use of fractional addresses, alphanumeric address
numbers, nor hyphenated address numbers.
   D.   Diagonal streets should be treated as either north-south or east-west
streets.
   E.   When assigning numbers to corner lots, use the driveway.
   F.   Apartments and other multi-tenant structures should be numbered with
the main building and then assigned apartment numbers as secondary location
indicators (e.g., 202 W. Main St., Apt. 303, this indicates the apartment is on
the third floor). If a building has a separate entrance for each unit then each
entrance will receive an address.
   G.   Businesses and business districts should be numbered just as
apartments, with the middle of the building determining the number and the
offices or businesses in the building being numbered as suites. Office parks
may also have one (1) primary address number along with a building number and/
or suite number. (Ord. 1766, 3-14-2017)
13-604: STREET NAME SIGNS:
   A.   Assignment, Installation And Maintenance Of Street Name Signs: Street
name signs shall be assigned and installed for all streets, whether public or
private and at all intersections throughout the City of Duncan. (Ord. 1766, 3-
14-2017)
13-605: DEFINITIONS:
BASE LINE: Those lines which divide the City into identifiable sectors and
which follow prominent major thoroughfares. In each case, one (1) base line
runs east/west and the other one, north/south. Base lines intersect at a
reference point.
DRIVEWAYS: A private way, beginning at the property line of a lot abutting a
public street, private street, easement or private right-of-way, given access
from that public street, private street or private right-of-way leading to a
building, use or structure on that lot.
FRONTAGE UNIT: A standard interval in feet used to assign consecutive property
numbers on a street. The standard front unit adopted for use throughout the
City of Duncan is 5.28 feet.
OFFICIAL STREET NAMES: The street list name and the street map name on file
with the City of Duncan 911 Addressing Office is hereby declared the official
street names and map for the City of Duncan streets, unless changed by action
of the City of Duncan Mayor and Council.
PRIVATE STREET: Any street, which is not maintained by the City of Duncan
through the use of public funds.
REFERENCE POINT: The reference point for the City of Duncan addressing system
is hereby designated at the point of the intersection of Main Street (north and
south) and 1st Street (east and west).
STREET: A public or private one-way or two-way street for ingress and/or
egress. Such street may be of various types including streets, rear access
streets, streets with cul-de-sacs, and dead- end streets. The definition
includes secondary streets, but does not include driveways.
STREET ADDRESS: The combination of numbers and street names assigned to a
particular location by the City of Duncan 911 Addressing Office, according to
this chapter, which uniquely identifies a particular location. (Ord. 1766, 3-
14-2017)
13-606: NAMING CITY STREETS:
   A.   Names tending to be confused as homonyms, having the same or similar
pronunciation but with different spellings are discouraged.
   B.   Avoid sound alike names (e.g., Bay View and Bayview).
   C.   Do not use special characters in road names such as hyphens,
apostrophes, or dashes.
   D.   Avoid the use of standard suffixes or directional suffixes or prefixes
as road names (e.g., North Blvd., Court St.)
   E.   Avoid duplication of street names.
   F.   If two (2) or more streets have duplicate or confusing names the policy
for renaming existing streets must be considered.
   G.   A street name combination (prefix, primary name and suffix) should be
used only once, and may not be used in any other alignment (e.g., Jones Drive,
Jones Circle, Jones Court, and Jones Street). (Ord. 1766, 3-14-2017)
13-607: RENAMING EXISTING STREETS:
   A.   In the case of two (2) or more conflicting street names the City of
Duncan will take into consideration the older recognized name, number of
addresses on each street, arterial street, historical relevance, existing
street signs, relatedness to the City.
   B.   City of Duncan Address Coordinator will notify the residents of a
street name conflict. Those residents will then have thirty (30) days to
provide street name requests. The Address Coordinator shall determine the new
street name and notify the residents and the United States Postal Service.
   C.   Request for new names and name changes must include a completed
petition signed by at least fifty percent (50%) plus one (1) of the residents
along the affected street. If there are not two (2) addressable structures on
the road the address will be assigned off the main road. The only exception is
in subdevelopments.
   D.   The City of Duncan 911 Addressing Office must approve petitions to name
unnamed streets or to change a street name.
   E.   Petition to change a street name must include a fee of fifty dollars
($50.00) per sign blade to cover cost of replacing signs in addition to one
hundred fifty dollars ($150.00) to advertise public hearings. If the City of
Duncan Community Development Director does not approve the request, only the
sign cost will be refunded.
   F.   The Community Development Director shall consider petitions for street
name changes annually during the first quarter. However, once a street has been
named, the street cannot be repetitioned again until the second calendar year
after the name has been approved.
   G.   There is no fee for requesting names for unnamed public or private
streets; however the procedure is the same.
   H.   Petition applications may be obtained from the City of Duncan 911
Addressing Office, 18 S. 7th St. Duncan, OK.
   I.   The City of Duncan 911 Addressing Coordinator will review requests to
determine if all procedures are met, and to ascertain that the proposed names
do not duplicate an existing name and also to ensure that the petition meets
all other requirements of this chapter. (Ord. 1766, 3-14-2017)
13-608: ADDRESSING:
   A.   All streets both public and private shall be named and addressed if it
is greater than eight hundred feet (800') in length and/or has two (2) or more
addressable structures, including mobile homes, located on and accessed by
them, or if the structure is not visible from the public road.
   B.   When each house or building has been assigned its respective address,
the City of Duncan, in cooperation with the U.S. Postal Service shall notify
the owners or occupant's agents of affected house or building by letter, or by
telephone advising of their new address. (Ord. 1766, 3-14-2017)
13-609: DISPLAY OF ADDRESS NUMBERS:
   A.   The official address number must be displayed on the front of a
building or at the entrance of the building, which is most clearly visible from
the street or road during both day and night.
   B.   If a building is more than one hundred feet (100') from any street, the
address number shall be displayed at the end of the driveway or easement
nearest the street, which provides access to the building.
   C.   Numerals indicating the address number of a single family dwelling
shall be at least four inches (4") in height and shall be posted and maintained
so as to be legible from the road.
   D.   Numerals for multiple dwelling units and non-residential buildings
shall be at least six inches (6") in height and shall be placed on the front of
the building facing the street or on the end of the building nearest the
street.
   E.   Numerals must be of contrasting color to the background.
   F.   Mobile home lots shall have sequential address numbers throughout the
park. Each lot will have a separate address number assigned. The address number
of each lot must be clearly displayed on the lot by being attached to a post on
the lot or to the mobile home consistent with subsection A of this section. No
unit designator shall be allowed in the address of mobile homes.
   G.   The address shall be placed on existing buildings within thirty (30)
days from the date of the letter of notification. (Ord. 1766, 3-14-2017)
13-610: NEW ADDRESS ASSIGNMENT:
   A.   The owner or occupant or person in charge of any house, trailer, or
building in need of an address in the City of Duncan shall apply through the
City of Duncan 911 Addressing Office.
   B.   The application for a 911 address shall be obtained at such time that
the owner, builder, or mobile home company applies for a permit from the City
of Duncan City Planning Department. The applicant must mark the driveway with a
flag until the address is obtained. If the driveway is already cut then no flag
will be needed. This applies to all address locations.
   C.   Final approval for a certificate of occupancy of any principal building
erected or repaired after the effective date of this chapter shall be withheld
until a permanent and proper address has been displayed in accordance with the
requirements outlined in this chapter. This will be strictly enforced. (Ord.
1766, 3-14-2017)
13-611: ADMINISTRATOR:
   A.   The Addressing Coordinator is hereby designated Administrator of this
chapter and shall have authority to verify, modify, or assign addresses and to
enforce the requirements of this chapter.
   B.   The Administrator shall assign and maintain a record of all addresses
for the City of Duncan.
   C.   The Administrator shall maintain a database of existing street names,
such that duplication and sound-alike street names are neither assigned nor
approved. (Ord. 1766, 3-14-2017)
13-612: AMENDMENTS:
Petitions for amendment of this chapter may be filed with the City Manager by
any citizen of the City of Duncan. (Ord. 1766, 3-14-2017)
13-613: MAYOR AND COUNCIL'S REVIEW:
The City of Duncan Mayor and Council according to the following procedure may
amend the provisions and requirements of this chapter:
No amendment shall become effective unless it has been proposed by or shall
have been reviewed by the City of Duncan Addressing Coordinator. The City of
Duncan 911 Addressing Coordinator shall have forty five (45) days in which to
review the proposed amendment and to make the recommendations to Mayor and
Council. If Mayor and Council fail to report within forty five (45) days it
shall be deemed to have approved the proposed amendment. (Ord. 1766, 3-14-2017)
13-614: VARIANCES AND EXCEPTIONS:
   A.   City of Duncan Community Development Director may issue variances and
exceptions from the requirements of this chapter such that would not be
contrary to the public interest, or the spirit and intent of this chapter, and
where due to special conditions, a literal enforcement of the provisions of
this chapter would result in unnecessary hardship. In granting a variance, the
Community Development Director may prescribe appropriate solutions, as it deems
necessary to preserve the intent of this chapter. In granting a variance or
exception to this chapter, Community Development Director may determine the
following:
      1.   Special conditions and circumstances exist which are peculiar to the
street naming or addressing involved and which are not applicable to other
streets or addresses.
      2.   The literal interpretation of the provisions of this chapter would
deprive the applicant of rights commonly enjoyed by other citizens.
      3.   Special conditions and circumstances do not result from the actions
of the applicant; and
      4.   Granting the variance requested will not confer on the applicant any
special privilege that is denied by this chapter to other citizens. (Ord. 1766,
3-14-2017)
13-615: APPEALS:
The provisions of this chapter shall be held to be minimum requirements adopted
for the promotion of the public health, safety, and general welfare. Wherever
the requirements of this chapter differ with the requirements of any other
adopted City, State or Federal regulations, the most restrictive or that
imposing the highest standard shall govern.
Any and all appeals shall be heard by the City Attorney or Assistant City
Attorney. The City Attorney or Assistant City Attorney shall have the
discretion to administratively adjust the requirements consistent with the
purpose of equity. Any appeal or variance determination of the City Attorney or
Assistant City Attorney shall be considered administratively final. (Ord. 1766,
3-14-2017)
13-616: ENFORCEMENT:
After the effective date of this chapter, any person, firm or agent thereof
that intentionally violates this chapter shall be guilty of a misdemeanor, for
the conviction of which, the maximum penalty by law may be imposed. Each day's
continuing violation is a separate and distinct offense. (Ord. 1766, 3-14-2017)
13-617: LIMITATION OF LIABILITY:
The City of Duncan, directors, officers and agents are not liable for any
damages in a civil action for injuries, death, or loss to persons or property
incurred by any person as a result of any act or omission of any of its
employees, directors, officers, or agents, except for willful or wanton
misconduct, in connection with developing, adopting, implementing, maintaining,
or operating any 911 system. (Ord. 1766, 3-14-2017)
13-618: SEPARABILITY:
Should any section or provision of this chapter be declared by the courts to be
invalid for any reason, such declaration shall not affect this chapter as a
whole, or any part thereof other than the part so declared to be invalid. (Ord.
1766, 3-14-2017)
PART 14
STREETS AND PUBLIC WORKS
CHAPTER 1
USE AND OBSTRUCTION OF STREETS
SECTION:
14-101: Street Department; Superintendent
14-102: Trees And Shrubbery To Be Trimmed
14-103: Unlawful To Injure Trees And Shrubbery
14-104: Dead Trees To Be Removed
14-105: Unlawful To Obstruct Sidewalks, Streets With Merchandise
14-106: Unlawful To Obstruct Unduly Sidewalks And Streets
14-107: Unlawful To Deposit Trash Upon Streets Or Sidewalks
14-108: Playing And Congregating On Streets; Noise; Interference
14-109: Unnecessary Obstruction
14-110: Certain Vehicles And Objects Prohibited
14-111: Building Fire On Paved Street Prohibited
14-112: Walking, Driving Or Riding On Streets Being Paved
14-113: Loads On Vehicles, Falling Objects Prohibited
14-114: Certain Things Not To Be Deposited On Streets; Exceptions
14-115: Vehicles Not To Be Washed On Street
14-116: Water From Filling Stations And Other Businesses
14-117: Owner Or Occupant Not To Permit Sidewalk Or Sidewalk Area To Become A
Hazard
14-118: Street Not To Be Obstructed So As To Interfere With Drainage
14-119: Excavations Adjoining Streets
14-120: Duty To Keep Sidewalk And Gutter Clean, Good Repair
14-101: STREET DEPARTMENT; SUPERINTENDENT:
   A.   There shall be a street department, the head of which shall be the
street superintendent, appointed by the city manager for an indefinite term.
Subject to supervision and control by the public works director, the street
superintendent shall have supervision and control of the street department.
   B.   It is the duty of the street department, among others, to construct,
repair, maintain and improve streets, alleys and other public ways. (Prior code
§§ 1-21, 1-22)
14-102: TREES AND SHRUBBERY TO BE TRIMMED:
   A.   The owner of any premises abutting on any street of this city shall
trim all trees and shrubbery growing in the parking, between the sidewalks and
the roadway, of any such street, and all trees and shrubbery growing on any
part of the premises adjacent to the sidewalks or any street or alley, in such
manner that the boughs or limbs thereof shall not obstruct free and convenient
passage and travel along the streets, sidewalks, and alleys. When such premises
are occupied by some person other than the owner, such occupant shall trim the
trees and shrubbery in the same manner as hereinafter required of the owner.
Such trees and shrubbery shall be trimmed so that the lowest branches or
foliage shall not be lower than thirteen feet (13') above the roadway of a
street or alley, nor lower than eight feet (8') above the sidewalk.
   B.   Any owner or occupant who shall fail, refuse or neglect to trim trees
and shrubbery as provided in this section, after receiving five (5) days'
notice from the head of the department in charge of streets to do so, shall be
guilty of an offense against the city. Every day that the owner or occupant
shall fail, refuse or neglect to trim the trees or shrubbery, after the
expiration of the five (5) days' notice, shall be a separate offense.
   C.   Trimming of trees and shrubbery to permit the proper stringing or
passage of utility or other wires or the trimming to maintain proper clearance
for existing wires is specifically authorized and such trimming shall not be
considered a wrongful injury. (Prior code §§ 19-1, 19-2; amd. Ord. 1293, 11-14-
1989)
14-103: UNLAWFUL TO INJURE TREES AND SHRUBBERY:
It is unlawful for any person to injure any tree or shrubbery on a street or
alley in the city; provided that this shall not prohibit the lawful and proper
care and removal of such trees and shrubbery. (Prior code § 19-3)
14-104: DEAD TREES TO BE REMOVED:
The owner, tenant or agent in charge of any property or premises within the
city shall remove or destroy all trees and shrubs upon the property or premises
or from any street or alley directly adjoining and on that side of the line
extending along the center of such street or alley next to the property or
premises as soon as such tree or shrub shall die. (Prior code § 19-4)
14-105: UNLAWFUL TO OBSTRUCT SIDEWALKS, STREETS WITH MERCHANDISE:
It is unlawful for any person, firm or corporation to place upon or permit to
be placed upon the sidewalks, parkways, right of ways, streets and alleys of
the city any goods, wares, articles of merchandise or any other obstruction,
and leave same thereon or to use the same as a place to carry on a business or
trade. (Prior code § 19-4)
14-106: UNLAWFUL TO OBSTRUCT UNDULY SIDEWALKS AND STREETS:
It is unlawful for any person, firm or corporation to use or obstruct the
sidewalks of the city in any manner so as to interfere unduly with pedestrian
traffic thereon, or to use or obstruct the streets and alleys of the city in
any manner so as to interfere unduly with lawful traffic and parking thereon.
(Prior code § 19-6)
14-107: UNLAWFUL TO DEPOSIT TRASH UPON STREETS OR SIDEWALKS:
It is unlawful for any person, firm or corporation to deposit, throw or sweep
into or upon the streets, alleys, parking or sidewalks of the city any paper,
rubbish, grass, weeds, tree trimmings, dirt, trash, crates, boxes or other
refuse of any kind. (Prior code § 19-8)
14-108: PLAYING AND CONGREGATING ON STREETS; NOISE; INTERFERENCE:
It is unlawful and an offense against the city, for any person to obstruct the
free, convenient and normal use of any public sidewalk, street, highway,
bridge, alley, road or other passageway, or the entrance, corridor or passage
of any public building or structure by impeding, hindering, stifling, retarding
or restraining traffic or passage thereon or therein after having been
requested by a police officer to move on. (Prior code § 19-7)
14-109: UNNECESSARY OBSTRUCTION:
Any person who shall unnecessarily obstruct any sidewalk or any street or
alley, walk or public ground within the city with any boxes, barrels, vehicles,
animals, lumber, wood or any material or structure whatever, or shall ride or
drive over and upon any sidewalk of the city, or dig any hole in the same,
shall be deemed guilty of an offense and be punished as herein provided. (Prior
code § 19-9)
14-110: CERTAIN VEHICLES AND OBJECTS PROHIBITED:
It is unlawful to drive or move on any street or alley any vehicle or object
which injures or would injure the surface of the street or alley. (Prior code §
19-10)
14-111: BUILDING FIRE ON PAVED STREET PROHIBITED:
It is unlawful for any person to build any fire or place any hot substance upon
any paved street, alley, sidewalk or thoroughfare, or any portion thereof. The
term "paved street, alley, sidewalk or thoroughfare", is to be construed to
include any street, alley, sidewalk or thoroughfare the surface of which is
paved or covered with pavement of any kind or character. (Prior code § 19-11)
14-112: WALKING, DRIVING OR RIDING ON STREETS BEING PAVED:
   A.   All persons are hereby prohibited from walking, riding or driving upon,
across or over any part of any street, alley or sidewalk in the city while such
part thereof is being paved, surfaced, excavated or repaired. (Prior code § 19-
12)
   B.   The city shall follow guidelines of the "Manual On Uniform Traffic
Control Devices" pertaining to street, alley and/or sidewalk closures. (Prior
code § 19-12; amd. 2015 Code)
14-113: LOADS ON VEHICLES, FALLING OBJECTS PROHIBITED:
   A.   No vehicle shall be driven or moved on any street, alley or other
public way unless such vehicle is so constructed or loaded as to prevent any of
its load from dropping, sifting, leaking, blowing or otherwise escaping
therefrom.
   B.   No person shall operate on any street, alley or other public way any
vehicle with any load unless the load and any covering thereon is securely
fastened so as to prevent the covering or load from becoming loose, detached or
in any manner a hazard to other users of the street, alley or other public way.
Any vehicle loaded with trash, tree limbs, garbage, sand, cinders, dirt, rock,
debris, or any other loose material susceptible to blowing or escaping by
reason of wind or movement of the vehicle shall have the load covered with a
tarpaulin or securely fastened with tie downs so as to prevent the blowing or
escaping of the load or any part thereof from the vehicle.
   C.   This section shall not apply to work done on any street, alley or other
public way under the direction of the city. (Prior code § 19-14)
14-114: CERTAIN THINGS NOT TO BE DEPOSITED ON STREETS; EXCEPTIONS:
   A.   It is unlawful for any person to place any lighted cigarette, cigar,
ashes, or other flaming or glowing substance or any substance or things which
may cause a fire; or any bottles, tin cans, paper cups, paper napkins, straws,
newspaper or other trash, garbage or debris of any kind or character whatsoever
in, upon, or within the limits of any surveyed or dedicated street, alley,
state or federal highway, county road or public property owned by the city, the
state, the federal government or the county, within the city limits of the
city.
   B.   The provisions of this section shall not apply to:
      1.   Flaming or glowing substances which by law may be placed upon any
street, alley, state or federal highway, for the purposes of public safety; or
      2.   Trash, garbage or debris placed in a garbage container or placed
beside a public street, alley, highway or road for collection by an established
garbage or collection agency.
   C.   The police department of the city and each officer thereof and all
other peace officers in this state shall have the authority to enforce the
provisions of this section. (Prior code §§ 19-24, 19-25, 19-26)
14-115: VEHICLES NOT TO BE WASHED ON STREET:
The washing of an automobile or other vehicle in any street of the city is
hereby prohibited. (Prior code § 19-16)
14-116: WATER FROM FILLING STATIONS AND OTHER BUSINESSES:
It is unlawful for any owner or operator of a filling station or other place of
business, or any agent or employee thereof, to cause or allow water, grease or
other fluid to flow or drain into, upon, over or across any sidewalk, parking,
street, alley or other public way. (Prior code § 19-18)
14-117: OWNER OR OCCUPANT NOT TO PERMIT SIDEWALK OR SIDEWALK AREA TO BECOME A
HAZARD:
It is unlawful for the owner or occupant of property abutting upon a sidewalk
area to permit the sidewalk or sidewalk area adjacent to the property to become
a hazard to persons using the sidewalk, or sidewalk area. (Prior code § 19-19)
14-118: STREET NOT TO BE OBSTRUCTED SO AS TO INTERFERE WITH DRAINAGE:
It is unlawful for any person, firm, or corporation to obstruct any street,
sidewalk, or alley, by placing any approach driveway or other obstruction or
substance whatever that will obstruct or prevent the natural flow of water,
into the storm sewers or drains, or dam the same so as to back any water upon
the streets, alleys, sidewalks, or gutter. (Prior code § 19-15)
14-119: EXCAVATIONS ADJOINING STREETS:
All excavations upon the front or side of any lot adjoining any street, avenue
or alley or under sidewalk in the city, shall be securely and properly guarded
and protected by the person or persons having charge of the same so as to
prevent the same from being or becoming dangerous to life or limb. (1985 Code)
14-120: DUTY TO KEEP SIDEWALK AND GUTTER CLEAN, GOOD REPAIR:
It is the duty of the occupant of any lot or piece of ground abutting upon any
street where there is a sidewalk or gutter on the street to keep such sidewalk
or gutter clean and to remove therefrom all hay, straw, papers, stone, snow or
ice, dirt, filth, weeds, refuse, rubbish or hazards of any kind and to keep the
sidewalk and gutter in good repair. If there is no such occupant of any such
lot other than the owner, it is the duty of the owner to do the same. (1985
Code)
CHAPTER 2
OPENINGS IN STREETS
SECTION:
14-201: Permit To Open Street
14-202: Refilling, Maintenance And Penalty
14-203: Openings, How Refilled
14-204: Barricades And Lights
14-201: PERMIT TO OPEN STREET:
   A.   Any plumber or other person desiring to cut into or in any manner open
any public street, alley, sidewalk or other public ground, whether paved,
graveled, graded or not, in the city, for any purpose whatever, shall first
obtain a permit from the city code enforcement official to cut or open such
street, alley, sidewalk or other public ground.
   B.   Prior to the issuance of a permit as required herein, the city code
enforcement official or his designated representative may require a deposit in
an amount sufficient to refill and repair the requested cut or opening in
accordance with the requirements of section
14-202 of this chapter. All deposits shall be made with the city treasurer and
shall be held in a special fund. Such deposit to be released to the permit
holder upon certification by the city code enforcement official or his
designated representative that refilling and repairing of the cut or opening
has been performed in accordance with the requirements of sections
14-202 and
14-203 of this chapter. (Prior code § 19-20)
14-202: REFILLING, MAINTENANCE AND PENALTY:
   A.   It is the duty of the permit holder to comply with the provisions of
sections
14-201 and
14-203 of this chapter and all work required shall be completed immediately.
   B.   After satisfactory refill and repair as required by section
14-203 of this chapter, it is the responsibility of the permit holder to
immediately perform any and all, subsequent refill, repair and maintenance on
the cuts or openings for a period of twelve (12) months from the date of the
permit upon notice from the city code enforcement official or his designated
representative.
   C.   Upon failure of the permit holder to make adequate refill and repair as
required by this chapter, the city may refill or repair or secure the work by
contract with the cost of the work being assessed against the permit holder.
Failure of the permit holder to pay such costs shall be grounds for denial of
any and all future permits required by section
14-201 of this chapter and the permit holder shall be subject to all other
penalties provided for in this chapter. (Prior code § 19-21)
14-203: OPENINGS, HOW REFILLED:
   A.   When any street, alley, sidewalk or the public ground has been cut or
opened for any purpose the permit holder shall refill and repair the cut or
opening using sand placed in the opening in layers or lifts not exceeding six
inches (6") in depth and tamped following each layer or lift to the surface.
   B.   All surfaces shall be restored with similar materials and workmanship
as originally existed prior to the cut or opening and subject to the approval
of the city code enforcement official or his designated representative.
   C.   All dirt and other materials taken from the cut or opening shall be
hauled away by the permit holder. (Prior code § 19-22)
14-204: BARRICADES AND LIGHTS:
In all cases where the surface of the street, alley, sidewalk or other public
ground is disturbed, the party so cutting into the opening shall maintain
suitable barricades and shall place lights at night to protect persons from
danger. (Prior code § 19-23)
CHAPTER 3
USE OF STREETS IN BUILDING
SECTION:
14-301: Temporary Occupancy Of Streets With Building Material; Permit And Bond
14-302: Requisite Of Permit; Amount Of Obstruction Permitted; Certain Streets
Excepted; No Advertising
14-303: Protection Of Sidewalks
14-304: May Occupy Part Of Street; Lights
14-301: TEMPORARY OCCUPANCY OF STREETS WITH BUILDING MATERIAL; PERMIT AND BOND:
   A.   Any person desiring to temporarily occupy any portion of any public
street, alley or sidewalk within the city, for the purpose of placing thereon
material or rubbish for or from building operations or for excavation of any
area thereunder or for any purpose whatever connected with the erection,
removal, alteration or repair of any building or other structure, shall apply
to the city engineer/public works director or designee for a permit for such
temporary occupation.
   B.   It is unlawful to occupy or obstruct any street, alley or sidewalk
without a written permit therefor from the city engineer/public works director
or designee.
   C.   The permit shall not be issued until the person applying therefor shall
have first presented a building permit therefor, together with a bond approved
by the city manager in such sum as shall be fixed by the engineer/public works
director or designee conditioned that the principal therein will discharge all
claims of every character arising from or occasioned by such occupancy of such
street, alley or sidewalk, or the construction or repair of such building, or
the making of such excavation and discharge all judgments obtained together
with all costs attached thereto against the city by reason of any such claim,
injury or damage sustained. (Prior code § 4-32; amd. 2015 Code)
   D.   Every person carrying on any such excavation or building operation
shall keep all streets, alleys, and sidewalks adjacent to such excavation or
building operations carried on by them in a clean and orderly condition and not
obstructed, except as provided herein, during such operation.
   E.   At the expiration of the time stipulated in the permit aforesaid, they
shall restore all such streets, alleys and sidewalks to as good condition as
they were before the beginning of such operations.
   F.   A violation of any of the provisions of this chapter shall, upon final
conviction thereof, constitute and work a forfeiture of all rights and
privileges granted by the permit hereinbefore mentioned. (Prior code § 4-32)
14-302: REQUISITE OF PERMIT; AMOUNT OF OBSTRUCTION PERMITTED; CERTAIN STREETS
EXCEPTED; NO ADVERTISING:
   A.   Permits for temporary street occupancy as hereinbefore provided shall
be issued by the city engineer/public works director or designee, shall be in
writing, and shall be for a period of time not to exceed ninety (90) days or
such time as the city engineer/public works director or designee may deem
expedient.
   B.   The permit shall specify how much of the street, sidewalk or alley
shall be obstructed which amount of obstruction shall be within the discretion
of the city engineer/public works director or designee. No more than one-half
(1/2) of any alley nor more than two-thirds (2/3) of any sidewalk nor more than
one-fourth (1/4) of any street shall be obstructed. (Prior code § 4-33; amd.
2015 Code)
   C.   When any building within the fire limits of the city is being repaired
or constructed, no part of the streets or the intersecting side streets shall
be obstructed by any lumber or material of any kind, and the streets shall be
kept open and clear for conveyance, traffic and travelers by foot, at all
times, except that sidewalks shall be restored to travel and the same roofed
and covered with proper and sufficient material to protect the traveling
public, while passing, from falling material of any kind.
   D.   No advertising of any kind or character shall be placed on the
structure or barricades on or inside the street lines of any street. (Prior
code § 4-33)
14-303: PROTECTION OF SIDEWALKS:
   A.   Whenever any portion of any street, alley or sidewalk shall be
obstructed under a permit as hereinbefore provided, the sidewalk and driveway
thereon shall be protected by a covering which shall be sufficient to protect
the public from danger attendant upon such building. The driveway and sidewalk
sufficient, in the opinion of the city engineer/public works director or
designee to accommodate the public, shall be kept in good condition for travel.
(Prior code § 4-34; amd. 2015 Code)
   B.   Failure to comply with this section shall immediately work a forfeiture
of the permit given thereunder and all rights and privileges granted therein.
(Prior code § 4-34)
14-304: MAY OCCUPY PART OF STREET; LIGHTS:
Any person or persons erecting any building may for the time occupy a
reasonable portion of the street in front of such building pursuant to this
chapter. The person occupying such street shall place and keep lights on the
material at night and maintain suitable barricades to protect persons from
danger. Such portions of the street so used for placing building material shall
not in any case exceed the specifications set out in this chapter. (Prior code
§ 4-35)
CHAPTER 4
STRUCTURES UNDER AND ABOVE STREETS AND ALLEYS
SECTION:
14-401: Approval Authorized
14-402: Application
14-403: Notice
14-404: Utility Relocations
14-405: Action On Application
14-406: Other Ordinances, Rules And Regulations
14-407: Appeals; Notice Of Intent To Appeal
14-401: APPROVAL AUTHORIZED:
   A.   The city engineer/public works director or designee may authorize and
regulate tunnels, walkways and other structures under and above public streets,
roads and alleys in accordance with the procedures set forth below.
   B.   In approving the construction of a tunnel, walkway or other structure
under or above a public street, road or alley the city engineer/public works
director or designee shall make written findings to the effect that: (Ord.
1277, 12-8-1987; amd. 2015 Code)
      1.   Such structure, tunnel or walkway shall not interfere with the
public use of the street, road or alley; and
      2.   Such structure, tunnel or walkway shall not unduly affect the right
of any public utility or franchise holder to maintain, install, replace or
repair facilities within the right of way of the street, road or alley. (Ord.
1277, 12-8-1987)
14-402: APPLICATION:
   A.   Application to construct a tunnel, walkway or other structure shall be
made to the city engineer/public works director or designee by the party or
parties requesting the same. Such application shall include plans, drawings or
other descriptions adequate to review and evaluate the proposal, to the
satisfaction of the city engineer/public works director or designee. (Ord.
1277, 12-8-1987; amd. 2015 Code)
   B.   If properties adjacent to the proposed structure are not under the same
ownership, the application shall bear evidence of joint application by all
owners of property contiguous to the proposed structure. (Ord. 1277, 12-8-1987)
14-403: NOTICE:
Upon receipt of an application under this chapter the city engineer/public
works director or designee shall provide notice of the request to all public
utilities and franchise holders having a right or privilege to maintain
facilities within streets and alleys in the city. Notice shall allow not less
than thirty (30) days for review and comment upon such application. (Ord. 1277,
12-8-1987; amd. 2015 Code)
14-404: UTILITY RELOCATIONS:
When an application for construction of a tunnel, walkway or other structure,
if approved, would require the relocation of facilities of a utility company or
franchise holder having a special right or privilege to maintain, replace,
repair or install facilities within a right of way of a public street or alley,
it shall be the responsibility of the applicant or applicants to provide
evidence of agreement to such relocation from the utility or franchise holder
or holders so affected. (Ord. 1277, 12-8-1987)
14-405: ACTION ON APPLICATION:
   A.   The city engineer/public works director or designee shall, after
expiration of the review and comment period, approve, deny or request further
information in support of the application. (Ord. 1277, 12-8-1987; amd. 2015
Code)
   B.   Any action upon the application shall be made in writing and may bear
such conditions and requirements as may be deemed appropriate to secure and
maintain the rights and privileges of the public and utility companies or
franchise holders.
   C.   A copy of the application approval, including all conditions and
requirements shall be attached to and made a part of the building permit for
the tunnel, walkway or structure. (Ord. 1277, 12-8-1987)
14-406: OTHER ORDINANCES, RULES AND REGULATIONS:
Nothing in this chapter shall be interpreted as abrogating any other provisions
of city ordinances or the laws of the state. (Ord. 1277, 12-8-1987)
14-407: APPEALS; NOTICE OF INTENT TO APPEAL:
   A.   Any party or parties aggrieved by a decision under this chapter may
appeal such decision to a court of competent jurisdiction.
   B.   Notice of intent to appeal shall be given to the clerk of the city
within ten (10) days of the action which is being appealed. Notice of intent to
appeal shall stay the issuance of any building permit for a period of fifteen
(15) days from receipt of the notice. If an appeal has not been filed in a
court of competent jurisdiction within fifteen (15) days of notice of an
appeal, a permit for such construction may be issued. If such appeal is filed
within the specified fifteen (15) days after notice of intent to appeal no
permit for construction shall be issued prior to resolution of such appeal.
(Ord. 1277, 12-8-1987)
CHAPTER 5
PARADES
SECTION:
14-501: Definitions
14-502: Permit Required
14-503: Exemptions
14-504: Permit Application
14-505: Permit Fee And Application
14-506: Issuance; Denial; Revocation
14-507: Place Of Parade
14-508: Police Assistance On Private Property
14-509: Carrying Permit
14-510: Compliance With Laws And Regulations
14-501: DEFINITIONS:
As used in this chapter, the term "parade" shall mean any parade, march,
ceremony, show, exhibition, pageant, demonstration, celebration, or procession
of any kind, or any similar display, in or upon any street, park or other
public place. (Ord. 1625, 4-11-2006)
14-502: PERMIT REQUIRED:
It shall be unlawful for any person to conduct or cause to be conducted any
parade, public meeting, celebration or demonstration on any of the streets,
highways, alleys, parks, public places or other public grounds of the city
without first having obtained a permit therefor from the city manager as herein
provided. (Ord. 1625, 4-11-2006)
14-503: EXEMPTIONS:
This chapter shall not apply to:
   A.   Funeral processions;
   B.   Students going to and from school classes or participating in
educational activities, providing such conduct is under the immediate direction
and supervision of the proper school authorities;
   C.   A governmental agency acting within the scope of its functions. (Ord.
1625, 4-11-2006)
14-504: PERMIT APPLICATION:
   A.   Method Of Obtaining: At least seven (7) working days (weekend and
holidays excluded) before any person intends to conduct any parade, meeting,
celebration or demonstration pursuant to this chapter, written application for
a permit therefor shall be filed with the city manager and the application
shall be accompanied by a written statement giving the name of the sponsoring
person, firm, corporation or organization; the route, dates and time of the
parade, the approximate number of persons and vehicles to take part, and the
date, time and place of the public meeting, celebration or demonstration, the
area to be occupied, and the approximate number of persons and vehicles to take
part; and the nature and purpose of the parade, meeting or demonstration.
   B.   Applications: The application for a parade permit shall set forth the
following information:
      1.   The name, address and telephone number of the person seeking to
conduct such parade;
      2.   If the parade is proposed to be conducted for, on behalf of, or by
an organization, the name, address and telephone number of the headquarters of
the organization, and of the authorized and responsible heads of such
organization;
      3.   The name, address and telephone number of the person who will be the
parade chairman and who will be responsible for its conduct;
      4.   The date when the parade is to be conducted;
      5.   The route to be traveled, the starting point and the termination
point;
      6.   The approximate number of persons who, and animals and vehicles
which, will constitute such parade; the type of animals, and description of the
vehicles;
      7.   The location where such parade will start and terminate. If the
parade or event is to take place in a city park or city owned building, the
name and location of such city owned property;
      8.   A statement as to whether the parade will occupy all or only a
portion of the width of the streets proposed to be traversed;
      9.   The location by streets of any assembly areas for such parade;
      10.   The time at which units of the parade will begin to assemble at any
such assembly area or areas;
      11.   The interval of space to be maintained between units of such
parade;
      12.   If the parade is designed to be held by, and on behalf of or for,
any person other than the applicant, the applicant for such permit shall file
with the city manager a communication in writing from the person proposing to
hold the parade, authorizing the applicant to apply for the permit on his
behalf;
      13.   Any additional information which the city manager shall find
reasonably necessary to a fair determination as to whether a permit should
issue;
      14.   Use of any sound amplification equipment by type. (Ord. 1625, 4-11-
2006)
14-505: PERMIT FEE AND APPLICATION:
There shall be a twenty dollar ($20.00) processing fee for a parade permit. The
permit application may be obtained from the office of the city clerk or from
the offices of the Duncan police department. (Ord. 1625, 4-11-2006)
14-506: ISSUANCE; DENIAL; REVOCATION:
   A.   Consideration: The city manager, where good cause is shown therefor,
shall have the authority to consider any application hereunder which is filed
less than seven (7) days before the date such parade is proposed to be
conducted.
   B.   Duty Of City Manager: It shall be the duty of the city manager upon
receipt of an application under this section to make such investigation and
inquiry as he deems necessary to determine whether any regular municipal
service of the city will be hampered, obstructed or delayed, the anticipated
degree of interference with general traffic, and the public convenience, and
the probable extent of extra policing, traffic control or other protective
service of the city reasonably occasioned thereby. If such interruption of
municipal service, traffic or public convenience, or if the extent of extra
services required is found to be unreasonable or detrimental to the interest of
the public, he shall endorse such finding upon the application and refuse to
grant the same.
   C.   Standards For Permit Issuance: The city manager shall issue a parade
permit when, from a consideration of the application and from such other
information as may otherwise be obtained, he finds that:
      1.   The conduct of the parade will not substantially interrupt the safe
and orderly movement of other traffic contiguous to its route;
      2.   The conduct of the parade will not require the diversion of so great
a number of police officers of this city to properly police the line of
movement and the areas contiguous thereto as to prevent normal police
protection to this city;
      3.   The conduct of such parade will not require the diversion of so
great a number of ambulances as to prevent normal ambulance service to portions
of this city other than that to be occupied by the proposed line of march and
areas contiguous thereto;
      4.   The concentration of persons, animals and vehicles at assembly
points of the parade will not unduly interfere with proper fire and police
protection of, or ambulance service to, areas contiguous to such assembly
areas;
      5.   The conduct of such parade will not interfere with the movement of
firefighting equipment en route to a fire;
      6.   The conduct of the parade is not reasonably likely to cause injury
to persons or property, to provoke disorderly conduct or create a disturbance;
      7.   The parade is scheduled to move from its point of origin to its
point of termination expeditiously and without unreasonable delays en route;
      8.   The parade is not to be held for the sole purpose of advertising any
product, cause, goods or events and is not designed to be held purely for
private profit.
   D.   Notice Of Permit Denial: If the city manager disapproves the
application for a parade permit, he shall mail to the applicant within three
(3) days after the date upon which the application was filed, a notice of his
action.
   E.   Revocation:
      1.   Any permit granted by the city manager under this chapter shall be
revocable at any time by the city manager when, in his discretion, it is
determined that the parade, meeting, celebration or demonstration has or will
unduly hamper or interfere with any regular municipal service, general traffic
or public convenience.
      2.   Except as provided in subsection E1 of this section the city manager
shall have the authority, after a hearing affording due process, to revoke a
parade permit issued hereunder upon application of the standards for issuance
as set forth in this chapter. (Ord. 1625, 4-11-2006)
14-507: PLACE OF PARADE:
The place of the parade may be restricted to a location described by the city
manager when said permit request is approved. The location of the parade may be
limited to specific areas upon any street, park or other public place in order
to ensure crowd management, preclude disruptive movement and ensure no
interference with general traffic, public safety or access to public buildings,
parks, sidewalks, parking areas or other public place. (Ord. 1625, 4-11-2006)
14-508: POLICE ASSISTANCE ON PRIVATE PROPERTY:
When it is anticipated by private property owners, that an event of a type
defined in section
14-501 of this chapter will take place on the owner's premises and when the
owner determines that crowd management is beyond the owners' capability to
control, the owner may request the assistance of the city police department.
The owner shall advise the city police department in writing of the following:
   A.   Date and place of the event;
   B.   Nature of the event;
   C.   Area of owner's property to which the event is to be restricted;
   D.   Authority of the city of Duncan to make arrests for trespass by any
participant in the event of entry onto restricted portions of the property;
   E.   Affidavit requesting that the city police enter on the owner's property
for purposes of crowd control. (Ord. 1625, 4-11-2006)
14-509: CARRYING PERMIT:
The parade chairman or other person heading or leading such activity shall
carry the parade permit upon his person during the conduct of the parade. (Ord.
1625, 4-11-2006)
14-510: COMPLIANCE WITH LAWS AND REGULATIONS:
A person holding a parade permit shall comply with all permit directions and
conditions attached to said permit and with all applicable laws and ordinances.
(Ord. 1625, 4-11-2006)
CHAPTER 6
DRIVEWAY STANDARDS
SECTION:
14-601: Scope And Application
14-602: Statement Of Purpose
14-603: Permit Required
14-604: Certificate Of Completion Or Occupancy
14-605: Right Of Access
14-606: Appeals
14-607: Penalty For Violation
14-608: Driveway Regulations
14-609: Construction Standards
14-610: Figures
14-601: SCOPE AND APPLICATION:
The provisions of this chapter shall apply to the construction, modification or
revision of any facility providing vehicular access between a public street and
private property within the city. (Ord. 1263, 1-13-1987)
14-602: STATEMENT OF PURPOSE:
It is the purpose of this chapter to provide for the public health, safety and
general welfare by controlling the number, location and design of driveways and
appurtenant improvements in order to:
   A.   Minimize conflicts between traffic on public streets and traffic
entering and exiting private property;
   B.   Protect the traffic capacity of public streets;
   C.   Protect street rights of way from encroachments which may restrict
future public improvements therein;
   D.   Assure safe and adequate ingress and egress to private property; and
   E.   Supplement the provisions and requirements of the major street plan for
the city. (Ord. 1263, 1-13-1987)
14-603: PERMIT REQUIRED:
   A.   It shall be unlawful and a violation of this chapter for any person,
firm, corporation, partnership or association to remove, alter, erect or
construct any curb, gutter, approach, driveway or drainage facility upon or
within a public street right of way without first obtaining a permit therefor
from the director of public works or his/her designated representative.
   B.   Application for a permit, as herein required, shall be made on the form
specified by the director of public works and shall be accompanied by such plot
plan or survey as may be required to assure compliance with this chapter. At a
minimum, such plan or survey shall accurately indicate existing and proposed
buildings, driveways, utilities, parking arrangements, property lines and
adjacent street improvements.
   C.   The application for a driveway permit shall be accompanied by a permit
fee as shall be set by motion of the city council. Such fee shall be
nonrefundable and shall be considered as including necessary and appropriate
site inspection fees.
   D.   A separate driveway permit shall not be required in conjunction with a
building permit; provided, that:
      1.   The public works director shall approve the plans for any multi-
family, commercial or industrial facilities prior to issuance of a building
permit; and
      2.   The public works director shall be notified of issuance of all
building permits involving driveway improvements. (Ord. 1263, 1-13-1987)
14-604: CERTIFICATE OF COMPLETION OR OCCUPANCY:
No building, construction or site improvement issued a driveway permit or
building permit shall be considered satisfactorily completed until driveway
construction or modification therein required has been completed, and no
certificate of occupancy or completion shall be issued therefor without the
approval of the public works director, or his/her designated representative.
(Ord. 1263, 1-13-1987)
14-605: RIGHT OF ACCESS:
Nothing in this chapter shall be construed as denying reasonable access to a
public street from an adjacent property unless such street is a limited access
roadway. In such instance where the size, shape or topography of a tract of
land makes compliance with the provisions of this chapter impractical or
imposes an undue hardship, the owner or tenant thereof may appeal the strict
application of this chapter to the public works director. (Ord. 1263, 1-13-
1987)
14-606: APPEALS:
   A.   Any person appealing the strict application of these standards shall
submit to the public works director a written appeal specifying:
      1.   The portion or portions of provisions of this chapter being
appealed;
      2.   The conditions unique to the property which make the application of
such provisions impractical and unreasonable; and
      3.   Plans showing the applicant's proposed alternative.
   B.   Upon receipt of an application on appeal, the public works director
shall, within five (5) working days, make a determination as to the merits of
the appeal. Such determination shall be made in writing and shall consider:
      1.   Validity of the hardship claimed, as compared to an inconvenience;
      2.   Ability of the site to provide access without the relief requested;
and
      3.   Uniqueness of the size, shape or topographic conditions claimed to
create an undue hardship.
   C.   Upon a finding that an appeal is reasonable and necessary, the public
works director may issue a driveway permit granting such relief as necessary to
allow suitable access to the site and bearing such conditions as necessary to
meet the spirit and intent of this chapter.
   D.   Upon a finding that an appeal is not reasonable or necessary, the
public works director shall so inform the applicant in writing, accompanied by
the findings.
   E.   Upon receipt of the public works director's findings, an applicant may
request a hearing of his appeal before the board of adjustment. Such hearing
shall be held only after notice of hearing as required for a zoning variance.
At such hearing, the applicant, interested parties and public works director
shall be heard.
   F.   In considering an appeal, the board of adjustment shall be required to
make the same findings required for a zoning variance in order to grant the
appeal. The board may approve the requested driveways, modify the requested
driveways or deny the request.
   G.   Appeal from the board of adjustment's action may be taken to district
court as provided in the zoning ordinance. (Ord. 1263, 1-13-1987)
14-607: PENALTY FOR VIOLATION:
Violation of the provisions of this chapter shall be considered an offense
against the city, punishable, upon conviction, in accordance with section
1-108 of this code. (Ord. 1263, 1-13-1987)
14-608: DRIVEWAY REGULATIONS:
   A.   Standard Driveway Dimensions:
      1.   For purposes of this chapter, allowable driveway dimensions shall
vary with the type of land use they serve as classified under the zoning
ordinance, and as follows:
         a.   Residential driveways serve one- and two-family dwelling sites.
         b.   Multi-family driveways serve three (3) or more dwellings and uses
permitted on review in a residential district and churches.
         c.   Commercial driveways serve uses permitted by right and upon
review in any commercial zoning district.
         d.   Industrial driveways serve uses allowed only in industrial zoning
districts.
      2.   Allowable driveway dimensions are hereby established as contained in
table 1, "Standard Driveway Dimensions", of this section.
The requirements of the table of standard driveway dimensions and the terms
used therein are illustrated in section
14-610, figures 1 through 5 of this chapter.
   B.   Limitations On Number And Total Driveway Opening:
      1.   In order to restrict the number of points of conflict between
traffic upon a public street and traffic entering and exiting private property,
the number and total width of driveways shall be limited in proportion to the
street frontage of the property served, in accordance with table 2,
"Limitations On Number And Total Driveway Opening", of this section.
      2.   The limitations on driveways shall be applied to individual tracts
of record under the same ownership as shown in the office of the county clerk
for Stephens County.
      3.   Calculation of allowable driveways and widths shall be based on a
single street frontage. Properties with frontage on two (2) or more streets
shall have limitations calculated for each frontage. Allowable driveways and
widths must be located adjacent to the frontage on which they are based.
   TABLE 1
   STANDARD DRIVEWAY DIMENSIONS

                                  provisions of tables 1 and 2 of this section
                                  shall still apply.
